Taxpayers are entitled to expect that any IRS request, examination or enforcement action will be in accordance with the law, not more intrusive than necessary, and will be carried out with full due process of law, including protection from search and seizure, and due process of law recovery hearings, where applicable.

Taxpayers are entitled to hire a designated representative of their choice to represent them with the IRS.1 If a taxpayer cannot afford a paid representative, he is entitled to receive assistance from the Low Income Taxpayers’ Assistance Unit.2 u

We accept most tax returns as they are filed. If we inquire about your return or select it for verification, it does not mean you are in bad faith. The inquiry or verification may or may not result in a tax increase. We may close your case without amendment, or you may receive a refund.

If we have already reviewed your tax return for the same items in the previous year or year before and have not suggested changes to your tax liability, please contact us as soon as possible so that we can decide whether we should stop the review.

If you do not wish to use the services of the IRS Independent Appeals Division or do not agree with its findings, you can refer your case to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Federal Claims Court, or the U.S. Federal District Court of your place of residence. If you refer your case to court, the IRS will have the burden of proving certain facts, provided you have made the appropriate records to reflect your tax liability, have cooperated with the IRS, and have met certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that our position was substantially unjustified, you will be able to recover some of your administrative and litigation costs. You will not be entitled to compensation for these delays unless you have attempted to resolve your case through administrative means, including through the appeals system, and have provided us with the information necessary to resolve the case.
As a rule, both you and your spouse are responsible for paying the full amount of taxes, interest and fines due under your joint return.

Generally, the IRS deals directly with you or your legal representative. However, sometimes we speak to others to obtain information that you have not been able to provide, or to verify information we have received. If we contact others, such as a neighbor, bank, employer, or employee, we are generally required to provide them with limited information, such as your name. The law prohibits us from disclosing more information than is necessary to obtain or verify the information required. Our need to contact others may continue for as long as activity on your case is ongoing. If we contact others, you have the right to request a list of the people we have contacted. This request can be made by phone, in writing, or during a face-to-face interview.
You can file a refund if you believe you have paid too much tax. Usually, you have to file a refund within 45 days of filing your return or claiming a refund.
If you are facing a serious tax issue, or you have tried but failed to solve your problem with the IRS, the organization will do its best to help you.

The IRS provides the following sources of forms, publications and additional information. Internet : IRS.gov/Help/Tax-Law-Questions and How to Get Help Preparing Taxes. Forms and Publications : IRS.gov/Forms and IRS.gov/OrderForms.

After receiving your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment benefit reports (mailed or electronically) or other government payments reports (Form 1099-G), as well as interest and dividends reports from banks (Forms 1099), you have several options for preparing and filing your tax return.
To complete the forms, you need to open an IRS account. You can file the forms online or by downloading and sending them by mail.
Go to IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account. View your amounts due and breakdown by tax year. View your payment agreement details or apply for a new payment plan.
With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process.
This tool allows your tax professional to apply for authorization to access your individual online account with the IRS. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.
The safest and easiest way to get your return is to file it online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account.

The following are options for preparing and filing your return online or at your home if you are eligible. Direct File Direct File is a finally approved software that allows you to file federal individual tax returns online free of charge and securely. Direct File is for partner state taxpayers who file relatively simple tax returns that include certain types of income and certain credits and deductions. While you cannot file a state return using Direct File if you live in a partner state, the system will redirect you to state-approved tax software for free state return filing. For more information, updates and answers to frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile The Free File Program. This program allows you to prepare and file your federal tax return using the Free File software or forms. However, filing a state tax return may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to find out if you qualify for both free federal tax return preparation and electronic filing, and for direct credit refund or other payment methods.
For returns in which an earned income credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC) is claimed, the IRS may not issue a refund before the middle of February.

Federal tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on how to make a payment using one of the following options. Direct Pay IRS. Pay your individual tax bill or quarterly assessment tax at no extra charge, directly from your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet. Choose an approved payment system for payments via the Internet or by phone. Electronically debit payments. Schedule payments on your federal tax return using tax preparation software or a tax professional. Electronically pay federal taxes. Best for business. Registration required. Check or postal money transfer. Send payment by mail to the address provided in the notification or instructions. Cash payment. You can pay taxes in cash at a partner store. Same-day electronic bank transfer. We can send a same-day electronic bank transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for availability, cost and timing.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information about your options. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations in the form of partial monthly payments if you are currently unable to pay your taxes in full.
For more information on how to respond to a notice or letter from the IRS, please visit IRS.gov/Notices.

You can use the LEP (Form 1040) “Request for Change of Preferred Language” to state your preference for receiving notices, letters and other correspondence from the IRS in a language other than English.

TAS will help you solve problems that you haven't been able to solve yourself. If you have problems after contacting the IRS, always try to solve them. If you haven't, contact us. Our services are free.
If you are a private entrepreneur or your company is registered as a partnership or an S-corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account.
Go to IRS.gov/SocialMedia for a list of the various social media that the IRS uses to share with you information that is publicly available.
You can refer to the IRS.gov/MyLanguage website if your native language is not English.

You are a self-employed person if you are a sole trader or independent contractor who owns a business or business. A self-employed person does not have to be engaged in a full economic activity. A part-time business that a person carries out in addition to his or her main job or business may also be considered self-employment. Commercial activity or business. Commercial activity or business generally refers to an activity for the purpose of making a profit. In each case, the definition of an economic activity as a commercial activity or business depends on the facts and circumstances. To be considered engaged in a commercial activity or business, you do not have to actually make a profit - the intention to make a profit is sufficient. You do not have to make a continuous effort to promote the interests of your business. Limited Liability Company (LLC). A limited liability company is a legal entity created under the laws of a state by filing a charter of a limited liability company. Generally, for income tax purposes, a single-member limited liability company is not considered an organization separate from its owner and reports income and deductions on the owner's federal tax return. For example, if a single-member limited liability company is not engaged in farming and the owner is an individual, such an individual may use Schedule C. Single-entrepreneur. A sole entrepreneur is a person who owns a company directly, without converting it into a corporation. If you are an individual and sole partner in a U.S. limited liability company, you are also a sole trader for income tax purposes if you do not declare the limited liability company as a corporation. Independent contractor. Generally, independent contractors are:
For regular employees, check box 13 on Form W-2 “Payroll and Tax Report”. Regular employees should use Appendix C for the payroll and expense report.

If you and your spouse own and manage a joint business without converting it into a corporation and share in the profits and losses, regardless of whether there is a formal partnership agreement, you are partners. Do not complete Schedule C. Instead, you must file Form 1065, U.S. Partnership Income Tax Return. For more information, see Publication No. 541, Partnerships. Exception: Joint Income. If you and your spouse fully own a business without converting it into a corporation as joint property under the laws of a state, other country or U.S. joint property holdings, you may report the business as a sole proprietorship or partnership. For a list of states that have joint property laws: Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington, Wisconsin. Change of status for reporting is considered a change in the legal definition of a business. For more information on joint property laws, see Publication No. 555. Exception: Qualifying joint venture. If each spouse who is the sole participant in a joint business is materially involved in the business and the spouses file a joint tax return for the tax year, they may report the business as a qualifying joint venture (QJV) instead of a partnership for that tax year. In that case, they may avoid filing Form 1065. In this case, each spouse will be credited with the social security contributions that form the basis for pension benefits. For the definition of “material participation”, see the instructions for Schedule C (Form 1).

What you need to know. Table A lists the questions you need to answer to meet your federal tax obligations. Follow the link below each question to find the appropriate section of this publication. The Mission of the U.S. Revenue Service (IRS). The IRS mission is to provide high-quality service to American taxpayers by helping them understand and fulfill their tax obligations and by ensuring that the law is complied with in good faith and impartially. Comments and suggestions. We welcome your comments on this publication and suggestions for further improvements. Comments and suggestions can be sent to: IRS.gov/FormComments. Or by mail to: Internal Revenue Service, Tax Forms and Publications, 1111 Constitution Ave. NW, IR-6526, Washington, DC 20224. Unfortunately, we cannot answer everyone in person, but we welcome your feedback and will take it into account when revising tax forms, instructions and publications. Do not send tax questions, returns or payments to the address above. Answers to tax questions. If you haven’t found the answer to your tax question in this publication or in the “How to get tax assistance” section at the end of this publication, go to the Interactive Tax Help page at IRS.gov/Help/ITA, where you can find the answers you need by searching or by browsing the categories listed.

The maximum net income taxable to the Social Security Fund is $168,600 in 2024. The net income taxable to the Medicare Fund is unlimited. Additional depreciation allowance. The additional depreciation allowance under section 168(k) will continue to decrease in 2024 and will be reduced from 80% to 60%.

For more information, see the Form 8886 instructions or the Illegal Tax Havens and Transactions section. Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Support Center (SB/SE). Need help with taxes, filing, or getting a publication or form? The Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Support Center provides assistance to taxpayers filing Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, Schedule C, E, or F, or Form 2106, and small business owners with assets of up to $10 million. For more information, visit the Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Support Center at IRS.gov/Business/Small. The Free Earning Economy Tax Center. The Free Earning Economy (or the Demand Economy, the Collaborative Economy, or the Access Economy) is an economic activity in which individuals earn income from performing work, providing services, or selling goods on demand.

After you have calculated the income and expenses of your business, you can calculate the net profit or net loss of your business. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and becomes part of your income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

The amount of your professional or business losses may be limited by law. Use Form 461 to determine the amount of your excess business losses, if any. Your excess business loss will be included as income on line 8p of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and is considered a net loss that you must carry forward and deduct in the next tax year.
For more information on NOL, see Publication No. 536. It explains how to calculate NOL, when to use it, how to claim a NOL deduction and how to calculate a NOL carry-over.
As a rule, you must pay SE tax and file a Schedule SE (Form 1040) if your net income from individual employment is $400 or more. Use Schedule SE to calculate your net income from self-employment.
If you are self-employed as a sole trader or independent contractor, you usually use Schedule C (Form 1040) to calculate your SE taxable income.
In 2024, the SE net income tax rate is 15.3% (12.4% social security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

Only the first 168,600 U.S. dollars of your total wages, tips and net earnings in 2024 are subject to any combination of 2.9% Medicare tax as part of SE tax, Medicare tax as part of RPF tax, or both, and their total amount is at least 168,600 U.S. dollars, you do not pay 12.4% Social Security tax as part of SE.

An additional 0.9% Medicare fund tax may apply to you if your net self-employment income exceeds a threshold amount (depending on your filing status). For more information, see the "Self-Employed Persons (SE) Tax" section in Chapter 1, as well as Form 8959 and its instructions.

Generally, resident aliens are required to pay self-employment tax under the same rules as U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are not subject to self-employment tax unless an applicable international social security agreement (also known as a comprehensive agreement) determines that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are subject to self-employment tax because they are considered U.S. residents for self-employment tax purposes. For more information about aliens, see Publication No. 519, the U.S. Tax Guide for Alien Residents.

If you are a sole proprietor and have reduced or discontinued your business activities, any payments you receive from insurance or other sources for lost business income are included in the SE taxable income. If you are not working at the time of receiving the payment, it still relates to your activity and is included in the SE taxable income, even if your company is temporarily not working.

If you are a crew member of a vessel that catches fish or other aquatic life, your earnings are subject to SE tax if all of the following conditions are met. 1. You receive no payment for work other than your share of the catch or a share of the proceeds from the sale of the catch, unless the payment meets all of the following conditions. 1. The wages are not more than $100 per trip. 2. The payment is only made if a minimum catch is available. 3. The payment is made exclusively for additional duties (such as assistant, engineer or cook) for which a separate cash payment is traditionally made in the fishing industry. 2. You receive a share of the catch or a share of the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the catch. 4. The crew of the vessel is usually less than 10 people. (A crew is considered to be less than 10 people if the average crew size on trips made over the last 4 calendar quarters is less than 10 people.)
The fee you receive for the services you provide as a notary is shown in Schedule C but is not subject to SE tax (see instructions for Schedule SE (Form 1040)).

You are subject to SE tax if both of the following conditions are met: 1. You are a U.S. citizen who is employed in the U.S., Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands or the U.S. Virgin Islands for: 1. a foreign government, 2. a wholly-owned agency of a foreign government, or 3. an international organization.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries to eliminate double taxation between the two social security systems. Under these agreements, you usually only have to pay taxes to the social security funds and Medicare programs in the country where you live. The country where you have to pay taxes will issue a certificate that serves as proof of exemption from paying social security taxes in the other country. See the instructions for the SE Schedule (Form 1040) to get more information.

You can use the alternative methods (discussed below) when you have a loss or a small net profit and one of the following applies: You want to get a credit against your social security payments. You have incurred child or dependent care expenses for which you could get a credit. (The alternative method may increase your earned income, which may increase your credit.) You are entitled to a tax credit for earned income. (The alternative method may increase your earned income, which may increase your credit.) You are entitled to an additional tax credit for a child. (The alternative method may increase your earned income, which may increase your credit.)

Using an alternative method can increase your SE tax. Paying more SE tax can result in you receiving higher social security payments. Using an alternative method can also reduce your adjusted gross income (AGI) by deducting half of the SE tax on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, which can affect your entitlement to credits, deductions, or other items that are subject to an AGI restriction.

To calculate your net income by the ordinary method, multiply your self-employment income by 92.35% (0.9235). Information on your net earnings calculated by the ordinary method is provided in line 4a of your SE-annex (Form 1040).

Use the non-farm alternative method only for income that is not related to farming. You can use this method if you meet all of the following requirements. 1. You are a sole proprietorship on a continuous basis. This means that your actual net self-employment income was $400 or more for at least 2 of the 3 tax years preceding the one for which you are using this method. For this purpose, the net income for the previous year can be derived from either agricultural or non-agricultural activities, or both. 2. You have used this method for less than 5 years. (There is a 5-year limit on the duration.) The years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your net non-agricultural income was: 1. Less than $7,493, and 2. Less than 72.189% of your gross non-agricultural income.
Your gross non-farm income is usually a sum of: Schedule C, Line 7 (Form 1040); and Schedule K-1, Form 1065, Column 14, Code C (from non-farm partnerships).

You cannot use this method to report an amount less than your actual net income from self-employment in non-farm activities. Your actual net income from non-farm activities is your net income from non-farm activities calculated by the usual method described above.
The following examples demonstrate how to calculate net income if the gross income of a non-farm enterprise is US$10,380 or less.
The following examples show how to calculate net income if the gross income of a non-farm enterprise is more than US$10,380.

You may declare less than the total actual net income of the agricultural and non-agricultural enterprises, but not less than the actual net income of the non-agricultural enterprise. If you use both alternative methods, you may declare no more than $6,920 as total net income from self-employment.

Use Schedule SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report SE tax. If you filed Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter SE tax on line 4 of Schedule 2 and attach Schedule SE to your form. If you filed Form 1040-SS, enter SE tax on line 3 and attach Schedule SE to your form. If you are required to pay SE tax, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR or Form 1040-SS, if applicable (with Schedule SE attached), even if you are not required to file a federal income tax return.

We accept most tax returns as they are filed. If we ask questions about your return or select it for verification, it does not imply that you are dishonest. The inquiry or verification does not necessarily result in an increase in tax debt. We may close your case without amendment or even issue a refund.

If you do not wish to go to the Appeals Division or do not agree with its findings, you can go to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Federal Claims Court, or the U.S. District Court of your place of residence. If you take the case to court, the IRS will have to prove certain facts, especially if you have maintained proper documentation to prove your tax liability, co-operated with the IRS, and met certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that our position was substantially unfounded, you will be able to recover some of the administrative and litigation costs. You will not be eligible for reimbursement of these costs unless you have tried to resolve your case through administrative means, including the appeals system, and provided us with the information necessary to resolve the case.

In general, both you and your spouse are jointly and severally liable for the full amount of tax, interest, or fines due under your joint return. To obtain an exemption from liability involving your spouse (or former spouse), you must file a Form 8857, "Request for Innocent Spouse Exemption from Tax, Interest, and Fines."

You can claim a refund if you believe you paid too much tax. Generally, you must file a refund within 3 years of the date you filed your original tax return or 2 years of the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. Publication No. 556 contains additional information about tax refunds. If you were entitled to a refund but did not file a tax return, you must file a refund within 2 years of the date you paid the tax to receive the refund. The law usually provides for interest on the refund if it is not paid within 45 days of the date you filed your tax return or made your refund application.

Once you have all your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or digitally) or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G); interest, dividend and pension statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have several options for preparing and filing your tax return.

To complete mobile-friendly forms, you must have an IRS tax account. You can file your form(s) online or download and print them to mail. You will need to scan the documents to prove your filing. For more information, visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

Visit IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account information. View amounts due and breakdowns by tax year. View payment agreement details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment, view 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments. Get online access to tax documents, including key information from your latest return and statements. View electronic copies of some IRS notifications. Approve or reject an authorization request from a tax professional. Update your address or choose how you want to receive notifications.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process. You can get a statement, view your last filed tax return and update your adjusted gross income.
This tool allows your tax professional to apply for authorization to access your individual online account with the IRS. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The safest and easiest way to get your tax refund is to file online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account. A direct deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use the direct deposit method to receive their refund. If you do not have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an account online.

The following are options for preparing and filing your return online or at your place of residence if you are eligible. The Direct File program. Direct File is a finally approved software that allows you to file federal individual tax returns online free of charge and securely. Direct File is suitable for taxpayers from partner states who file relatively simple tax returns that include certain types of income and certain credits and deductions. While you cannot file a state return using Direct File if you live in a partner state, the system will redirect you to state-approved tax software for free state return filing. For more information, updates and answers to frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile The Free File Free File System. This program allows you to prepare and file federal individual income tax returns for free using the software or the Free File fillable forms. However, state-level tax preparation may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to find out if you are eligible for free federal tax preparation online, electronic filing, direct deposit or payment options. VITA. The Income Tax Assistance Grant Program (VITA) offers free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income individuals, disabled individuals, and taxpayers with limited English language skills who need assistance preparing their tax return. Visit IRS.gov/VITA to download the free IRS2Go app or call 800-906-9887 for information on free tax return preparation.

For returns claiming an earned income credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC), the IRS may not issue a refund before mid-February. This deadline applies to the entire refund of overpaid taxes, not just the part related to these credits.

IRS Direct: Pay your individual tax bill or quarterly assessment at no additional cost, directly from your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment system for online or phone payments. Electronic Federal Tax Payment: Best for business. Registration required.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information about your options. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to settle your tax liability in monthly payments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today.
Go to IRS.gov/Notices for more information on how to respond to an IRS notice or letter.

You can use the LEP (Form 1040) Request for Change of Preferred Language to state your preference to receive IRS notices, letters and other correspondence in a language other than English. You may not immediately receive correspondence in the language you request. The IRS’s commitment to taxpayers with limited English skills is part of a multi-year process that will begin in 2023.

TAS will help you solve problems that you haven't been able to solve yourself. If you have problems after contacting the IRS, always try to solve them. If you haven't, contact us. Our services are free.
If you are a sole proprietorship or a partnership or S-Corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.

Go to IRS.gov/SocialMedia for a list of the various social media that the IRS uses to share the latest tax changes, fraud warnings, initiatives, products and services. At the IRS, privacy and security are top priorities. We use these tools to share publicly available information with you. Do not post your social security number or other sensitive information on social media. Always protect your privacy when using any social media. The following IRS YouTube channels provide short informative videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish and ASL (American Sign Language).

SBDCs provide advice, training and technical services to current and potential small business owners who cannot afford the services of a private consultant. They can help you start, improve or expand your small business.

SCORE provides advice and training to current and potential small business owners. SCORE consists of current and former entrepreneurs who offer their experience and knowledge to help people to start, run and grow a small business.
You can visit the SBA website at SSA.gov. Visiting the SBA website will allow you to find a variety of information of interest to small business owners.

The IRS issues an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number to foreigners who are residents or temporary residents of the United States and do not have a Social Security Number and are not eligible to receive it. The Individual Taxpayer Identification Number expires every time a taxpayer fails to file a federal tax return (or for each taxpayer who is not declared as a dependent on another taxpayer's tax return) for 3 consecutive years. As a general rule, if you require an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, you must file Form W-7, "Application for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number," with a completed and signed original tax return and any other required documentation, and send all of them to the address listed in the instructions for Form W-7. Exceptions are listed in the instructions. If you need to include another person's social security account number in your tax return, but that person does not have the number and cannot obtain it, enter that person's Individual Taxpayer Identification Number. The application is also available in Spanish. The form is available at IRS.gov/FormW7.

If you are required to have an EIN, please provide it along with your Social Security Number in Appendix C, as instructed. You can apply for an EIN in several ways: Online at the "Employer ID Numbers (EINs)" section at IRS.gov/businesses/small ; if your main place of business is in the U.S. or U.S. territories, you will receive an EIN immediately after processing the information provided in your application; By phone: 267-941-1099 (call fees apply); only if your main place of business is outside the U.S. or U.S. territories; or By mail or fax: Form SS-4 "Application for an Employer Identification Number".

If the legal form of the company or the ownership structure of the company has changed, you may need to obtain a new Employer Identification Number. För mer information se Publication nr 1635 ”Om Employer Identification Number” (storsta).

In the course of your business, you will have to make payments that must be reported in the tax return. The list of such payments is given in the section "Information Declarations" later in this chapter. You must provide the recipient of such payments (the payment recipient) with a statement showing the total amount paid during the year.
If you are making payments to someone who is not your employee and you must report such payments on a disclosure return, you will need to know the social security number of that person.

You can file your income tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attaching Schedule C. Enter the net profit or loss shown in Schedule C in Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate your net profit or loss from business. If you have managed more than one company as a sole trader, you must attach a separate copy of Schedule C for each company.

If you are filing your tax return electronically using a tax return software or a tax return professional, you and your spouse will both need to create your own PIN and enter it as an electronic signature. To create your PIN, you must know your AGI as stated on your original 2023 tax return (do not use the amount stated on your amended tax return, on Form 1040-X or after you have notified the IRS).

You can receive a return check by mail or receive your refund by direct transfer to your current or savings account. Using IRS e-file, your refund will be paid twice as fast as filing a paper tax return. In most cases, your refund will be paid within 21 days of filing.

As with paper returns, if you have a debt on federal taxes, state taxes, a student loan or alimony, you (or, if you file a joint tax return, your spouse) may not receive the full amount of the refund.

The IRS will not pay returns filed for an earned income tax credit or a child tax credit earlier than mid-February 2025, not just for the portion of the refund related to the said tax credits, but for the full amount of the refund.

To file through the IRS e-file program you will only need a computer with Internet access. With a personal computer you can file through e-file from home 24/7, anytime. To successfully file you will need to put on the tax return an electronic signature - your self-chosen PIN. In this case, to confirm the submission of a form, confirming the signature or a Form W-2 is not required.

If you are filing for a fiscal year (see explanation in chapter 2), you must file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month after the end of your fiscal year. Penalties and interest may apply if you fail to file your tax return on time. If you are unable to file your tax return on time, file Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of U.S. Individual Income Tax Return Date, to request an automatic extension of the filing deadline by 6 months. If you file your tax return for a calendar year using this form, you can extend the deadline to October 15. If you file this form to extend the filing deadline, the tax filing deadline is not extended.

If insufficient income tax and self-employment tax was deducted from your salary in 2024, or if you paid insufficient deductible tax, you may be liable to a fine for the amount not paid. In this case, the IRS will calculate the fine and send you an invoice. You can also use Form 2210, "Deductible Tax Deductions by Individuals, Estates and Trusts" to check for a penalty due and calculate the amount of the penalty. For more information, see Publication No. 505.

The self-employed tax is a social security and Medicare tax that is mainly levied on individuals who work for themselves. This tax is similar to the social security and Medicare tax that is withheld from the wages of most employees. If you have earned income as an employee, you are not required to pay self-employed tax for such income. Social security and Medicare taxes are already withheld from such income, but you may have to pay a tax on your income as a self-employed person.

Social security benefits are available to both wage earners and self-employed persons. Self-employed tax is taken into account when determining the amount of social security benefits. Under the social security system, you receive pension benefits, disability benefits, survivorship benefits, and hospital expenses (Medicare). You must provide a statement of all income from self-employment. Otherwise, you will receive less social security benefits when you retire.

For 2024, you received one of the maximum four credits for every $1,730 ($1,810 in 2025) of income taxable to the Social Security Fund. Thus, if you received income (from self-employment and as a wage) of $6,920 taxable to the Social Security Fund in 2024, you will receive four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). You can find out the number of credits required to receive insurance and social security benefits for yourself and your relatives at the nearest Social Security Office. False statements made in order to receive or increase social security payments may result in a fine.

As a rule, the Social Security Office only grants a credit if the self-employment income is reported in a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months and 15 days of the tax year in which the income was received. If you file a tax return or notify changes in the self-employment income after this period has expired, the Social Security Office will only accept a cancellation or reduction of the income. u The Social Security Office will not make any upward changes in your self-employment income.

In 2024, only the first 168,600 U.S. dollars, which is the sum of wages, tips and net profits, is subject to any combination of 12.4% self-employed tax, 2.9% Medicare tax or 1% Medicare tax on railway pension benefits. If the wages and tips you receive as an employee are subject to 12.4% self-employed tax, and your income is at least 168,600 U.S. dollars, you are not required to pay 12.4% self-employed tax on any net profits.

If you have both wages and self-employment income, the amount limit applied to the Medicare Supplemental Income Tax on Self-Employment is reduced (but not reduced to zero) by the amount of wages subject to the Medicare Supplemental Income Tax. Use Form 8959, Supplemental Medicare Tax, to calculate the amount of this tax.

For more information, see Publication No. 15 (Circular E) “Employer Taxation Guide”. This publication lists your tax liabilities as an employer. Do not deduct the amount of the non-refundable and refundable portions of the eligible sick leave and family leave credits received under the Families First Coronavirus Relief Act and the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 and reported on your employer’s tax return. Instead, report these credits as income. To determine whether people working for your company are your employees, see Publication No. 15-A. This publication contains information that will help you determine whether an individual is an independent contractor or an employee. If you incorrectly declare an employee as an independent contractor, you may be liable to pay tax on that employee plus a penalty.

The federal excise duty, which must be reported on Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, includes several categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental Protection Tax on the sale or use of ozone-depleting substances and imported products containing or made using such substances.

The use of certain types of heavy duty vehicles, tractors and buses on public roads is subject to a federal excise tax. This tax applies to vehicles with a gross taxable weight of 55,000 pounds (25,000 kg) or more.

If you make or receive payments in the course of your business, you may be required to file a disclosure return with the IRS. To verify the presence of payments in your disclosure return, the IRS compares the disclosure return with each person's income tax return.

Regardless of the amount of the payment, you must also file a Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you have withheld any federal income tax (report in box 4) under the additional withholding tax rules. If you are completing a Form 1099-NEC for a report on sales of consumer goods totalling $5,000 or more, you must file this form with the IRS by January 31.

The following forms are subject to fines: Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC or Form W-2. There are also fines for providing incorrect information. For more information, see the general instructions for certain disclosure forms.

If you can prove that the violation was committed for reasonable reasons and not due to wilful negligence, you will be exempted from fines. Furthermore, for not including all the required information or for providing incorrect information in a de minimis (insignificant) number of informational declarations when correcting errors before 1 August of the year in which the declarations are required, no fine is imposed.
You must file Form 8300, "Report of Cash Payments Over US$10,000" received by a merchant or company if you received more than US$10,000 in cash payments for one or more merchant transactions.

You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return for the annual reporting period called the tax year. In addition, you must consistently use a reporting method that clearly shows your income and expenses for the tax year.
You must use the same accounting method for calculating your taxable income and keeping accounting records.

You can keep accounts of business and personal income and expenses using different accounting methods. For example, you can calculate your business income on an accrual basis, even if you use the cash method for calculating personal income and expenses.

If you have two or more separate and distinct lines of business, you may use different accounting methods for each if the method clearly reflects the income of each line. They are separate and distinct only if you keep complete and distinct documents and records for each line.

In the cash method, include in your gross income all items of income that you actually or supposedly receive during the tax year. If you receive property or services, you must include their fair market value in income.

You have implied income when the amount is credited to your account or provided to you without restrictions. You do not have to own it. If you have appointed someone as your agent, you are deemed to have received the income when your agent received it.

You cannot keep checks or postpone the acquisition of similar property from one tax year to another to avoid paying income tax. You must report income for the year in which the property was received by you or provided to you without restriction.

If your debts are paid by another person or cancelled by your creditors, you may have to declare part or all of the cancelled debt as income. If you receive income in this way, you are supposedly receiving income when the debt is cancelled or paid. For more information, see the section “Repaid debt” in the section “Types of income” in Chapter 5.
If you include a certain amount in your income and need to refund it in full or in part in the following year, you can generally deduct the amount of the refund in the year you made it.

With the cash method, you usually deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them. These include business expenses for which you dispute responsibility. However, you will not be able to deduct prepaid expenses, and you may need to capitalize certain expenses as described in the "Uniform Capitalization Rules" section below.
You can deduct prepaid expenses only in the year they relate tol.

Under the accrual method, you usually report income in the year in which it is earned and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year in which they are incurred. The purpose of accrual accounting is to compare income and expenses for the year in question.

When using the accrual method, you usually include an amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all the events determining your entitlement to income occurred and you can determine that amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with a proper financial statement or other financial statement prepared in accordance with the regulations of the Ministry of Finance, the “all events” test for a gross income item is deemed to be met no later than when it is recognized in the proper financial statement or other similar financial statement.

If you include a reasonably estimated amount in gross income and later determine that the exact amount is different, take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine the amount.

If you provide services at the base rate specified in the contract, you must accrue income at the base rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate, until you complete the services and then receive the differencel.

Generally, you report the advance payment as income in the year you receive it. However, if you receive an advance payment, you may defer the inclusion of the advance payment in income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the inclusion of any payment until the next tax year. For more information, see sections 538 and 451.

Under the accrual method, you will generally deduct or capitalize the business expense if both of the following conditions apply: 1. The time of events requirement is met. This requirement is met when: 1. All the events that establish the fact of liability have occurred, 2. and the liability can be determined with reasonable accuracy. 2.

If your expenses are related to property or services provided to you or your use of property, the economic result is achieved as you provide the property or services. An exception allows certain recurring items to be treated as incurred during the tax year even if the economic result has not been achieved.

When the production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in your business, you generally have to keep inventory records at the beginning and end of the tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest due to a dependent person who uses the cash method of accounting until you make the payment and the amount is included in the gross income of the dependent person. Determine the degree of relationship for this rule at the end of the tax year in which the expenses or interest would otherwise be deductible. If the deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with the person ceases before the expenses or interest are included in that person's gross income.

If you are a small business owner, you may not include inventory in your assets, but you should still use an accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects income. If your accounting method treats MTS (materials and stocks) as planned materials or stocks or is consistent with your financial accounting for inventory, however, if you choose to include inventory in your assets, you should generally use the accrual method and value the inventory each year to determine the value of goods sold in Part III of Annex C.

You are considered a small business owner if you (a) have an average annual gross income of $30 million or less for the 3 previous tax years and (b) are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business did not exist for the entire three-year tax period used to calculate your average gross income, calculate the average for the period in which it existed, and if your business has a predecessor, include the predecessor's gross income for the 3-year tax period when calculating your average gross income.
If you want to change your MTS accounting policy, you must file Form 3115, Request for Accounting Policy Change. See the section "Changing Accounting Policy" below.

You must assess your MTFs at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the value of the goods sold (Annex C, line 42). To assess your MTFs, you need a method of identifying the items of income and expenditure in your MTFs and a method of measuring those items.

Under the uniform capitalization rules, you must capitalize the direct costs and part of the indirect costs of production or resale. Include these costs in the base of the property that you produce or acquire for resale, rather than reporting them as a current deduction.

You may fall under the uniform capitalization rules if you engage in one of the following activities, except where the property is intended for personal use and not for business or activities carried out for the purpose of making a profit. There are special methods for accounting for certain items of income or expense. These include the following methods. Depreciation of intangible assets, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Bad debts, discussed in Topic No. 453 “Write-off of bad debt”. Depletion, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Depreciation, discussed in Publication No. 946 “How to depreciate property”. Sale on instalment, discussed in Publication No. 537 “Sale on instalment”. Long-term contractual accounting methods. See Section 460.

An equivalent transaction is the exchange of property for another, equivalent property. This is the most common type of non-taxable transaction. In order for the transaction to be equivalent, the property exchanged and received must be (a) real estate and (b) property of the organization or investment property.

If you provide credit to the buyer of your property, instead of the buyer getting a credit or mortgage from a third party, you are selling the property on an installment basis. For more information on installment sales, see Publication No. 537.

Instead, all the assets of the business are sold. In this case, each asset is treated as a separate sale for the purposes of determining profit or loss. The buyer and seller involved in the sale of the business must report to the IRS on the distribution of the sale price among the assets of the business.
The value or the sale price of a property is usually used as the base value when determining the income or loss from the sale or otherwise disposed of the property.

The adjusted base value is generally defined as the original cost of the property plus certain premiums and minus certain deductions, such as depreciation and accidental losses.1 In determining the income or loss, the adjusted base value of the property is increased by the costs incurred in transferring it to a new owner, such as the cost of sale.

The amount of the sale of property is defined as the total amount of money you received plus the fair market value of all the property or services you received. The amount of the sale also includes all your liabilities that the buyer assumes and all liabilities in respect of the property you have transferred, such as property taxes or mortgages.

The fair market value of a property is defined as the price at which it passes from the seller to the buyer, provided that both parties are not under any coercion and are reasonably aware of all the necessary facts.

Your income or loss from the disposal of property is usually recognised as income or loss for tax purposes. The recognised income must be included in gross income. The recognised loss may be deducted from gross income. However, in some cases, the income or loss from certain property exchange transactions is not recognised. See the section “Non-taxable transactions” presented above.
You must classify your income and loss as a profit or loss from the sale of capital assets. This is necessary to determine your net income or loss.
If you have received a profit or loss from the sale of a capital asset, you must determine whether it is a short-term or long-term profit or loss.
If you have received taxable income, you will also need to file Schedule D (Form 1040).
To provide this information, you may also need to file Form 4797 and Appendix D (Form 1040).
To provide this information, you may need to file Form 6252, Income from Sale on Installment. You may also need to file Form 4797 and Schedule D (Form 1040).
To provide this information, you may also need to file Schedule D (Form 1040).
The total tax credits of the company for the current year consist of the tax credits carried over from previous years and the amount of the tax credits for the current year.

All the tax credits below are part of the company's overall tax credits. The form you use to calculate each credit is in parentheses. You will also need to complete Form 3800. Some tax credits have a validity period.

This credit applies to the initial cost of a new qualifying defined benefit or defined contribution (including 401(k)) pension plan, SIMPLE plan or SEP plan. For more information, see Publication No. 560, Small Business Pension Plans.
This credit is for qualifying investments in the equity of qualifying local development enterprises. For more information, see Form 8874.
To get a general company tax credit, you must get the forms needed to claim the company's credits for the current year.

This chapter explains what business income is, how to account for it for tax purposes, and what income is not considered income. This also provides guidance for people who are engaged in certain activities. If there is a link between your business and the income you receive, then that income is considered to be business. The link exists if it is obvious that there would be no income if you did not own the business. You can have business income even if you do not take a regular part in the activities of your business. u Income from a side job in addition to your main job can be business income. u For example, you can provide services to a company that provides a ride-sharing service as a second job. u Most income from individual business activities, such as income from the sale of goods or services, must be reported in ru ru but income from the sale of company assets, such as land and office buildings, must be reported in other forms. ru For more information about selling company assets, see ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru

Income from business activities includes the amounts you received in the course of your individual business activities and that you reported on Forms 1099-NEC. This includes the amounts reported in box 1 of the said form as payments under a civil contract.

Name, Image, Likeness (NIL) is a term used to describe the means by which student athletes are allowed to receive financial rewards. NIL can be classified as self-employment income. If your NIL income exceeds $600 from any source, including non-cash income, you will receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC, containing the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you are a sole proprietor, you may obtain a Form 1099-K that shows the total amount in dollars of all reportable payment transactions. This may not be the amount you should report as income, as it may not include all income, but may include items that are not included in your income (for example, sales tax).

The income you declared on Schedule C may be qualified individual business income and entitle you to a deduction on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (line 13). See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to determine the amount of the deduction.

In most cases, individual business income is received in the form of cash, checks and credit card payments. However, individual business income may also come in other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen who receives individual business income from sources outside the United States (abroad income), you must report that income on your tax return unless it is exempt from tax under U.S. law. If you are resident outside the United States, you are entitled to deduct all or part of the foreign individual business income from your tax base. For more information, see Publication 54, Tax Guidelines for U.S. Citizens and Foreign Residents Living Abroad.

If you are a real estate agent who receives income from renting out property, or a hotel, motel, etc. owner who provides certain services to guests (maid services, etc.), you must report your rental income and expenses in Schedule C. If you are not a real estate agent or such an entrepreneur as described in the previous sentence, report your rental income and expenses in Schedule E. For more information, see Publication No. 527 “Residential Property for Rent”.

You are a real estate agent if you sell real estate to clients with the aim of making a profit from these sales. The rent for real estate that you hold for sale to clients is subject to SE tax. However, the rent for real estate that you hold for speculative purposes or as an investment is not subject to SE tax.

Rent income from a trailer park is subject to SE taxation if you are a self-employed trailer park owner who rents out premises and parking spaces and provides essential services for the convenience of tenants.

Rent income from the use or occupation of hotels, guesthouses or apartment buildings is subject to SE tax if you provide services to tenants. Generally, you are considered to provide services to tenants if these services are primarily for their convenience and are not services that are usually provided for renting rooms for living only.
The bonus you receive from the tenant for providing the rental is an addition to the rent. Include it in the gross revenue in the year of receipt.
If your tenant makes payments to someone else under an agreement to pay your debts or liabilities, include those payments in gross income when the tenant makes payments.

If you rent out personal property (equipment, vehicles, official clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross income in Schedule C. Prepaid rent and other payments described in the “Real Estate Rental” section above may also be received for renting out personal property.

If a loan due becomes uncollectible during the tax year and you are using the accrual method, you should generally include in gross income the specified unconditionally payable interest accrued prior to the time the loan became uncollectible. If accrued interest previously included in income is subsequently uncollectible, you may be eligible for a deduction for uncollectible debts. See the section "Uncollectible Debts" in Chapter 8.

For most sole proprietors and legal employees, however, dividends are not business income. If you receive dividends on business insurance premiums that you have deducted from the tax base in one of the previous years, you must declare all or part of those dividends on your tax return as business income.

If your debt is cancelled or forgiven, unless it is a gift or inheritance, you must generally include the amount written off in your gross income for tax purposes. If the debt is related to business, the amount written off is shown on line 6 of Schedule C. If the debt is not related to business, the amount written off is shown on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
If you owe a seller for a property you bought, and the seller reduces your debt, you can generally not count the savings from the debt reduction as your income.
You have not realized the income from the cancelled debt if the amount of the payment of this debt could have been deducted from the taxable base.

If the cancelled debt is excluded from income because the cancellation takes place during bankruptcy proceedings, the exclusions in situations 2-5 do not apply. If the cancellation of the debt takes place against the background of your insolvency, the exclusions in situations 3 and 4 do not apply to the extent appropriate to the insolvency.
In the context of this material, debt includes any of your personal debts and debts related to your property.

You can exclude the write-off of a qualified debt of a real estate company from your income (up to a certain limit). In this case, you must reduce the taxable base of your amortising property by the amount excluded from your income. This reduction must be made at the beginning of the tax year following the tax year in which the write-off occurred. However, if you sell the property before that point, you must reduce the taxable base immediately before the sale.

If you are a non-corporate entity (e.g., a single-member LLC), see the Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness section in Chapter 1 of Publication No. 4681 to see if you qualify for this exclusion. You may not exclude from income an amount that exceeds either of the following items: 1. the outstanding principal of the real estate company’s qualifying debt (immediately prior to cancellation); 2. the fair market value (immediately prior to cancellation) of the company’s real property that is collateralized by the debt, less the outstanding principal of any other qualifying debt of the company secured by that property, immediately prior to cancellation.

If you have received a package of securities or any other property with restrictions on its value, the fair market value of such property that exceeds the value of your services is included in the income shown in Schedule C after the restriction is removed. However, you may pay tax in the year in which you received the property.
This rule does not apply to depreciation, which is accrued as explained below.
The depreciation deduction must be returned to the state in the following situations. This means that you must include in your income all amounts of deductions for previous years.

If the extent of the use of the registered property (as described in the “Depreciation” section of Chapter 8) for business purposes has decreased to 50% or less in the tax year following the tax year in which you put the property into operation, you may have to return part of the depreciation deduction. In this case, you include part of the depreciation deduction for previous years in the income to be reported in Schedule C. To calculate the amount to be reported in Schedule C, use Part IV of Form 4797, “Sale of Company Property” to determine the amount to be included in Schedule C. For more information, see the section “What is the “Business Use Criterion”?” in Chapter 5 of Publication No. 946.

If you deduct the value of an asset under Section 179 (described in the “Depreciation” section of Chapter 8) and the extent of its use for business purposes falls to 50% or less before the end of the refund period, you will be required to refund the portion of the deduction under Section 179.

If you have sold or exchanged depreciable property with profit, you must declare all or part of the depreciation gain as ordinary income. How to calculate the depreciation return is described in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Publication No. 544.

You may make a deduction from your income for actual damages from your business activity. The deduction is equal to the lesser of the following amounts. The amount received or accrued by you in compensation for damages in the tax year under consideration less the amount paid or incurred by you in the same tax year for the purpose of compensation for the said damages.

Any rebate you receive is declared as part of income in Annex C. However, rebate should not be included in income if you lawfully report it as a decrease in the relevant expense item, as capital expenditure or as the value of goods soldu.

If you have received a refund of bad debt or any other amount you have already deducted from the tax base in a previous year, you must include the amount of the refund in income on Schedule C. However, if the total or partial amount of the deduction in previous years has not reduced your tax liability, you are entitled to exclude from your income the part that has not affected your tax liability. If you have deducted from your income part of the refund, you must attach a calculation to your tax return, which shows how the deduction was calculated.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income.
The increase in the value of your property is not declared as income until you realize it by selling it or dispose of it in another taxable manner.

If a tenant builds new buildings or provides your property with amenities, the improvement in the value of the property due to the amenities is not your income. However, if the facts indicate that the amenities are deducted from the rent you receive, then the improvement in the value of the property is declared as income.

The transfer of the goods to another person for sale on your behalf is not a sale. The ownership of the goods remains with the consignee, i.e. with you, even after the consignee takes possession of the goods. Thus, if the goods are shipped for sale on a consignment basis, you cannot report any profit or loss until the consignee sells the goods.
Some tax-exempt Medicaid care payments listed on Form 1099-MISC or Form 1099-NEC may not be taxable. For more information on reporting these payments, see the instructions for Appendix C (Form 1040).

A short-term lease is a contract (or other occupancy or use agreement) for a period of 15 years or less. In determining whether a lease is for a period of 15 years or less, consider whether it provides for the possibility of renewal at a fair market rate as determined at the time of renewal. Two or more leases in a single transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or substantially similar commercial space are considered as one contract.

Commercial space is real estate rented, occupied or otherwise used by you as a tenant in your business activities for the sale of tangible personal property or services provided to an unlimited number of persons.
Qualified long-term use property is non-residential property that is part of your commercial space and is returned to the landlord upon the expiration of the lease.

As a rule, if you exchange business or investment property exclusively for other business or investment property of a similar type, the result of the transaction is not recognized as a source of income or a source of loss.
This section provides information to determine whether you should report your income on Schedule C (Form 1040).

You must report this income whether or not it is reported to you in the disclosure statement. You are engaged in direct selling if you meet all of the following requirements: 1. You engage in one of the following professional or business activities. 2. You provide or distribute newspapers or store advertisements (including any services directly related to the profession or business) 3.

If you are an options or commodity dealer, your profits and losses from dealership or trading in contracts under section 1256 (regulated futures contracts, foreign exchange contracts, dealership options on stocks, options on other financial instruments and dealership futures contracts on securities) or any other property related to those contracts (e.g., an equity contract to hedge options) are reported in Schedule C. For more information, see sections 1256 and 1402(i).

You are a securities or commodities trader if you engage in transactions to buy and sell securities or commodities on your own account. As a securities or commodities trader (including if you have elected to revalue to fair market value under section 475(f) as a securities or commodities trader), the profits and losses from your transactions are not reported in Schedule C. For more information on securities or commodities traders, see Publication No. 550, Investment Income and Expenses and Topic No. 429, Exchange Brokers.
If the remuneration does not meet the above requirements, you must state it in line 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

If you are a crew member of a fishing vessel that is engaged in fishing for fish or other aquatic organisms, your income should be reported in Appendix C if you meet all the requirements of the section "Crew Member of a fishing vessel".

Termination payments for services provided by you as a freelance insurance agent are not included in Schedule C if all of the following conditions apply to you: you were paid after the expiration of your service agreement with the company; you did not provide any services to the company after the termination of the agreement and until the end of the year in which you were paid; you undertook to not compete with the company for at least 1 year from the date of termination of your service agreement; ii the total amount of payments was based primarily on the insurance policies you sold or credited to your account during the last year of your service agreement; ii the extent to which these policies remained valid for any period of time after the termination of your service agreement, or both; ii the amount of payments was in no way dependent on service or on the total earnings for services provided to the company (whether or not your entitlement to payments was determined by the duration of your service; ii ii the amount of payments was determined by the number of years you worked for the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company). ii

Income paid by an insurance company to a retired freelance insurance agent as a percentage of the commissions he received before retirement is reported in Annex C. Renewal commissions and deferred commissions on sales of policies before retirement are also usually reported in Annex C. However, renewal commissions paid to the surviving spouse of an insurance agent are not reported in Annex C.
This rule applies regardless of whether you are guaranteed a minimum earnings, and whether you have received credit for unsold newspapers or magazines that you returned to the supplier.
The fee you receive for your services as a notary public is listed in Annex C. These earnings are not subject to self-employed tax (see the instructions for Annex SE (Form 1040)).

Public officials do not normally declare their official earnings in Schedule C. This rule applies to payments from public funds due to an elected tax collector, which is a fixed percentage of the amount of taxes collected by them. Public office is defined as any elected or non-elected office in the government of the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, a state or a political subdivision thereof, or a government body under the full authority of any of the above-mentioned administrative units. State or local public officials shall declare their fees received from the public in Schedule C if they receive payments exclusively on a fee basis and if their earnings may be subject to, but are not subject to, social security tax, in accordance with an agreement between the federal government and the state authorities.

Accounting for income for tax purposes is sometimes different from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the most common differences that may affect your business transactions. Calculate your business income for the tax year based on your accounting method (see chapter 2).
You must pay tax on all your earned income. You cannot avoid tax by posting your income to a third party.

If the purchaser of your property places all or part of the purchase price in an escrow account, no part of that amount can be recognized in gross sales until you receive it as actual or anticipated income, but upon the expiry of the contract and the escrow account agreement, the amount deposited in the account will become taxable income, even if you do not acquire possession of the funds until the following year.

If you donate inventory (property that you sell in the course of your business), the amount you can deduct as a gift is equal to the lesser of the two: the fair market value on the day of the gift or the value of the gift.

There are two methods of accounting for immediate payment discounts. You can either credit them to a separate discount account or deduct them from the total amount of purchases for the year. Whichever method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change your method of calculating the value of your inventory, you must file Form 3115.

If you are taking out goods for personal or family use, you must exclude this value from the total amount of goods you have purchased for sale. To do this, you must credit the purchase or sale account with the value of the goods you have taken out for personal use. You must also credit this amount to your current account. The current account is a separate account that you must keep to account for the business income that you withdraw to pay for personal and family expenses. As mentioned above, you also use it to account for the withdrawals of goods for personal or family use. This account is also known as a cash withdrawal account or a personal account.

Labour costs are usually a component of the cost of goods sold only in manufacturing or mining businesses. Small merchants (wholesalers, retailers, etc.) usually do not have labour costs that can be attributed to the cost of goods sold. In manufacturing businesses, labour costs appropriately attributed to the cost of goods sold include both direct and indirect costs used in transforming raw materials into a finished, marketable product.i

Direct labour costs are the wages you pay to employees who work all their time directly on the product you produce. These costs also include the portion of the wages you pay to employees who work directly on the product part-time, if you can identify that portion of their wages.

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform plant-wide functions that are not directly or indirectly related to the production of a commodity but are a necessary part of the production process.

Other labour costs that are not part of the cost of goods sold may be deducted as commercial or administrative costs. In general, the only types of labour costs that may be attributed to the cost of goods sold are direct or indirect labour costs and some other costs considered as overheads attributed to the production process, as discussed further on Line 39, “Other costs”.

Materials and supplies, such as equipment and chemicals, used in the production of goods are recognized in the cost of the goods sold. Those of them that are not used in the production process are treated as deferred expenses. You deduct them as business expenses when you use them.

Overhead costs include rent, heating, light, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor and supervision. Overhead costs that you consider to be direct and necessary production costs are included in the cost of the goods sold l and l

You do not need to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of goods is not a factor generating income for your business. Your gross profit equals net revenue (gross revenue minus returns, discounts or other discounts).

At the end of each business day, make sure that your records match the actual cash and credit receipts for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to record receipts. You should also use a proper billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

If you charge a buyer a state sales tax or a local sales tax charged to you as a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount received in gross revenue. If you are required to collect state taxes and local taxes charged to buyers and remit them to the appropriate local or state agencies, you generally do not include these amounts in income.

If you are a retailer or wholesaler, you can check the accuracy of your gross profit. First divide your gross profit by your net revenue. The percentage you get measures the average difference between the cost of the goods sold and the price you pay. Then compare this percentage with your margin policy. A small difference between the two percentages or no difference at all indicates that your gross profit is accurate. A large difference between the percentages may indicate that you have miscalculated sales, purchases, inventory or other costs. You must determine the cause of the difference.

You are a retailer. On average, you set your selling price to generate a gross profit of 331/3% on sales. The net revenue (gross revenue minus returns and discounts) reported in your income statement is $300,000. The cost of the goods sold is $200,000. As a result, your gross profit is $100,000 (300,000 – 200,000). To check the accuracy of this year’s results, you divide your gross profit ($100,000) by your net revenue ($300,000). The resulting value of 331/3% confirms your margin of 331/3%.

If your company has income from a source other than the ordinary business activity, enter this income in line 6 of Annex C and add it to the gross profit. This results in the gross business activity income. As an example, you can mention income from an interest account, income from the sale of scrap metal, income from certain tax credits and refunds for fuel tax, as well as amounts reimbursed for bad debts.
These expenses are called business expenses. They are expenses that are not required to be capitalized or included in the cost of goods sold, but can be deducted in the current year.

SEP, SIMPLE and Qualified Plans are tax-friendly ways to save for retirement. You can deduct the contributions you make for your employees on Schedule C, Line 19. If you are a sole proprietor, you can deduct the contributions you make for yourself on Schedule 1, Line 16 (Form 1040). You can also deduct commission trustees if your contributions to the plan do not cover them. Earnings from contributions are usually not taxable until you or your employees receive payments from the plan. You may also qualify for a tax credit if you start a new Qualified Determined Benefit or Determined Contribution Plan (including a 401(k) plan), SIMPLE plan or SEP plan. For more information on this credit and credits for automatic enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and separate instructions.
