Under some plans, employees may ask you to contribute limited amounts from their wages before taxation. These amounts (and income from them) are usually not taxable until your employees receive payments from the plan. For more information on Small Business Pension Plans, see Publication No. 560.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of property that you do not own. In general, you can deduct rent as a business expense only if the rent is charged for property that you use in your business. u If you have or will acquire a share in the property or ownership of the property, you will not be able to deduct the rent u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u

You cannot get a rent deduction for unreasonable rent. Usually, the question of reasonableness only arises if you and the tenant are relatives. A rent paid to a relative is reasonable if it is equal to the amount you would pay to a non-relative for the use of the same property.

You can deduct state tax on Schedule C on gross income (as opposed to net income) directly related to your business. You can deduct other local income taxes as well as state income tax on Schedule A (Form 1040) if you declare item-by-item deductions. Federal income tax is not deducted.
You can deduct half the self-employment tax on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). The self-employment tax is explained in Chapter 1 and Chapter 10 of the Income Tax Act.
You may deduct on Schedule C any tax imposed by local or state authorities on personal property used in business. You may also deduct registration fees for use of property in the state or local area.

You can deduct on Schedule C the real estate taxes you pay on your business property. Deductible real estate taxes are any local or foreign taxes, as well as state taxes, on real estate levied for the public welfare. The tax authority must levy these taxes equally at the same rate on all real estate under its jurisdiction, and the proceeds must be used for the general purposes of the state or district.

If the service, cost, or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you may deduct the tax as part of that service or expense. If the property is a depreciable good, add the sales tax to the base for accruing depreciation. For information on the property base, see Publication No. 551.

In general, your tax home is your usual place of work, regardless of where your family home is located. It includes the entire city or district in which your company is located. For more information, see Publication No. 463. Below is a brief description of the expenses that you can deduct.

You can deduct the costs of operating and maintaining the car during business trips. You can deduct actual costs or the standard mileage rate (discussed earlier in the section “Expenses for cars and trucks”) as well as travel and parking costs.
You can deduct the costs of dry cleaning and laundry during your business trip.
You can deduct tips you have left on any expenses from this list.
To be eligible for a business use of the home, you must meet the following requirements. 1. The business use of the home must be: 1.

To qualify for exclusive use, you must use a certain area of the home exclusively for commercial or business purposes. The area used for business activities can be a room or other separately identifiable space. This space does not have to be separated by a permanent partition. You do not qualify for exclusive use if you use the space for both business and personal purposes.

To meet the criterion of regularity, you must use a certain area of your home for business activities on a permanent basis. You do not meet this criterion if the use of the area for business activities is only occasional or occasional, even if you do not use the area for any other purposesu.
The second paragraph (2) above does not include the self-employment half-tax deduction. Use Form 8829, “Expenses on the Use of a Home in Business Activities,” to calculate your deduction.

The IRS provides a simplified method for determining your home use for business. The simplified method is an alternative to calculating and justifying actual expenses. In most cases, you calculate your deduction by multiplying $5 by the area of the home used for business. The area you use to calculate the deduction is limited to 300 square feet. For more information, see the instructions for Appendix C.

As a rule, you must capitalize the cost of acquiring or producing real or tangible personal property used in your professional or commercial activity, such as buildings, equipment or furniture. However, if you choose to avail yourself of the de minimis benefit for tangible property, you may deduct the de minimis amounts paid for tangible property up to a maximum of $5,000 per item or invoice.
For detailed information on the choice and requirements for using the safe harbor rule for tangible assets, see the section “Regulations governing tangible assets”.

You may be eligible for the following expenses: Advertising. Banking fees. Donations to commercial organizations. Educational expenses. Disability expenses. Interview costs allowances. Licensing and regulatory fees. Moving equipment. Employment assistance services. Penalties and fines for late performance or non-performance of a contract. Repairs and maintenance of real or tangible personal property. Income recovery. Supplies and materials.11 Utilities.12

Generally, you cannot deduct the following expenses as business expenses. Bribes and charges. Charity contributions. Demolition or damages expenses. Contributions to business, social, sports, dining, sports, airline and hotel clubs. Entertainment expenses. Improvements to real or tangible personal property. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements, restorations or work that adapt your property to a new or different use. Lobbying expenses. Penalties and fines that you pay to a public agency or authority because you broke the law. Personal, domestic and family expenses. Political contributions. Settlements or payments related to sexual harassment or sexual assault if such settlements or payments are subject to a non-disclosure agreement. You cannot also deduct attorneys' fees associated with such settlements or payments.

If someone owes you money that you cannot collect, you have bad debt. There are two types of bad debt – business and non-business. Business-related bad debt usually arises as a result of professional or commercial activities. You can deduct bad debt as an expense on your tax return.

Debt is considered closely related to your business if the primary motive for its creation was business activity. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are recorded in your books as receivables or bills of exchange. If you are unable to collect any part of these receivables, the uncollectable part is a bad debt. You can deduct bad debts on these accounts and bills of exchange only if the amount of the debt was included in your gross income, either for the year in which the deduction is made or for the previous year.

If you have declared a deduction for bad debt on your tax return and later recover (collect) the debt in whole or in part, you may have to include all or part of the amount received in your gross income. You must include in your income exactly as much as you actually deducted. However, you can exclude from your income the amount deducted that did not reduce your tax. Report the amount received as "Other Income" on the appropriate tax form or schedule. For more information, see the "Recoveries" section of Publication No. 525.

If a bad debt deduction increases a carried-forward NOL that is not expired before the beginning of the tax year in which the debt is collected, the deduction is classified as a reduction in your tax. A bad debt deduction that affects a NOL contributes to a tax reduction in the year you carry forward the NOL. For more information on NOL for individuals, see Publication No. 536. See also the Form 1045 instructions and the Form 1139 instructions.

If you use the accrual method of accounting, you usually report income when you earn it. You can get a bad debt deduction for uncollectible receivables if you have included the uncollectible amount in income.

If you are using cash accounting, you usually report income when you receive payment. You cannot deduct bad debt in respect of amounts owed to you that you have not received and cannot receive if you have never included those amounts in income.

If you have sold your company and left behind receivables, these are business receivables because they arose as a result of your professional or commercial activities. If part of the receivables becomes useless, it can be classified as business bad debt.

Losses from company debts received in inheritance are classified in the same way as debt received when buying a company. The testator classifies any loss from debt as a business bad debt if the debt was closely related to the professional or commercial activity of the deceased when it became useless.

If you have lent money to a customer, supplier, employee or distributor for commercial purposes and have failed to pay back the debt after several attempts to do so, you are considered to have bad debt.

If a political party (or other organization that accepts contributions or spends money to influence the outcome of elections) owes you money and the debt has become useless, you can claim a deduction for bad debt only if all of the following requirements are met: 1. You are using the accrual method. 2. The debt arose from the sale of goods or services in the ordinary course of professional or commercial activity. 3. More than 30% of your receivables accrued in the year of sale arose from transactions with political parties. 4. You have made substantial and consistent efforts to recover the debt.
You cannot claim a deduction for bad debt on a loan made to a corporation if, based on the facts and circumstances, the loan is in fact a contribution to the capital.22

If your partnership breaks up and one of your former partners becomes insolvent, you may have to pay more than your proportionate share of the partnership’s debts. If this does happen, you can claim a bad debt deduction for the amount paid against the insolvent partner’s share.

If you guarantee the payment of a debt that has subsequently become useless, the debt can be considered a bad debt of a company if all of the following conditions are met: You provided the guarantee in the course of your professional or commercial activity. You are legally obliged to pay the debt. You provided the guarantee before the debt became useless. You meet this requirement if you reasonably expected the borrower to reimburse you for your expenses in repaying the debt. You received something substantial in return for providing the guarantee. You meet this requirement if you provided the guarantee in accordance with normal business practice or for a valid business purpose.

When you pay off a loan you have secured, you may acquire the rights of a lender, and therefore the right to recover the debt. If you have such or similar rights to recover debt from a borrower, you may not claim a deduction for bad debt until these rights become partially or completely useless.
If two or more debtors jointly owe you money, your inability to recover money from one of them does not allow you to deduct the proportional amount of that debtor's debt as bad debt.
If the mortgaged or pledged property is sold at a price lower than the amount of the debt, the unpaid and uncollectible balance of the debt is bad debt.

Debt becomes useless when there is no chance of paying it. This can happen on the day the debt is due or before that date. To demonstrate the uselessness of the debt, you just need to show that you have taken reasonable steps to collect the debt, but without any result.

If you receive property as a partial payment of debt, reduce the debt by the fair market value of the property, which becomes its original value. You may deduct the remaining debt as bad debt if and when it becomes useless. If you subsequently sell the property for more than its original value, any gain from the sale is considered an increase in the value of the property and is not classified as a recovery of a previously bad debt. For information on selling an asset, see Publication No. 544.

If you use the specific write-off method, you can deduct certain business bad debt that has become partly or completely useless during the tax year. However, for partly useless bad debt, your deduction is limited to the amount that you have written off in your books during the year.

You can deduct certain bad debt that becomes partially uncollectible during the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you write off in your books during the year. You do not have to write off and deduct partially uncollectible debt annually. You can defer the write-off to a later year. However, you cannot deduct any part of the debt after the year in which it becomes completely uncollectible.

If the debt becomes completely useless in the current tax year, you can deduct the entire amount except for any amount deducted in the previous tax year when the debt was only partially useless. You do not have to actually write off the debt in order to include the bad debt deduction for the totally useless debt, but you should do so. If you do not do so, and the IRS then decides that the debt is only partially useless, you will not be able to deduct the debt for the tax year in question, because the deduction of the partially useless bad debt is limited to the amount actually written off. See the subsection "Partially Useless Debt" above.

If you use your car or truck in business, you can deduct the costs of operating and maintaining the car. You can also deduct other expenses for local transportation and overnight trips from home for businessu.

Local business travel does not include expenses you incur during overnight trips from home. These expenses are deductible as business travel expenses and are explained in the section "Travel and meals". However, if you use your car during overnight trips from home, use the rules in this section to calculate the deduction for car expenses. u In general, your tax home is your permanent place of work, no matter where your family home is located. u It includes the entire city or district u where you work or do business.

You can use the standard mileage rate to calculate your deductible expenses for operating your car, van, pickup or van for business purposes. For 2024, the standard rate for each mile travelled for commercial purposes is 67 cents.

You cannot use the standard mileage rate if you: 1. Operate five or more vehicles at the same time; 2. Have a depreciation deduction using any method other than linear, such as ACRS or MACRS; 3. Have a depreciation deduction for a vehicle under section 179; 4. Have a specifically authorized depreciation deduction for a vehicle; 5. Have an actual cost of a vehicle that you have leased; or 6. Are a rural postal carrier who has received a qualifying rebate.

Generally, you can deduct the amount you reimburse your employees for car and truck expenses. The amount you deduct and how you do it depends on whether you reimburse under a reportable or non-reportable plan. For more information, see Publication No. 15. This publication explains reportable and non-reportable plans, and whether to report reimbursements on Form W-2.

If you acquire property for business use that will be used for more than one year, you cannot generally deduct the entire cost as business expenses in the year of its acquisition. You must spread the expenses over more than 1 tax year and deduct part of it each year under Schedule C. This method of deducting the value of business property is called depreciation. u Below is a brief overview. u For more information about depreciation, see u Publication No. 946.

You can depreciate property if it meets all of the following requirements. It must be property that you own. It must be used in business or for income generation. You will never be able to depreciate inventory (see chapter 2) because it is not intended for use in your business. It must have a useful life significantly longer than the year in which it was put into service. It must have a definite useful life, which means that it must be something that wears out, degrades, is used, becomes obsolete or loses its value for natural reasons. You will never be able to depreciate the value of land, because land does not wear out, become obsolete or be wasted. It must not be an excluded property. This includes property that is put into service and is taken out of use in the same year.

Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvements are amounts paid for improving your property, restoring your property, or doing work that adapts your property for a new or different use.

You can elect to deduct a limited amount of the value of certain depreciable property in the year you put it into service. This deduction is called a section 179 deduction. The maximum amount you can elect to deduct in 2024 is usually $1,220,000 (higher limits apply to certain property). This limit is usually reduced by the amount by which the value of the property put into service during the tax year exceeds $3,050,000. The total amount of depreciation (including the section 179 deduction) that you can accrue on a passenger car used by you in your business and first put into service in 2024 is $12,400 ($20,400 if you avail the special depreciation allowance for qualifying passenger cars put into service in 2024).
Use Form 4562, Depreciation and Amortization, if you are reporting any of the following: Depreciation of property put into service in the current tax year. Deduction under Section 179.

Some of the types of pay for your employees are listed below. Bonuses. Educational expenses. Non-cash payments (explained below). Loans or advances that you believe the employee will not repay you if they are for personal services actually rendered. Property that you give to the employee as payment for services.

Generally, you can deduct the cost of the in-kind benefits you provide in your Schedule C in the category to which the expense belongs. For example, if you allow an employee to use a car or other property that you lease, deduct the rental cost as a rental or lease expense. If you own property, include a cost deduction or other basis such as a section 179 deduction or depreciation deduction.

You may deduct insurance premiums paid for the following types of insurance related to your business. 1. Fire, theft, flood or similar insurance. 2. Credit insurance covering losses from bad debt. 3. Group hospitalization and employee health insurance, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Negligence insurance covering your personal liability for professional negligence resulting in injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. Employee compensation insurance, established by state law, which covers any claims for work-related injury or illness incurred by employees of your company, regardless of fault. 7. Contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are deductible as taxes if they are considered taxes under state law. 8. Overhead insurance, which pays overheads of your business during extended periods of disability caused by your injury or illness. 9. Automobile and other vehicle insurance, which covers liability, damage and other losses related to vehicles used in your business. If you use a car partially for personal purposes, deduct only that part of the insurance premium that relates to the use of the car in your business. If you use the standard mileage rate to calculate your car expenses, you cannot deduct insurance premiums. 10. Life insurance of your employees, if you are not a direct or indirect beneficiary of the contract. 11. Business interruption insurance, which compensates for lost profits.

You cannot deduct insurance premiums under the following types of insurance. 1. Self-insurance reserve funds. You cannot deduct amounts credited to a reserve set up for self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain insurance coverage for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deducted. For more information, see Publication No. 547. 2. Loss of earnings. You cannot deduct insurance premiums under a policy that pays for your lost earnings due to illness or disability. However, see item 8 in the previous list. 3. Certain types of life insurance and annuities. 1. Under contracts entered into before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct insurance premiums under a life insurance policy under which you, an employee or any person having a financial interest in your business is insured if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary of the policy. You are included as a possible beneficiary of the policy if the policyholder is required to repay a loan received from you from the funds of the policy. A person has a financial interest in your business if they are the owner or co-owner of the business or have lent money to the business. 2. Under contracts entered into after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct premiums under any life insurance policy, accumulation agreement or annuity agreement if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary. This prohibition applies regardless of who is covered by the policy. 4. Insurance to secure credit. If you take out insurance for your life or the life of another person having a financial interest in your business to obtain or protect credit, you cannot deduct insurance premiums as expenses of conducting business. You cannot deduct insurance premiums under a policy that pays for your lost earnings due to illness or disability.
You can deduct the amount you paid for medical and dental insurance and qualified long-term care insurance for you and your family.

You cannot deduct expenses of future periods even if you paid them in advance. This rule applies to any expenses paid in advance enough to create an asset with a useful life significantly beyond the end of the current tax year.

Some taxpayers are required to limit their deduction for interest payments. See the instructions for Form 8990 to find out if you are required to limit the deduction for interest payments on a loan, who is required to file Form 8990, and how some companies can waive the limit for interest payments on a loan.

Below are additional points to consider. How to allocate interest between personal and business use. Limit on interest for business. When to deduct interest. Rules for a loan with an interest rate below the market rate. (This is usually a loan on which interest is not accrued or is accrued at a rate below the current federal rate.)

Legal and professional fees, such as accountants' fees, which are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the conduct of the business, are deductible on Schedule C. However, you cannot usually deduct legal fees that you pay for the acquisition of business assets.

For tax purposes, a foreigner is a person who is not a U.S. citizen. Aliens can be classified as temporary residents (non-resident aliens) and permanent residents (resident aliens). This publication will help you determine your status and give you the information you need to file a U.S. tax return. Resident aliens are generally taxed on their total income worldwide, just like U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed only on income from sources in the United States and on certain income related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

Partial suspension of the Income Tax Convention with the USSR in respect of Belarus. On December 17, 2024, the United States officially notified the Republic of Belarus of the partial suspension of the double taxation treaty with the USSR in respect of Belarus. The United States suspended Article 3(1)(g) of the Convention. The remaining articles of the treaty will remain in force. The suspension came into effect on December 17, 2024 and will expire on December 31, 2026, or earlier if the governments of both countries so decide. Partial suspension of the Income Tax Convention with Russia. On June 17, 2024, the United States officially notified the Russian Federation of the partial suspension of the agreement between the two countries. The United States suspended Article 1(4), Articles 5-21 and Article 23 of the Convention and the Protocol. The suspension came into effect on August 16, 2024, both for taxes originally withheld and for other taxes, and will remain in effect until the two governments agree to terminate it. Payments of income from sources in the United States made on or after August 16, 2024 must be taxed at the statutory rate of 30%. Taxpayers previously entitled to preferential taxation under the Russian-U.S. Income Tax Treaty. Spouse designated as a resident (permanent resident) of the United States. A check mark has been added to the Tax Status section of Forms 1040 and 1040-SR,

Non-Treaty Income is gross income that is taxed at a tax treaty rate not exceeding 15%. Non-Treaty Income is gross income that is not taxed at a tax treaty rate. To determine the tax on non-Treaty Income, calculate the tax at either a flat rate of 30% or a graduated rate, depending on whether the income is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States.

Some double taxation treaties contain an “independent personal services” clause, which allows residents of the treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed person from U.S. taxation if such person is in the U.S. for a period not exceeding a certain number of days, and if they do not have a fixed base regularly available to them in the U.S.,122223.

Under many double taxation agreements, foreign non-resident faculty or professors who come to the United States temporarily for the primary purpose of teaching at a university or other accredited educational institution are not subject to U.S. income tax on the remuneration received for teaching for the first 2 or 3 years after their arrival in the United States.

All treaties contain provisions for tax exemption on income earned by certain foreign governments. However, there is a difference in who is eligible for this benefit, depending on the specific treaty. Under many treaties, foreigners who are U.S. residents are not eligible for this benefit. Under most treaties, foreigners who are not citizens or subjects of the foreign state are not eligible for this benefit. Foreign governments should read the relevant treaty carefully to understand whether they are eligible for the benefits. Chapter 10 of this publication also contains information for foreign governments.

Under some double taxation agreements, students, apprentices and interns are exempt from tax on remittances received from abroad for tuition and maintenance. Furthermore, under some agreements, scholarships and grants, as well as limited amounts of remuneration received by students, apprentices and interns, may be exempt from tax.

Foreign residents are usually not eligible for tax treaty benefits because most tax treaties contain an exclusion clause that retains the right of the U.S. to tax its nationals and residents as if the tax treaty had not come into force. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the clause that may allow a foreign resident to continue to claim benefits under the treaty. Some exceptions to such a clause apply to all foreign residents (for example, under the U.S.-People's Republic of China treaty); others apply only to foreign residents who are not lawful permanent residents of the U.S. (green card holders). In certain cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because, under the treaty, that income will be exempt from U.S. tax. However, if the income was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or other information return, you should report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, amounts specified in column 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount claimed for the treaty benefits in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income" in parentheses, the name of the treaty country and the treaty article providing for the exemption. For income that is treaty-taxed at a reduced rate but not exempt, attach the following:

Generally, you must be a non-resident alien, student, apprentice, trainee, teacher, professor or researcher, to qualify for a treaty tax exemption on remittances from abroad for U.S. education and maintenance, scholarships, grants and research grants, and wages or other remuneration for personal services. Once you become a resident alien, you can generally no longer claim a treaty tax exemption on that income. However, if you entered the U.S. as a non-resident alien, but are now a resident alien for U.S. taxation purposes, the treaty tax exemption will continue to apply if you otherwise meet the requirements for the treaty tax exemption (including any time period for the application of the treaty tax exemption, as described below).

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income is not taxed in the U.S. under the treaty. However, if the income was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other disclosure, you should report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, amounts listed in Form W-2, column 1). Enter the amount claimed under the treaty in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income" in parentheses, the name of the treaty country, and the treaty article that provides for the exemption.

If you claim an agreement benefit that overrides or modifies any provision of the Tax Code and your tax is or may be reduced as a result of the claim, you must attach a properly completed Form 8833 to your tax return. See the "Exceptions" section below for situations where you are not required to file Form 8833.
These are the most common situations where Form 8833 is required. See the Form 8833 instructions for additional provisions.

You are not required to file Form 8833 in any of the following situations. 1. You claim a tax reduction under the agreement on interest, dividends, rent, royalties or other fixed or determined annual or recurring income normally taxed at the 30% rate. 2. You claim that the agreement reduces or alters the taxation of income from personal dependent services, pensions, annuities, social security and other government pensions, or income from performers, athletes, students, interns or teachers. This includes taxable scholarships and scholarship grants. 3. You claim a tax reduction or alteration under an international social security treaty or diplomatic or consular treaty. 4. You are a partner in a partnership or beneficiary of an inheritance or trust, and the partnership, inheritance or trust provides the required information in its return. 5. Payments or items of income that are otherwise required to be disclosed are not more than $10,000. 6. You claim benefits under the agreement for amounts that... 1. are reported to you on Form 1042-S (referring to Form 5472 disclosure returns filed by U.S. corporations that are 25% owned by a foreign person), or 2. are received by you... 1. as a related party from a reporting corporation, or 2. as a beneficial owner who is a direct owner of an account with a U.S. financial institution or a qualified intermediary, or a direct partner, beneficiary or owner of a retaining foreign corporation.

You should first review the tax exemption provisions under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty, if any, to determine whether your salary is eligible for U.S. income tax exemption under those provisions. Generally, you are not eligible for income tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty if you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien. For more information about the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular treaties, please contact the Office of Foreign Missions of the State Department at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you are not eligible for tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or bilateral consular conventions, but are a citizen of a country that has a double taxation agreement with the United States, you should consult that agreement to see if it has a provision that exempts your salary from U.S. income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident alien working in the United States for a foreign government, your salary is usually not exempt from tax. For more information, see the section "Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government" in Publication No. 901.

Employees of foreign governments who do not qualify for tax exemption under any of the Vienna Conventions, a bilateral consular treaty or a double taxation agreement may be exempted from U.S. income tax if they meet the following requirements for exemption from taxation of such wages under U.S. tax law. The tax exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of foreign governments, not to former employees. Pensions received by former foreign government employees who are resident in the U.S. do not qualify for the exemption discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors.

Many international organizations have a provision that may exempt your salary from U.S. income tax. If you work for an international organization in the U.S., first check if the international organization you work for has such a provision and if you are covered by it.

If the international organization agreement for which you work does not contain a tax exemption provision and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be eligible for tax exemption under U.S. law. However, see the subsection "Aliens with Retained Immigration Status (Legal Permanent Resident)" below for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption.

If you sign a waiver under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (Form I-508) to retain your legal permanent resident status (“green card”), you are no longer eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax laws from the date of the waiver.
If you are a foreigner, fall under category (1) or (2) above, and you have filed a request for denial under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a permit to leave.

International students, interns and exchange students, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2 or Q visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on these visas, other than... allowances to cover expenses related to study or internship in the United States, such as travel, maintenance and tuition costs; the cost of any services, meals and accommodation associated with such study or tuition; income from employment authorized by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS); or interest on deposits that are not directly related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

International students, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not earn income from sources in the United States while in the United States on these visas, except for... income from employment authorized by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), or interest on deposits that are not directly related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

Certain other non-resident aliens who have not earned taxable income in the tax year prior to the date of departure or in the previous tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that the alien has earned taxable income and that the collection of income tax may be impeded by departure, the IRS may require the alien to obtain a leave permit. This category includes the following groups. 1. Foreign military trainees who enter the United States for education under the auspices of the Department of Defense and leave the United States on official military assignments; 2. Foreign business visitors on a B-1 visa, or on B-1 and B-2 visas, who do not stay in the United States or U.S.-administered territories for more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. Foreign tourist visitors on a B-2 visa; 4. Foreigners transiting through the United States or U.S.-administered territories on a "C-1 visa" or under a contract, such as a sale and purchase agreement, between a transportation company and the Attorney General; and 5. Foreigners who enter the United States on a border crossing ID or who do not require a passport, visa or ID to cross the border if they...
Foreigners from Canada or Mexico who frequently travel from these countries to the United States to work and whose wages are subject to U.S. withholding tax.

If you do not fall into any of the categories listed above in the section "Aliens who do not require an exit permit", you must obtain an exit permit. To obtain an exit permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (whichever applies) with your local Tax Assistance Center (TAC) before leaving the United States. See the "Forms to File" subsection below. You must also pay all taxes listed as payable on Form 1040-C and any past-year taxes payable. See the "Paying Taxes and Getting Refunds" subsection below.

To obtain a tax return, you must visit a TAC office (see above) at least 2 weeks before you leave the U.S. and file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C, as well as any other required tax returns that have not been filed. The return cannot be issued more than 30 days before your departure. If you and your spouse(s) are foreigners and both are leaving the U.S., you must both go to a TAC office. Please note that all TAC offices are on appointment. You can call 844-545-5640 from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. local time to schedule a meeting. For more information about your local TAC office, please visit IRS.gov/TAC.

1. Your passport and foreigner registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your U.S. tax returns filed for the last 2 years. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Income tax receipts for those returns. 4. Receipts, bank records, cancelled cheques and other documents proving your withholdings, business expenses and dependents listed in your income. 5. A statement from each employer showing the wages paid and taxes withheld from January 1 of the current year to the date of departure if you were an employed person. If you were self-employed, you must provide a statement of income and expenses up to the date you plan to leave. 6. Confirmation of any estimated tax payments for the past and current year. 7. Documents proving any profit or loss from the sale of personal and/or real property, including fixed assets and goods. 8. Documents relating to scholarships or grants, including... 1. documentary proof of the founder, source and purpose of the grant. 2. copies of the grant application and its approval. 3. statement of the amount paid and your purposes and obligations under the grant. 4. list of all previous grants. 9. documents proving your eligibility for claimed special tax benefits. 10. document proving the date of your departure.

Foreigners in any of these categories who have not filed an income tax return or paid income tax for any tax year must file a tax return and pay income tax before they are issued a leave permit on Form 2063.

If you need to get a leave and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Normally, all income earned or reasonably expected to be earned during the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and tax must be paid on it. When you pay any tax listed as payable on Form 1040-C and you file all returns and pay all taxes due for previous years, you are granted a leave. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond to guarantee payment in place of tax payment for certain years. See the "Security Bond" section below.

If you provide information to the satisfaction of the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you may be granted a leave to leave by completing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax listed on it. However, you must file all tax returns that have not yet been duly filed and pay all income tax due on those returns.

You must pay all taxes listed as due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, unless a deposit is provided or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not prevent the collection of income tax. You must also pay any past tax debts. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, no tax is charged on the return. However, the IRS cannot provide a refund at the time of departure. If you are entitled to a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

If an income tax return is required by law, it must be filed even if a Form 1040-C has already been filed. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss the procedure for filing an annual U.S. income tax return. Tax paid using Form 1040-C must be credited to your tax liability for the entire tax year on your annual U.S. income tax return.

After receiving all your payroll and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or digitally) or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G); and interest, dividend and pension reports from banks and investment companies (Forms 1099), you have several options to choose from to prepare and file your tax return.

To complete the mobile-friendly forms, you must have an IRS account. You can file the form(s) online or download and print them to mail. You will need to scan the documents to prove your filing. For more information, visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

Go to IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account information. View amounts due and breakdowns by tax year. View payment agreement details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment, view 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments. Get online access to tax documents, including key information from your latest return and statements. View electronic copies of some IRS notifications. Approve or reject an authorization request submitted by a tax professional. Verify your address or choose how you want to receive notifications.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process. You can get a statement, view your last filed tax return and update your adjusted gross income.
This tool allows your tax professional to apply for authorization to access your individual online account with the IRS. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The safest and easiest way to get your tax refund is to file online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account. Direct deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use the direct deposit method to receive their refund. If you do not have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account for you.

The following are options for preparing and filing your return online or at your place of residence if you are eligible. Direct File. Direct File is a finally approved software that allows you to file federal individual tax returns online for free and securely. Direct File is suitable for partner state taxpayers filing relatively simple tax returns that include certain types of income and certain credits and deductions. While you cannot file a state return using Direct File if you live in a partner state, the system will redirect you to state-approved tax software for free state return filing. For more information, updates and answers to frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile Free File Free File System. This program allows you to prepare and file a federal individual income tax return for free using the software or Free File fillable forms. However, filing for U.S. state taxes may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to find out if you are eligible for free online federal tax preparation, electronic tax transfer, and direct deposit or payment options. VITA. The Income Tax Assistance Grant (VITA) program offers free tax assistance to low- and middle-income individuals, disabled individuals, and taxpayers with limited English language skills who need assistance in preparing their own tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app, or call 800-906-9887 for details on free tax filing.
For returns claiming an earned income credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC), the IRS may not issue a refund before mid-February.

Federal tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on how to make a payment using one of the following options. IRS Direct : Pay your individual tax bill or quarterly assessment tax at no additional charge, directly from your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet : Choose an approved payment system for payments online or by phone. Electronic withdrawal : Available only when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment : Best for business. Registration required. Check or money order : Mail your payment to the address provided in the notification or instructions. Cash : You can pay your taxes in cash at a participating retail store. Same-day delivery : You may be able to make a same-day transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about the availability, cost and timelines.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on payment options. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations in monthly payments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today.
Go to IRS.gov/Notices for more information on how to respond to an IRS notice or letter.

You can use the LEP (Form 1040) Request for Change of Preferred Language to state your preference to receive notices, letters and other correspondence from the IRS in a language other than English. You may not immediately receive correspondence in the language you request.

TAS will help you solve problems that you have not been able to solve yourself. If you have problems after contacting the IRS, always try to solve them. If you have not, contact us. Our services are free. TAS assists all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, companies and tax-exempt organizations. You can contact TAS if you are experiencing financial difficulties due to the inaction of the IRS, if you have tried to resolve your problem with the IRS and have failed, or if you see a deficiency in the work of the agency. For help with basic tax matters, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov.
If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership or S-Corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.

Go to IRS.gov/SocialMedia for a list of the various social media that the IRS uses to provide you with the latest tax updates, fraud warnings, initiatives, materials and services. At the IRS, privacy and security are top priorities. We use these tools to share publicly available information with you.

1. I was a resident of Belgium at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been granted the legal privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am in the United States for the purpose of education or training. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax under the U.S.-Belgian tax treaty in an amount not exceeding US$9,000 in any tax year. 4. I have arrived in the United States [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of your education or training]. For an intern who is temporarily in the United States for the purpose of training required for the pursuit of a professional activity or a professional specialty, the exemption from the treaty is only available for compensation payable for a period of 2 years.

1. I was a resident of Indonesia at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States solely for the purpose of studying at [insert name of the university or other accredited educational institution at which you are studying]; or I am temporarily in the United States as a recipient of a grant, benefit or award from [insert name of the non-profit organization or government agency granting the grant, benefit or award] for the primary purpose of studying, researching or training. 3. I will receive compensation for services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under a tax treaty between the United States and Indonesia in an amount not exceeding US$2,000 per tax year, provided that such services are rendered in connection with my studies or are necessary for my maintenance. 4. I have arrived in the United States [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of my studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years from the tax year including the date of my arrival.

1. I was a resident of [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under a tax treaty between the United States and [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] in an amount not exceeding $3,000 in any tax year. I have not previously claimed income tax exemption under that treaty in respect of income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years from the tax year including the date of my arrival. ii.

1. I was a resident of [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under a tax treaty between the United States and [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] in an amount not exceeding $2,000 in any tax year. I have not previously claimed an exemption from income tax under this treaty in respect of income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years from the tax year including the date of my arrival in the United States. ii

1. I was a resident of Morocco at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I was not legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under the U.S.-Morocco tax treaty in an amount not exceeding US$2,000 in any tax year. I have not previously claimed an exemption from income tax under that treaty in respect of student income earned prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States before beginning studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years from the tax year that includes the date of my arrival in the United States.

1. I was a resident of the Netherlands at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying full-time at [insert the name of the recognized U.S. university, college or school at which you are studying]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under the tax treaty between the United States and the Netherlands in an amount not exceeding US$2,000 in any tax year. 4. I have arrived in the United States at [insert the date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of your studies at a U.S. institution]. I claim this exemption only for the period of time reasonably necessary to complete my education.

1. I am a resident of Pakistan. I am not a U.S. citizen. Because I have not been lawfully granted the privilege of permanent residence in the U.S. as an immigrant, I cannot be considered a resident alien for the relevant tax year. 2. I am temporarily present in the U.S. solely as a student at [insert the name of the recognized university, college or school in the U.S. at which you are attending]. 3. For personal services rendered in the U.S., I will receive compensation. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax under the U.S.-Pakistan tax treaty in an amount not exceeding US$5,000 in any tax year.

1. I was a resident of [insert name of the treaty country with which you are seeking exemption] on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying or training at [insert name of the university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]; or I am temporarily in the United States as a recipient of a grant, benefit or award from [insert name of the non-profit organization or government agency granting the grant, benefit or award]. 3. I will receive compensation for services rendered in the United States. This compensation is subject to federal income tax exemption in an amount not exceeding $5,000 in any tax year. 4. I have arrived in the United States [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of your studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years from the tax year that includes the date of my arrival.

1. I was a resident of [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying or training at [insert name of university or other accredited educational institution at which you are studying or training]. 3. I will receive compensation for services rendered in the United States. This compensation is subject to exemption from federal income tax under a tax treaty between the United States and [insert name of treaty country with which you are claiming exemption] in an amount not exceeding $5,000 in any tax year. 4. I have arrived in the United States [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation payable for five tax years beginning in the tax year including the date of my arrival and for such time as is necessary to meet the educational requirements of a full-time student as a candidate for a graduate or specialist degree at a recognized institution.

1. I was a resident of Trinidad and Tobago at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of the university or other accredited educational institution at which you are studying]. 3. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax in an amount not exceeding US$2,000 (or, if you are undergoing education required to pursue a professional activity or a professional specialty, not exceeding US$5,000) for any taxable year. I have not previously claimed an income tax exemption under this treaty in respect of income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of your studies at a U.S. educational institution].

This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under the U.S.-Tunisia tax treaty in an amount not exceeding US$4,000 in any tax year. 4. If you are a foreigner (non-U.S. citizen), you are considered a non-resident foreigner unless you meet one of the two tests described in the subsection "Resident Foreigners" below.

You are a U.S. resident for tax purposes if you have passed the Green Card or Substantial Presence test during the 2024 calendar year (January 1 - December 31). Even if you do not pass either of these tests, you may elect to be treated as a U.S. resident for a portion of the year. See the "Choosing the First Year" subsection in the "Dual-Status Aliens" section below.

Until you have proof that your letter has been received, you will remain a resident alien for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of your green card because it is more than 10 years old, or because you have been away from the United States for a certain period of time.

Do not count the days you travel to work in the United States from your place of residence in Canada or Mexico if you regularly travel to work from Canada or Mexico. You are considered to be regularly traveling to work if you travel to work in the United States for more than 75% (0.75) of the working days during your working period. For this purpose, “travel to work” means traveling to work and returning to your place of residence within 24 hours. “Working days” are the days you work in the United States, Canada or Mexico. “Working period” means the period beginning on the first day of the current year when you are physically in the United States for work and ending on the last day of the current year when you are physically in the United States for work. If your work requires your presence in the United States only on a seasonal or cyclical basis, your working period begins on the first day of the season or cycle during which you are in the United States for work and ends on the last day of the season or cycle during which you are in the United States for work. You may have more than one working period in a calendar year, and your working period may begin in one calendar year and end in the following calendar year.

When counting days in the United States, you can only exclude the days you actually participated in the sporting event. You cannot exclude the days you were in the United States for training at the event, for promotional or other activities related to the event, or for travel between events.

For example, for the purposes of the substantial presence test, you may justify that you intended to leave the United States if your purpose of visiting the United States can be achieved within an insufficiently long period. However, if you would need a long period of time to achieve the purpose of your visit and that period would allow you to pass the substantial presence test, you will not be able to justify the intention to leave the United States before the end of that long period. In the case of a person who has been declared mentally incapable, proof of the intention to leave the United States may be determined by looking at the pattern of the person's behavior prior to the declaration of mental incapacity. If you are eligible to exclude days of presence for health reasons, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the "Form 8843" section below. You cannot exclude any days of stay in the United States in the following circumstances. You were initially not allowed to leave, then you were able to leave, but stayed in the United States beyond the time objectively required to take action on departure. You returned to the United States for treatment for an illness that occurred during your previous stay. This condition existed before you arrived in the United States and you were aware of the condition. It does not matter whether you needed treatment for the illness when you entered the United States.

A foreign employer includes an office or place of business of a U.S. organization in a foreign state or territory administered by the U.S. If you are eligible to exclude days of presence in the U.S. as a teacher or intern, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the "Form 8843" subsection below.
If you are eligible to exclude days spent in the United States as a student, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the Form 8843 subsection below.

A tax home is the common territory of your main place of business, work or service, regardless of where you live. A tax home is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or a sole trader. If you do not have a permanent or main place of work because of the nature of your activity, then your tax home is the place where you regularly live.

In determining whether you have a closer connection with a foreign State, the term “foreign State” means … any territory under the sovereignty of the United Nations or of a government other than the United States Government, the territorial waters of a foreign State (as defined by United States law), the seabed and subsoil of those submarine areas adjacent to the territorial waters of a foreign State, and over which a foreign State has exclusive rights under international law for the exploration and exploitation of natural resources, and territories administered by the United States.

It does not matter whether your permanent residence is a house, an apartment or a furnished room. It also does not matter whether you rent it or own it. It is important, however, that your home is available permanently and at all times, and not only for a short stay.

Steps to change your status to permanent resident include, but are not limited to, completing the following forms: Form I-508, Request for Waiver of Certain Rights, Privileges, Exemptions, and Immunities; Form I-485, Application for Registration of Permanent Residence or Adjustment of Status; Form I-130, Application for a Foreign Relative; Form I-140, Immigrant Application for Foreign Workers; Form ETA-9089, Application for Permanent Employment Certificate, Schedules A-D and Final Decision; Form DS-230, Application for Immigration Visa and Alien Registration.

If you are a dual resident taxpayer, you may still qualify for benefits under a double taxation treaty. A dual resident taxpayer is a taxpayer who is a resident of the United States and another country under the tax laws of each of those countries. A double taxation treaty between two countries must contain a provision to resolve conflicting claims of residence (the "tie-break" rule).
You can be both a non-resident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year. This usually happens in the year you enter or leave the United States.

If you were a U.S. resident for any part of the previous calendar year and are a U.S. resident for any part of the current year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at the beginning of the current year.

When counting the days of your stay in paragraphs (1) and (2) above, do not count the days you have been in the United States under any of the previously discussed exceptions in the subsection "Days of Presence in the United States". If you choose the first year, the start date of your stay in 2024 will be the first day of the earliest 31-day period (as described in paragraph (1) above) that you use to qualify for the option.

You cannot file Form 1040 or 1040-SR or this application until you meet the 2025 substantial presence test. If you do not pass the 2025 test as of April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of time to file your 2024 Form 1040 or 1040-SR for a reasonable period after you become eligible for long-term residence. To request an extension of time to file until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You can file the form on paper or use one of the electronic filing options described in the Form 4868 instructions. Given this extension, you must pay your 2024 tax arrears as if you were a non-resident alien all year. To calculate your tax, you can use Form 1040-NR. Enter the tax amount on Form 4868. If you fail to pay your tax arrears, you will be charged interest on any tax not paid by the due date, and you may be subject to a late payment penalty. Once you have made your choice of the first year, you cannot change it without the approval of the IRS. If you fail to follow the procedures described here for choosing the first year, you will be considered a non-resident alien for the entire year 2024. However, this rule does not work if you have clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to learn about the filing procedures and the important steps to comply with those procedures.

You usually make this choice when you file a joint tax return. However, you can also make the choice by filing a Form 1040-X, Amended Individual Tax Return of a U.S. Citizen. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and enter “Amended” at the top of the amended tax return. If you choose an amended tax return, you and your spouse must also amend any tax returns that you may have filed after the selected year.

If you are a U.S. resident during any period in 2025, as well as during any period in 2024, you will be considered a resident until the end of 2024. This rule applies regardless of whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country than the United States during 2024, and whether you are a resident under the Substantial Presence Test or the Green Card Test.

If you are married at the end of the tax year and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or a resident alien and the other spouse is a non-resident alien, you have the option of designating the non-resident spouse as a resident for the purposes of income taxation for the entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse can request to waive your status as a U.S. resident under any tax treaty.

However, you can also make the choice by completing an amended joint return using Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and enter “Amended” at the top of the amended return. If you make the choice with an amended tax return, you and your spouse must also amend any tax returns that you may have filed after the selected year.

Once you have elected resident status, it applies to all subsequent years, unless it is suspended (as explained in "Suspension of Electing Status") or terminated by one of the following methods. If the election has ceased to be valid by one of the following methods, neither spouse can make the election in any subsequent tax year. 1. Cancellation. Either spouse may cancel the election for any tax year provided that he or she completes the cancellation before the due date for filing the tax return for that tax year. The spouse who cancels the election must attach a signed statement that the election is cancelled. The application must include the name, address and identification number (TIN) of each spouse. (If one spouse dies, provide the name and address of the person who cancels the election in place of the deceased spouse.) The application must also include a list of all states, foreign countries and territories where joint property laws are in effect and where one spouse resides or where property is located that generates income for either spouse. File the application as follows. 1. If the cancelling spouse must file a tax return, attach the application to the return for the first year of the cancellation. 2. If the cancelling spouse does not have to file a tax return but does (for example, to claim a refund), attach the application to the tax return. 3. If the cancelling spouse does not have to file a tax return and does not file a tax return even for a refund, send the application to the same IRS location where you last filed your joint tax return. 2. Death. The death of one spouse terminates the election, beginning with the date of the death of the spouse.

If you are a resident alien, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other payments for services, income from leasing property or royalties, and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in the U.S. and abroad.

Non-resident aliens are taxed only on their income from United States sources and on certain income related to the pursuit of a professional or business activity in the United States (see chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from U.S. sources that apply to most non-resident aliens are shown in Table 2-1. The following discussions cover the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules. Not all items of income from U.S. sources are taxed. See chapter 3.

Real property is land and buildings, and generally everything that is built on, grows on or is attached to land. Gross income from United States sources includes the increase, profit and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.1

Income from the sale of the products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural resource, or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign state, or located in a foreign state and sold in the United States, is partly income from U.S. sources. See the definition of this part in the regulations, section 1.863-1(b).

Personal property is property such as machinery, equipment, or furniture that is not real property. Profits or losses from the sale or exchange of personal property usually have a source in the United States if your tax home is in the United States. If your tax home is not in the United States, the profits or losses are usually considered to have been received from sources outside the United States.

Inventory is personal property used in trade or primarily intended for sale to buyers in the course of ordinary professional or business activities. Income from the sale of inventory you acquire is deemed to be received at the place of sale of the property. Usually, this is the place where ownership of the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is income from a source in the United States, whether you acquired it in the United States or elsewhere. Income from the sale of inventory that you made in the United States and sold outside the United States (or vice versa) is income from a source in the United States. These rules apply even if your tax home is not in the United States.

To determine the source of income from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the income that does not exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property. You allocate that portion of the gains among U.S. sources based on the ratio of U.S. depreciation adjustments to the total amount of depreciation adjustments. The remainder of the gains is considered to have been received from sources outside the U.S. In this case, “U.S. depreciation adjustments” are depreciation adjustments to the property base that are allowed in calculating taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is used predominantly in the U.S. during a tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation adjustments. But there are some exceptions for certain vehicles, communications equipment and other property used internationally. Gains from the sale of depreciable property that exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property are treated as if the property were inventory, as discussed above. Loss is treated in the same way as depreciation deductions. However, if the property was used predominantly in the U.S., all loss reduces income from the U.S. source. The property base usually means the cost (money plus the fair market value of other property or services) of the property you acquired. Depreciation is the amount deducted to recover the cost or other base of an asset used in a professional or commercial activity. The amount you can deduct depends on the value of the property, when you began using the property, and whether you have a depreciation adjustment on the property.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, secret processes or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names and other similar property. Profits from the sale of amortising or depreciating intangible property within the limits of previously allowed depreciation or wear deductions are treated in the same way as the original deductions. This rule is similar to the source rule for profits from the sale of amortising property. See the subsection "Depreciable property" above for details on how to apply this rule. Profits exceeding depreciation deductions are considered to be sourced in the country where the property is used if the income from the sale depends on the productivity, use or disposal of the property.

Notwithstanding any of the foregoing rules, if your tax home is not in the United States, but you have an office or other permanent place of business in the United States, income from any sale of personal property (including inventory) relating to that office or place of business is considered income from a U.S. source. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory for use, disposal or consumption outside the U.S. if your office or other permanent place of business outside the U.S. was materially involved in the sale.

Interest income from a U.S. source does not include the following items. 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or a domestic corporation on bonds issued before August 10, 2010, if, in the three-year period ending at the end of the payer's tax year preceding the payment of the interest, at least 80% (0.80) of the total gross income... 1. came from sources outside the U.S. and 2. is related to the active pursuit of a profession or business by a person or entity in another country or territory administered by the U.S. However, the interest will be considered as interest income from a U.S. source if one of the following conditions applies. 1.

In most cases, dividend income from domestic corporations is income from U.S. sources. Dividend income from foreign corporations is usually income from a foreign source. An exception to the second rule is discussed later. A substitute payment of dividends to a transferor of securities under a securities lending or repurchase transaction is accounted for in the same way as a distribution on the transferred security.

The payment of the equivalent amount of dividends includes any gross amount referred to as dividends from a U.S. source and used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from the taxpayer under a contract if the taxpayer is a party entitled to receive payments under the contract. As a result, the taxpayer may be considered to have received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or does not pay any amount as the net amount is zero. In 2024, the NPC or ELI will generally be the specified NPC or specified ELI, respectively, if the contract relates to derivative transactions of the delta one type. Typically, the delta is the ratio of the change in the fair market value of the NPC or ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares specified in the contract. Typically, the amount of the dividend equivalent for a given NPC or ELI is the amount of dividend per share multiplied by the number of shares specified in the contract multiplied by the delta of the contract. For more complex contracts, special rules apply. For more information, see section 1.871-15 of the regulations and Notice 2024-44 (or subsequent notifications).

All wages and any other remuneration for services performed in the United States are deemed to be received from U.S. sources. The only exceptions to this rule are discussed in the "Employees of Foreign Persons, Organizations or Offices" subsection below, and in the "Crew Members" subsection above. If you are an employee and receive remuneration for work or personal services performed both in the United States and abroad, special rules apply to the determination of the source of remuneration.

Some companies sell products under a multi-level marketing scheme, in which a top-level distributor who has sponsored a lower-level distributor is entitled to payments from the company based on certain actions of that lower-level distributor.
