Typically, depending on the facts, payments from such multi-level marketing companies to independent (non-employed) distributors (top-level distributors) based on the sales or purchases of the persons they have sponsored (lower-level distributors) constitute income for the performance of personal services in the recruitment, training and support of lower-level distributors. The source of such income is usually dependent on the location of the services provided by the top-level distributor and may, depending on the facts, be considered as a multi-year remuneration, the source of income being determined over the period to which such remuneration relates.

The source of multi-year remuneration is usually determined on a time-based basis over the period to which the remuneration relates. Multi-year remuneration is remuneration that is included in your income in one tax year but relates to a period that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period to which the remuneration relates based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, the amount of remuneration that relates to a period of time that includes several calendar years relates to the entire multi-year period. The amount of remuneration that is considered to have been received from U.S. sources is determined by multiplying the total amount of remuneration for the multi-year period by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or a unit of time less than a day, if applicable) that you have performed U.S. employment or personal services in connection with the project. The denominator of the fraction is the total number of days (or a unit of time less than one day, if applicable) that you have worked or provided personal services in connection with the project.

The above additional benefits, except for tax reimbursement and hazardous or hard work allowances, are calculated based on the main place of work. The main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. It can be your office, factory, store, store or other place. If there is no such place where you spend most of your working time, then your main place of work is the place where your work is concentrated, i.e. where you attend work or are required to “do” your work. If you have several workplaces at the same time, the location of your main place of work depends on the facts of each case. The most important factors to consider are … the total time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you earn in each place.
The removal deduction is only available if you are an active service member of the United States military and are moving due to a permanent change of duty location.

The source of local transportation benefits is determined by the location of your primary workplace. Local transportation allowance is the amount you receive as compensation for local transportation for you, your spouse or dependents at your primary workplace. The amount considered as a local transportation allowance is limited to the actual cost of local transportation and the fair rental cost of any employer-provided vehicle used primarily by you, your spouse or your dependents for local transportation.
The source of the tax refund is the jurisdiction that assessed the tax for which you are getting a refund.

The source of relocation reimbursement is usually determined by the location of your new primary workplace. However, the source is determined by the location of your former primary workplace if you provide sufficient evidence that such a determination of source is more appropriate in the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer or a written statement of company policy that was drawn up prior to the relocation and entered into or established to encourage you or other employees to relocate to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the relocation costs you incur to return to your former primary workplace, whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that place. u It may contain certain conditions that determine the eligibility for reimbursement, provided that those conditions set out clear standards that can only be met before or as a result of the completion of your relocation to your former primary workplace.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your remuneration on an alternative basis if you prove to the IRS that, in the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis determines the source of your remuneration more accurately than the time or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep documentation (including for verification) that supports why the alternative basis determines the source of your remuneration more accurately. Also, if the total amount of remuneration from all sources is $250,000 or more, answer “Yes” to both questions on line K of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach a written statement to your tax return that includes the following: 1. Your name and social security number (SSN) (entered at the top of the return). 2. The specific remuneration income or specific additional benefit for which you use the alternative basis. 3. For each item in (2), the alternative source distribution base used. 4. For each item in (2), a calculation showing how the alternative distribution was calculated. 5. A comparison of the dollar amount of U.S. remuneration and foreign remuneration received on both the alternative and the time or geographic basis described above.

This applies whether the surface vessel or aircraft is owned, leased or leased. The term “surface vessel or aircraft” includes any container used in connection with the surface vessel or aircraft. All income from transportation that begins or ends in the United States is treated as income from U.S. sources.

As a rule, scholarships, grants, prizes and awards are paid from the payer's residency, regardless of who actually pays the funds. However, see the subsection "Activities to be carried out outside the United States" below. For example, payments for research or education in the United States made by a United States non-corporate resident or a national corporation are payments from U.S. sources.

If you receive a pension from a national fund for services rendered both in the United States and abroad, a portion of your pension payments comes from U.S. sources. This portion is the amount related to the pension plan income and the employer contributions made for services rendered in the United States. This rule applies regardless of whether payments are made under a qualifying or non-qualifying stock reward plan, retirement plan, profit-sharing plan or annuity (whether or not it is a contributory one). If you have worked as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government under a plan, such as the Public Service Pension System, that is considered a qualifying pension plan. Your income from a U.S. source is the taxable amount of payments that relate to your total U.S. government base salary, excluding tax-free fees for services rendered outside the U.S. u2.

Your income from a U.S. source includes real estate income and royalties received during the tax year from property located in the U.S. or from any interest in such property. Income from a U.S. source also includes real estate income or royalties for the use or privilege of use of intangible property in the U.S., such as patents, copyrights, secret processes and formulas, goodwill, trademarks, franchises and similar property12.
In these cases, you and your spouse must declare the joint income as described below.

The earned income of the spouse(s), with the exception of income from professional or commercial activities and the partner ' s share of the partnership ' s income, is considered to be the income of the spouse whose services have generated the income, and this spouse must declare such income in his/her separate tax return.

Income from professional or commercial activities other than the distributable share of the partner in the income of the partnership is considered as income of the spouse or spouses who are engaged in professional or commercial activities, and this spouse must declare such income in his or her separate tax return.
The partner’s distributive share in the company’s income (or loss) is treated as the partner’s income (or loss).

Income from one spouse's separate property (which is not earned income, income from professional or commercial activities or income from a distributable share in a partnership) is considered to be that spouse's income. u That spouse must declare such income in his/her separate tax return. u Use the relevant law on joint property u to determine what is separate property.

Resident and non-resident aliens are allowed to have an exclusion from gross income if they meet certain conditions. An exclusion from gross income is generally income that you receive but that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. taxation.

If you are physically present in another country or countries for at least 330 full days in any 12-month period, you may qualify for an exclusion of foreign earned income. The exclusion amounted to $126,500 in 2024. In addition, you may exclude or deduct certain amounts for foreign housing. You may also qualify if you are a valid resident of a foreign state and a citizen or resident of a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty. For more information, see Publication No. 54.

A foreign state is any territory under the sovereignty of a government other than the United States Government. The term "foreign state" includes the territorial waters and airspace of a country, but not the international waters and airspace above them. It also includes the seabed and subsoil of those submarine areas adjacent to the territorial waters of a country over which it has exclusive rights under international law for the exploration and exploitation of natural resources. The term "foreign state" does not include possessions or territories administered by the United States. It does not include the Antarctic region.

Interest income not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States is excluded from income if it relates to... deposits (including certificates of deposit) in financial institutions; deposits or withdrawal accounts in mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, local building and credit associations and other savings institutions registered and regulated as savings and credit or similar associations under federal or state law (if interest paid or credited is deductible by the association); and amounts retained by an insurance company pursuant to an agreement to pay interest thereon.11

Interest on obligations of a state or political entity, the District of Columbia or a territory administered by the United States is generally not included in income; however, interest on certain private-sector bonds, arbitrage bonds and some unregistered bonds are included in income.11

Interest and initial issue discount (OID) that qualify as tax-exempt interest are not subject to Chapter 3 (Tax Code) withholding under Sections 1441 to 1443. However, such interest may be subject to withholding if it is a withholding payment and there are no exceptions to Chapter 4 (Tax Code) withholding under Sections 1471 to 1474. For more information, refer to the topic of tax-exempt interest in the section “Withholding on Specific Income” in Publication No. 515. To be tax-exempt, interest must be paid on bonds issued after July 18, 1984. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, tax-exempt interest does not include interest paid on unregistered debt obligations. Prior to March 19, 2012, tax-exempt interest included interest on certain registered and unregistered (bearer) bonds if the bonds meet the requirements described below.

A liability that would otherwise be considered in a registered form is not considered in a registered form at a given time if it can be converted at any time in the future into a liability that is not in a registered form. For more information on whether liabilities are considered to be in a registered form, see the topic of tax-free interest in the section “Withholding on Specific Income” in Publication No. 515.
No documentation is required for bearer interest to qualify as tax-free interest, but in some cases you may need documentation for Form 1099 reporting and additional withholding.

Tax-exempt interest does not include contingent interest. contingent interest is any of the following interests. 1. Interest that is determined by reference to... any income, sales or other cash flows of the debtor or a related person; income or profits of the debtor or a related person; any change in the value of any property of the debtor or a related person; or any dividends, partnership payments or similar payments made by the debtor or a related person. for exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other kind of contingent interest as may be specified by the Minister of Finance in regulations.
The following dividend income is exempt from tax in the amount of 30%.
The 30% tax on interest-related dividends from United States sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) is not charged.

The 30% tax on certain dividends on short-term capital gains from United States sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) may be waived. The mutual fund will determine in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax exemption will not apply to you if you are in the United States for 183 days or more during your tax year.
If you are paid by a foreign employer, your income from a U.S. source may be exempt from U.S. tax, but only if you fall into one of the categories discussed below.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from domestic services provided in the United States is income from a U.S. source and is subject to taxation under the rules of Chapter 4. If your payment for these services exceeds $3,000, the entire amount is income from professional or commercial activities in the United States.

Foreign non-resident students and exchange guests present in the United States under an F, J, M or Q visa may exclude from their gross income wages received from a foreign employer. This group includes active students, academics, interns, teachers, professors, research assistants, specialists or leaders in a specialised field of knowledge or skill, or persons of similar profile. This also includes the spouse(s) of the foreigner and minor children if they come with the foreigner or come later to join the foreigner.
The term “foreign employer” does not include a foreign government. Payments made by a foreign government that are exempt from U.S. income tax are discussed in Chapter 10.2

Income of any kind exempt from tax in the United States under a treaty to which the United States is a party is excluded from your gross income. However, income that is only subject to tax by treaty is included in your gross income. See Chapter 9.

If you are a degree candidate, you may exclude from your income some or all of the amounts you receive as a qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to both resident and non-resident foreigners. If you are a non-resident foreigner receiving a scholarship from a non-U.S. source, you are not subject to U.S. taxation.

However, for educational expenses to qualify, the terms of the scholarship or grant may not require that it be used for other purposes, such as accommodation and meals, or that it be stated that it cannot be used for tuition or course-related expenses.

The amount of the scholarship used to pay any expenses that are not eligible is taxable, even if the expenses are fees that must be paid to the educational institution as a condition of enrolment or attendance.

Resident aliens are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed depending on the source of their income and whether their income is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. The following material will help you determine whether the income you receive during a tax year is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and understand how it is taxed.

This means that their worldwide income is taxed in the United States and must be reported on their U.S. tax return. Foreign residents' income is subject to the differentiated tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens.

The difference between these two categories is that the actual related income after allowable deductions is taxed at differentiated rates. These are the same rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Income that is not directly related is taxed at a flat rate of 30% (or lower treaty).

u Generally, you must engage in a business during a tax year in order to be able to consider income earned in that year as actually related to that professional or commercial activity. u Whether you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. u The following discussions will help you determine whether you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. u

If you provide domestic services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. u Certain remuneration paid to a non-resident foreigner by a foreign employer is not included in gross income. u For more information, see u "Work Performed for a Foreign Employer" in u Chapter 3. u

If you are temporarily in the United States as a non-immigrant on an F, J, M or Q visa and do not engage in a business activity, you are considered to be engaging in a business activity in the United States if you have taxable income from a scholarship or fellowship grant described in section 1441(b).

You are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States if trading in stocks, securities or commodities on your own account is your sole activity in the United States. This rule applies even if the trading is carried out while you are in the United States or by your employee, your broker or other agent.

If you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, all income, profits or losses for the tax year that you receive from U.S. sources (except for certain investment income) are considered to be actually related to the U.S. activity. This rule applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the professional or commercial activity carried out in the United States during the tax year.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether income from a U.S. source that falls under one of the three categories and is received during the tax year is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the U.S. If the tests show that the income is actually related, you should include it as part of other actually related income.
Generally, the shares of a corporation are not considered as an asset used or held for use in a professional or commercial activity in the United States.
Under this test, if the conduct of a professional or commercial activity in the United States was a substantial factor in the generation of income,a the income is deemed to be actually related.b

If you provide personal services in the United States, you are deemed to be engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Personal services income received by you in the tax year in which you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States is actually connected to the professional or commercial activity in the United States. Income received in a year other than the year of provision of services is also actually connected if it would have been actually connected if you received that income in the year of provision of services. Personal services income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, and employee allowances and bonuses. Income may be paid to you in the form of money, services, or property. If you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States solely because you provide personal services in the United States during the tax year, income and gains from assets, and income and losses from the sale or exchange of capital assets, are generally not actually connected to your professional or commercial activity. However, if there is a direct economic connection between the ownership of an asset and the professional or commercial activity of providing personal services, then the income, gains, or losses are actually connected.

"Permanent place of business" generally means a place, facility, building or other similar facility through which you engage in professional or commercial activity. "Regular service" means that a ship or aircraft follows a published schedule with repeated flights or missions at regular intervals between the same points for flights or missions that begin or end in the United States.

This is any interest in real property located in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands, or any interest (other than as a creditor) in a national corporation that is a corporation that owns real property in the United States. Real property includes the following. 1. Land and unused natural products of the land, such as growing crops and timber, as well as mines, wells and other natural deposits. 2. Improvements to the land, including buildings, other permanent structures and their structural components. 3.

The shares of any domestic corporation are treated as the shares of a U.S. corporation that owns the real estate, unless you prove that the corporation is not a U.S. corporation that owns the real estate.

In most cases, any payment from a QIE to a non-resident foreigner, foreign corporation or other QIE that relates to the QIE's profits from the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest is treated as a profit recognized by the non-resident foreigner, foreign corporation or other QIE from the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest. Certain exceptions apply to the cross-sectional test for payments from a QIE. A QIE payment in respect of shares regularly traded on an organized securities market in the U.S. is not treated as income from the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest if the shareholder owns 5% or less of those shares (or 10% or less of those shares in the case of a REIT) at any time within 1 year ending on the date of payment.

For the purposes of determining whether a QIE is controlled domestically, the following rules apply. 1. A person holding less than 5% of shares of any class of QIE that are regularly traded and bought on an organized securities market in the United States throughout the verification period will be treated as a U.S. person. 2. Any shares of QIE that are owned by another QIE will be treated as owned by a foreign person if... 1. any class of shares of such other QIE is regularly traded and bought on an organized securities market, or 2. such other QIE is a RIC that issues certain redeemable securities.

If this is the case, you are deemed to have received income from the sale or exchange of a share in U.S. real estate in an amount equal to the payment that would have been treated as such income. This also applies to any substitute dividend payment. A transaction is not considered a fictitious sale if... you actually receive a payment from a domestically controlled QIE related to the share sold or acquired as a result of the transaction, or you sell shares of any class in a QIE that are regularly traded on an organized securities market in the U.S., but only if you have not owned more than 5% of the shares of that class at any time during the 1 year ending on the date of payment.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign corporation that carries on (or is deemed to carry on) a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and you directly or indirectly sell that interest, the gain or loss from the sale of that interest in the corporation may affect your federal tax liability. Under section 864(c)(8), your gain or loss from the sale, exchange or other disposition of an interest in the corporation is deemed to be actually related to the conduct of a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. (“actually related gain” or “actually related loss”). However, the amount of the actual related gain or loss is limited to the portion that would have been your distributable share of the actual related gain or loss if the corporation had sold all of its assets at fair market value on the date of sale. Section 864(c)(8) applies to sales, exchanges or other dispositions that occurred on or after November 27, 2017.

Any income from a foreign source that is equivalent to any of the items of income described above is considered to be actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. For example, interest and dividend equivalents from a foreign source are considered to be actually related to the United States if the income is derived by a foreign person from actively conducting banking, financial or similar business in the United States.i

Income that you receive in a tax year and that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States is taxed, after allowable deductions, at the rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Generally, you can receive actually related income only if you are a non-resident foreigner engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services, or any other transaction during a tax year in which you are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, but such payments would be considered to be actually related income in the year of the transaction or provision of services, they are treated as actually related income in the tax year in which you received them.
You may be able to classify all income from real estate as income directly related to U.S. activities. See the subsection "Income from Real Estate" later in this section.

The 30% (or lower by agreement) rate applies to the gross amount of fixed, determined, annual or periodic (FDAP) profits, revenues or income from a U.S. source. Income is considered fixed when it is paid in amounts known in advance. Income is determined whenever there is a basis for determining the amount payable. Income may be periodic if it is paid from time to time. It does not have to be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income may be determined or periodic even if the duration of the time during which payments are made increases or decreases.

Generally, non-resident foreigners are subject to 30% tax on gross gambling income earned in the United States unless such income is directly related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States and is not exempt from tax under a treaty. However, non-commercial gambling income is not subject to tax if a non-resident foreigner wins in the United States at blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette or the big six wheel. Non-resident foreigners are subject to differentiated taxation on net gambling income earned in the United States that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Under some tax treaties, such income is exempt from tax. A list of tax treaties that exempt gambling winnings from U.S. tax can be found in Table 1 of the IRS.gov/TreatyTables. For more information, see Publication No. 915.

A non-resident foreigner must include 85% of any social security payments (and the equivalent of the social security of the Tier 1 railroader's pension) in a source of fixed, determined, annual or recurring income in the United States. Social security payments include monthly pension, survivor's and disability benefits. This income is exempt from taxation under certain tax treaties. See Table 1 on the Tax Treaty Tables webpage, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables for a list of tax treaties that exempt U.S. social security payments from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Publication No. 915.

Report your gains and losses from the sale or exchange of capital assets that are not actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States in a separate Schedule D (Form 1040) or in Form 4797, or both.

If you have income from real property located in the United States that you own in whole or in part and you acquired it for the purpose of earning income, you may treat all income from that property as income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. This option applies to all income from real property located in the United States and intended for earning income, and to all income from any interest in such property. This includes income from lease, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells, or other natural resources. It also includes profits from the sale or exchange of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore with a retained economic interest. You may make this option only in respect of real property income that is not otherwise related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States. If you make this option, you are eligible for deductions related to real property income, and only your net real property income will be taxed. This option does not apply to a non-resident alien who is not otherwise engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States as engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year.
This choice remains valid for all subsequent tax years, unless you cancel it.

You can opt out without IRS approval by filing Form 1040-X for the year you made the election and for subsequent tax years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years of the date you filed your return or 2 years of the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. If this time period has expired for the year you opted out, you cannot opt out for that year. However, you can opt out for later tax years only if you have IRS permission. For information on how to obtain IRS approval, see section 1.871-10(d)(2) of the IRS Regulations.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income from the United States. This includes only transportation income, which is considered to have been received from United States sources if the transportation starts or ends in the United States. For transportation and domestic services income, the transportation must be between the United States and a territory administered by the United States. For domestic services of a non-resident alien, this applies only to income received from or in any way related to an aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are taxed on gross income and gains from your U.S. source on a net basis at the differentiated rates applicable to individuals (with allowable deductions) for the period during which you were a non-resident alien, unless you are subject to a higher tax under section 871 (the rules that normally apply to the taxation of non-resident alien income are discussed above) after taking into account any applicable treaty benefits. For information on how to calculate the special tax, see the section "Expatriation tax" below.

If you are liable for this tax for any year during the period you were a non-resident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return must be filed within the deadline (including extensions) for filing your U.S. income tax return for the year you become a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach to your return a statement showing the source of all your gross U.S. and foreign income, as well as the items of income that fall under this special rule.

The expatriation tax provisions apply to U.S. citizens who have renounced their citizenship and to long-term residents (LTRS) who have ceased their residence. The following section describes the expatriation rules under Section 877A that apply to persons who left the country on or after June 17, 2008. See the section "Expatriation after June 16, 2008" below. If you left the country before June 17, 2008, refer to the section "Expatriation after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008" in Chapter 4 of Publication No. 519 of 2018 and the Instructions for Form 8854 of 2018. If you renounced your citizenship or ceased your long-term residence after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008, you will continue to be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (as applicable) of your departure and file Form 8854 with the IRS.

You must file an initial Form 8854 in the year you renounce U.S. citizenship or terminate your long-term residence, even if you are not liable to pay expatriate tax. In addition, you must file a Form 8854 annually after your expatriation if you were liable to pay expatriate tax and... 1. you have deferred the payment of current market value tax (see the subsection "Deferring the Payment of Current Market Value Tax" below), 2. you have deferred compensation titles, or 3. you are entitled to income from the assets of trusts without a trustee.

You are deemed to have renounced U.S. citizenship no earlier than the following days: 1. The date you renounced U.S. citizenship before a U.S. diplomatic or consular official (provided that the voluntary renouncement was subsequently confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 2. The date you filed with the Department of State a signed declaration of voluntary renouncement of U.S. citizenship attesting to the act of expatriation (provided that the voluntary renouncement was subsequently confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 3. The date the Department of State issued a certificate of loss of citizenship. 4. The date a U.S. court annulled your certificate of naturalization.

In the year you leave the United States, you are liable to income tax on the net unrealized gain (or loss) in your property as if the property had been sold at fair market value the day before you left the United States. This applies to most types of property interest that you owned on the date of renunciation or cessation of residence. However, see the "Exceptions" subsection below.

Instead, in the case of (1) and (3), tax may be withheld initially. In the case of (2), you are deemed to receive the current value of your accrued benefits for the day prior to the date of your expatriation. In the case of (4), you are deemed to receive a distribution of your entire share of the bill for the day prior to the date of your expatriation. For more information, see Notice 2009-85 and the Form 8854 instructions.

Once you have determined your U.S. residential alien status, the source of your income, and whether (and how) that income is taxed in the United States, your next step will be to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for U.S. residential aliens as for non-resident aliens.

Non-resident aliens may claim the same item deductions as resident aliens. However, non-resident aliens may only claim item deductions if they have income actually related to their professional or commercial activity in the United States. There may be limitations on the amount of item deductions you can claim in Schedule A. See the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) "Item Deductions" in the instructions for Form 1040-NR.

You can claim the same item-by-item deductions as U.S. citizens using Schedule A (Form 1040). See the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not specify your deductions item-by-item, you can claim the standard deduction for your specific filing status. See the instructions for Form 1040 for more information.

You can deduct certain itemized deductions if you earn income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States. As a rule, you can only include deductions and/or losses that are properly allocated and proportionate to the income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States.

Non-resident foreigners cannot claim the standard deduction. However, there is a special rule for certain foreigners from India who are temporarily residing in the United States, as described below:11
These losses are not subject to the limitations that apply to personal property. Use Section B of Form 4684 to calculate your deduction for these losses.

Special rules apply to students and business interns who are eligible for benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement. You can claim a standard deduction provided you do not claim item-by-item deductions. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. If you are married and your spouse files a tax return and states item-by-item deductions, you cannot use the standard deduction.

If you are a student or business intern eligible for relief under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement who has been affected by certain major federal disasters in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters), you may elect to increase your standard deduction for any qualifying personal disaster losses on your 2024 tax return.

You can deduct state and local income tax that you paid on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Your deduction is limited to $10,000 ($5,000 for married individuals filing separately). If you received a refund or overpayment refund on taxes paid in the previous year, do not deduct that amount. Instead, you must include the refund or overpayment refund in your income if you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax. For details on how to calculate the amount to include in your income, see the “Refunds” section in Publication #525.

You may, with some restrictions, deduct charitable donations or gifts to eligible organizations. Eligible organizations include religious, charitable, educational, scientific or literary organizations, and organizations working to prevent child or animal abuse. Some organizations that promote national or international amateur sports also meet the eligibility criteria. For more information on deducting charitable contributions, see the section "Gifts to U.S. Charities" in the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) "Artikelspecifieke aftrekposten" and in the instructions for Form 1040-NR.

Donations made directly to a foreign organization are not deductible. However, you may deduct contributions to a U.S. organization that transfers funds to a foreign charity if the U.S. organization controls the use of the funds, or if the foreign organization is merely an administrative unit of the U.S. organization. Under a number of double taxation agreements, you may be entitled to deduct contributions to a foreign charity. For more information, see Publication No. 526l.

You can deduct accident and theft losses on your tax return. You can deduct a non-commercial accident or theft loss only if it is caused by a federally defined natural disaster. If the accident or theft occurred to you as a result of a federally defined natural disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

For more information, see the instructions for line 7 in the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) “Item Deductions” in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. See also Publication No. 529, or the IRS’s website.

You may claim a credit, subject to certain limitations, for income tax you paid or were assessed in a foreign state on income from a foreign source. You cannot claim a credit for taxes paid or assessed on excluded foreign income. To claim a credit for income tax paid or assessed in a foreign state, you must usually complete Form 1116 together with Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication No. 514.
You may be eligible for this credit if you are 65 years of age or older, or if you have retired due to permanent or total disability. See Publication No. 524 and Appendix R (Form 1040) for details.

An adopted child is a child who has been legally adopted by a person. If a person does not have an SNN (or ITIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return date (including extensions), such person cannot claim a child tax credit and an additional child tax credit on the original 2024 tax return or on an amended tax return.

The Other Dependants Credit is for people who have dependents and who are not eligible for a child tax credit. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, an unincorporated resident or a resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued no later than the date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions).

To qualify for an EIC, you must have income from working for someone or running or owning a business or farm and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must either meet the additional rules for employees who do not have a qualifying child or have a child who meets all of the qualifying criteria for children. The EIC reduces the amount of tax you owe and can help you get your refund. For more information, visit IRS.gov/EIC. If you (or, in the case of joint tax returns, your spouse(s)) did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline or earlier (including renewals), you cannot claim an EIC on either your original return or your 2024 amended return. Furthermore, if the child did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 amended return or earlier (including renewals), you cannot count that child as a qualifying child in calculating the EIC on either your original return or your 2024 amended return. If your Social Security card has a “Not Eligible for Employment” label and the number was issued to enable you (or your spouse or qualifying child) to receive federal benefits, you cannot claim an EIC. An example of a federally funded benefit is Medicaid. If the card has this label and the person’s immigration status has changed to make them a U.S. citizen or a legal permanent resident, ask your IRS to refund the EIC.
Credits are only allowed if you earn income that is actually related to your business activity in the United States.

If you have income from a foreign source that is actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States, you may be entitled to a refund of any income tax paid or assessed in a foreign state or territory administered by the United States. You may not be credited for taxes levied by a foreign state or territory administered by the United States on your income from a U.S. source if those taxes were levied solely because you are a citizen or resident of a foreign state or territory.

You may be eligible for this credit if you pay someone to care for your qualifying dependent child under 13 years of age, or for your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. See Publication No. 503 for definitions of these terms. Married non-resident foreigners may only qualify for the credit if they elect to file a joint tax return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse as described in the section "How to make a choice" in Chapter 1, or if they are married and live separately (see the "Joint Tax Return Test" section in Publication No. 503).

An adopted child is a child legally adopted by a person. If you did not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit on either your original return or your amended return. If your child did not have a valid employment SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit for that child, but you can claim a credit for other dependents for that child. See the "Tax Credit Payable for Other Dependants" section discussed below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) to calculate the amounts of credits.

This is a non-refundable tax credit of $500 per eligible person. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, resident of an unincorporated territory (e.g., American Samoa) or a resident alien. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR. To qualify for the credit for other dependants, your dependent must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued no later than the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions).

If you are a non-resident foreigner for any part of the tax year, you are generally not eligible for an earned income credit (EIC). However, if you are married and choose to file jointly with a U.S. citizen spouse or a resident spouse as described in the "Non-resident spouse treated as a resident" section in Chapter 1, you may be eligible for an EIC. If you or your spouse did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return filing date (including extensions), you cannot count that child as qualifying for an EIC either on the original return or on the 2024 amendment return.

Any federal income tax withheld on your salary during the tax year when you were a non-resident alien is admissible as a payment against your U.S. income tax liability for that year. You may claim that the tax withheld during the year is used to pay your U.S. tax, whether you engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year and whether the salary (or any other income) was related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.u

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) of the additional Medicare tax on wages or railway pensions (RRTA) that exceed $200,000 in 2024. If you do not owe additional Medicare tax, you can claim a credit for any additional Medicare tax withheld against the total tax liability shown on your tax return by completing Form 8959.

You may use as a payment any tax withheld before payment on investments or on other fixed or determined annual or periodic income paid to you. Fixed or determined income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties that you do not actually refer to as related income.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign corporation that engages (or is considered to engage) in a professional or commercial activity in the United States and you dispose of that interest directly or indirectly for profit, for transfers after 2017, the recipient will generally withhold and pay to the IRS on your behalf tax equal to 10% of the amount realized on the sale. The rules for withholding and paying in excess of that amount are similar to those for the sale of U.S. real estate interests. You will receive a Form 8288-A reflecting the withheld amount, which you can then claim on line 25f of your Form 1040-NR as a deduction for the tax you owe on the profits. You can provide the recipient with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding. For example, if the Tax Code’s profit withholding provision applies to all of the profits earned on the transfer, the recipient may not have to withhold tax if you provide a notice stating that the profit withholding provision is applied. If you are the recipient and your tax has not been withheld, the corporation may withhold tax on the distribution of income. The U.S. Treasury Department decision (T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910/2020-51_IRS#TD-9926), published on November 30, 2020 (as amended in 86 FR 13191), contains final regulations (1446(f) regulations) for the withholding of income tax on the transfer.

If you are a non-resident alien who is a valid resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same way as resident aliens. You should file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and disclose information on all income from both U.S. and non-U.S. sources. However, you may exclude the income described in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income reporting, you will be treated as a non-resident alien. For example, you are not allowed a standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot disclose a dependent unless the person is a U.S. citizen or a resident of an unincorporated territory. There are also restrictions on what deductions and credits are allowed. See the “Non-resident aliens” subsection in the “Deductions” and “Artikel Deductions” sections, and also the “Tax Credits and Payments” section in this chapter.

If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year will be a calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a standard fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52-53 week year) and consider yourself a U.S. resident for any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of the fiscal year that falls into that calendar year.

A taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be provided on tax returns, returns and other tax documents. For an individual, it is a Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN and are not eligible for one, you must apply for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). An Employer Identification Number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in a profession or business as a sole proprietor and have employees or a qualifying pension plan. You must provide a taxpayer identification number (TIN) if you are... a foreign national whose income is directly related to a profession or business in the United States at any time during the year; a foreign national who has an office or place of business in the United States at any time during the year; a non-resident spouse considered a resident as discussed in Chapter 1; or any other foreign national who files a tax return, amendment tax return or tax refund claim (but not a disclosure return).

If you do not have a Social Security Number, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to find out if you are eligible. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 800-772-1213 (for deaf or hard of hearing, call TTY 800-325-0778).

If you have an F-1, M-1, or J-1 visa, see SSA Publication 05-10181, available at SSA.gov/Pubs/10181.html, for additional information on the documents you must provide to prove your immigration status.

If you have not used your ITIN on a federal tax return at least once for the 2021, 2022 or 2023 tax year, it will expire on December 31, 2024, and if you need to file a 2024 federal tax return, you will need to renew your ITIN. To update your ITIN, see the Form W-7 and its instructions at IRS.gov/FormW7. For more information, see the IRS.gov/ITIN section.

Your tax status is important in determining whether you can file for certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your filing status are different for resident and non-resident foreigners.

Non-resident foreigners married but not to U.S. citizens or residents should usually use the Married and Separately Filed Tax Calculator Worksheet when determining tax on income actually related to professional or commercial activities in the U.S.

Married non-resident foreigners are not generally eligible to use the Tax Grid or the Unmarried Tax Calculator. However, you may file as a single person if you have lived separately from your spouse for the past 6 months and you are a married resident of Canada, Mexico or South Korea or an uninclused resident of a married non-incorporated territory. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR to find out if you are eligible. The definition of an uninclused resident is given below in this section. A non-resident foreigner is generally not eligible to file a joint tax return. However, a non-resident foreigner married to a U.S. citizen or resident may choose to be a resident and file a joint tax return using Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For details on these options, see Chapter 1.

A non-resident foreigner's estate or trust using Form 1040-NR must use the Tax Rates Schedule W in the Form 1040-NR instructions when determining income tax on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

You must report on each item of income that is subject to taxation under the provisions of the law in chapters 2, 3, and 4. For foreign residents, this includes income from sources both in the United States and outside of the United States. For non-resident foreigners, this includes both income that is actually related to professional or commercial activity in the United States (taking into account differentiated tax rates) and income from sources in the United States that is not actually related (subject to a flat tax rate of 30% or a lower rate under a double taxation agreement).

You may claim deductions to calculate your taxable income directly related to your U.S. business activities (ECTI). As a general rule, you cannot claim deductions related to income not related to your U.S. business activities.

You can deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses related to a professional or business activity in the United States to the extent that they are related to income actually related to such activity. For information on other business expenses, see the Business Expense Resource Guide.

If you paid interest in 2024 on an approved education loan, you may deduct up to $2,500 from the interest you paid. Generally, you may claim the deduction if all requirements are met. The deduction is made on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Publication No. 970.

If you have income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying income from a qualifying professional or commercial activity, plus 20% of your qualifying dividends from a qualifying REIT and a qualifying PTP. For more information, see line 13a in the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information on the deduction from qualifying business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and their annexes, and the appropriate instructions for the forms and annexes.

If you were a qualifying educational worker in 2024, you can deduct as an income adjustment up to $300 in unrefundable qualifying expenses that you paid or incurred during 2024 for certain training courses, as well as for books and supplies (except for non-sports supplies for health or physical education courses), computer equipment (including related software and services) and other additional equipment and materials that you use in your education.

If you made contributions to a traditional IRA for 2024, you can report this deduction on your tax return. But to do so, you must have taxable compensation actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Form 5498 must be sent to you by June 2, 2025; it will list all contributions to your traditional IRA for 2024. If you were insured under a retirement plan (qualifying pension, profit-sharing (including 401(k)), annuity, SEP, SIMPLE, etc.), employment or self-employment, your IRA deduction may be reduced or cancelled. But you can still make contributions to a traditional IRA even if you cannot deduct them. If you made non-taxable contributions to a traditional IRA for 2024, you must report them on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication No. 590-A.

The deduction for relocation costs is only available if you are a U.S. military member on active duty and are relocating on military order due to a permanent change of duty location. For more information, see Publication No. 3. If you qualify, use Form 3903 to determine the amount of the deduction.

Do not include in income the cost of removal and storage services provided by the Government due to the relocation in accordance with the transfer to a new permanent duty station. Similarly, do not include in income amounts received as relocation allowances, temporary living expenses, temporary living allowances or tax credits for housing. For more information, see Publication No. 311.

You must include in your income all actual related interest income that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it by any penalty you are required to pay for early withdrawals from a savings account. However, if the interest income is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year, you may deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the early withdrawal penalty charged by the bank. Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you are a resident alien, your child or eligible relative may be a legal dependent. For a child to qualify, you must pass five tests. For a person to qualify as your eligible relative, you must pass four tests. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040. If you do not provide a dependent's SSN, ITIN or ATIN in the "Dependents" section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be available. See the "Identification Number" section above.

If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year is a calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52-53 week year) and are considered a U.S. resident for any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of your fiscal year that falls within that calendar year.

During the part of the year when you are a foreign resident, you are taxed on income from all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is taxed if you received it while you were a foreign resident. Income is taxed even if you earned it while you were a non-resident alien or if you became a non-resident alien after you received it and before the end of the year. During the part of the year when you are a foreign non-resident, you are taxed on income from sources in the United States and on certain income from foreign sources that is considered to be actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. The rules for treating income from foreign sources as actually related are discussed in the Foreign Income section in Chapter 4. Income from sources outside the United States that is not actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States is not taxed if you receive it while you are a non-resident alien. Income is not taxed even if you earned it while you were a non-resident alien or if you became a resident alien or a U.S. citizen after you received it and before the end of the year. Income from sources in the United States is taxed whether you receive it as a non-resident alien or a resident alien unless it is specifically exempt from tax under the Tax Code or a tax treaty provision. In general, the tax treaty provisions apply only to the part of the year in which you were a non-resident. However, in some cases, treaty provisions may apply when you were a resident alien. For more information, see Chapter 9.
You cannot use the standard deduction allowed on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. However, you can specify any allowable item-by-item deductions.
You cannot use the "Main breadwinner" column in the table or the worksheet for tax calculations.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you may list a dependent on your tax return. Typically, the dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. You may be eligible for additional deductions and credits if you have a qualifying dependent. For more information, see the Form 1040 instructions or the Form 1040-NR instructions. If you were a resident of an unincorporated territory or lived in Canada or Mexico, you may list a dependent under the same conditions as U.S. citizens. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see Chapter 5.

All income from your residence and all income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during your non-residence, after allowable deductions, is added and taxed at the rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents.

During the part of the year you are a non-resident alien, 85% of any U.S. Social Security payments (and equivalent part of Tier 1 railway pension payments) you receive are taxed at a flat rate of 30% unless you are exempt or subject to a lower treaty rate. (See "Tax at 30%" in Chapter 4.) During the part of the year you are a resident alien, the portion of the Social Security payments and equivalent part of Tier 1 railway pension payments will be taxed at differentiated rates if your adjusted gross income plus half of those payments exceeds a certain base amount. Use the Social Security Payments worksheet in the Form 1040 instructions to help you determine the taxable portion of your U.S. Social Security payments and equivalent Tier 1 railway pension payments for the part of the year you were a resident alien. If you received U.S. Social Security payments as a non-resident alien, the Social Security Administration (SSA) will send you Form SSA-1042S showing your total payments for the whole year and the amount of tax withheld. You will not receive separate reports of the payments received during your residency and non-residency. Therefore, it is important for you to keep a careful record of these amounts. This information is necessary to complete your return correctly and determine your tax liability.

As a dual-status alien, you can generally claim tax credits using the same rules that apply to resident aliens. There are certain restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are discussed here, along with a brief explanation of the credits that are often claimed by individuals. You cannot claim an educational tax credit, an earned income credit (EIC), or an elderly or disabled persons credit unless you are married and have chosen to be considered a U.S. resident for the duration of 2024 by filing a joint return with your spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident, as described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for this credit if you pay someone to care for your dependent child under 13 years of age or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse so that you can work or seek employment. Married foreigners with dual status may only qualify for the credit if they choose to file a joint return as described in Chapter 1, or if they qualify for a certain category of married and separated persons. The amount of care expenses for your child and dependants that qualify for the credit in any tax year cannot exceed your earned income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication No. 503 and Form 2441.

An adopted child is a child who has been legally adopted by a taxpayer. If you do not have a Social Security account number (or individual taxpayer identification number) issued at or before the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a tax credit for the child on the original 2024 tax return or any amendments. If your child did not have a Social Security account number valid for employment and issued before the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a tax credit for the child, but you can claim a tax credit for other dependents for that child. See the section "Tax credit payable for other dependents" below.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for eligible expenses for the adoption of a qualifying child. This amount may also be paid for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of eligible expenses. To receive this tax credit, file Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return.

If you are a taxpayer who renounces your status as a resident during the year and are not a resident on the last day of the year, you must file Form 1040-NR. Enter a "Dual-Status Return" at the top of the tax return. To report on your income during the year you were a resident, attach a statement to your tax return. You can use either Form 1040 or 1040-SR as a statement, where you must enter a "Dual-Status Statement" at the top of the form. If you renounced your citizenship or lost your status as a resident in 2024, you may need to file a renouncement statement (Form 8854) with your tax return. For more information, see the "Expatriation Tax" section in Chapter 4.

Any return must contain your name, address and taxpayer identification number (TIN). You do not have to sign a separate statement or an annex to the tax return because the signature on the tax return is valid for all attached statements and annex to the tax return.

If you file Form 4868 by the tax filing deadline, you will be eligible for an automatic extension of 6 months (up to October 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year). For more information, see Form 4868. If you file a tax return automatically extended by 6 months, your tax filing deadline does not extend. If you have not paid your tax by the original tax filing deadline, you will incur interest on the outstanding tax. Also, penalties may apply. If your company is located and your place of residence is outside the U.S. and Puerto Rico on April 15, your tax filing deadline is automatically extended to June 15. If you require more time at the end of the two-month period, you may obtain an additional extension of 4 months until October 15 if you file Form 4868 by June 15. In addition to the 6-month extension, non-US taxpayers (as defined in the Form 4868 instructions) may, at their discretion, request an additional 2-month extension of the tax filing deadline (up to December 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year). To request an additional extension of the deadline, you must send the IRS a letter explaining why you require the additional 2 months. The letter must be sent by the extension deadline (up to October 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year) to the address below. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-

You must also file a tax return if you want to... claim a refund of excessively withheld wages or overpaid taxes, or to apply for any tax deductions or credits. For example, if you do not have any economic activity in the United States, but you receive income from real estate that you claim as income from an activity in the United States (as described in Chapter 4), you must file a true and completed tax return on time to receive any authorized deductions on such income.

Even if you have left the U.S. and filed a Form 1040-C on departure, you are still required to file an annual U.S. income tax return. If you are married and both you and your spouse are required to file a tax return, each of you must file a separate return.

If a foreign person wholly owns a non-corporate entity located in the United States, such entity is considered a U.S. corporation separate from its owner (a foreign person) for the purposes of the requirements of Section 6038A, which apply to 25% of corporations located in the United States and owned by foreigners. A non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners must file the standard Form 1120 and Form 5472 in the appendix to the tax return before the filing deadline (including extensions). The Form 1120 only requires the name and address of the non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners, and must complete Sections B and E in the first part of the document. If a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners has been engaged in professional, commercial or other reportable activities in the United States, it may have been subject to the reporting requirement before 2017. For additional information and affiliation with Form 5472 to be filed by a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners, see the instructions for Form 5472. Also note: Since a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners is generally a tax-transparent entity, the foreign person must disclose (or will continue to disclose) on Form 1040-NR any information that is relevant to the entity.

If you are unable to file your tax return on time, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing methods listed in the Form 4868 instructions. Thus, for the 2024 calendar year, you will be able to extend your tax return deadline to October 15, 2025. If your tax return deadline is June 16, 2025, you will be able to extend your tax return deadline to December 15, 2025. You must file the tax return deadline extension form before the tax return deadline.

If your U.S. activity was restricted and you are satisfied that you did not earn any gross income from U.S. professional or commercial activities during the year, you may file a tax-free organization return (Form 1040-NR) by the deadline set out above. By filing this return, you protect your right to deductions and credits if it is later determined that some or all of your income is actually related to U.S. professional or commercial activities. You are not required to report any income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities or deductions on the tax-free organization return, but you must justify the need to file this return. If you believe that an activity has earned you income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities, you must file a tax return by the original deadline that reports such income and related deductions. To protect your right to deductions or credits for other activities, you must attach a statement to your tax return that requires you to explain that you want to protect your right to such deductions and credits if it is later determined that those activities have earned you income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities. If you believe that you are not tax-free from U.S. activities under a tax treaty, you may do the same. You must also complete box L of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR).

If you are a valid resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entirety of your tax year and work temporarily in the U.S., you must pay U.S. Virgin Islands income tax and file your income tax return at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802. Chapter 8 describes the withholding of taxes from U.S. piece wages paid to U.S. Virgin Islands residents.

If you are a valid resident of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) for the duration of your tax year, you must file a tax return and pay any taxes required by the laws of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands.

If you noticed changes in your income, deductions or tax credits after filing your tax return, you must file Form 1040-X. If you were supposed to file Form 1040-NR instead of Form 1040-SR, or vice versa, you must also use Form 1040-X. If you are amending a Form 1040-NR or filing a correct tax return, enter “Amended” at the top of the document and attach the amended tax return (Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-NR) to your Form 1040-X. As a general rule, you must file an amended tax return within 3 years of the tax filing date or within 2 years of the tax payment date, whichever is later.
FinCEN Form 105 is required under 31 U.S.C., Chapter 5316 and U.S. Treasury Department regulations (31 U.S.C., Chapter X).
The form is available at FinCEN.gov/resources/filing-information. For more information on the BSA E-Filing system, see the E-Filing section at BSAefiling.fincen.treas.gov/main.html.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of these assets exceeds a specified threshold (the “reporting threshold”). The reporting threshold depends on whether you are a resident of the United States, married, or filing a joint income tax return with your spouse. The specified foreign financial assets include any financial account maintained by a foreign financial institution. They also include any shares, securities or other interests held for investment purposes in a foreign organization, and any financial instrument or contract with a non-U.S. issuer or counterparty.

If you fail to file your tax return and pay the tax on time, you may be fined. You may also be fined if you substantially understate the tax amount, submit unfounded tax documents, and fail to provide your taxpayer identification number (TIN). If you have provided false information in your tax return, you may be fined for tax fraud.

If you fail to file your tax return by the deadline (including extensions), you will have to pay a non-filing penalty. The penalty is based on the taxes not paid by the deadline (excluding extensions).

If the item in your return is related to a tax haven, the tax reduction for adequate disclosure is not made. However, the tax reduction is made for the reference to an authoritative source, but only in the case where you reasonably believed that the tax accounting you used was correct.

In the event of a material understatement, only items that meet the requirements of Tax Procedure 2024-44, available at IRS.gov/irb/2023-51_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (or later) are considered adequately disclosed in your return. Tax Procedure 2024-44 does not take into account changes in tax laws that take effect in tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a line in a tax procedure affects changes and requires additional reporting, a taxpayer will be required to file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, “Disclosure Regulation Statement,” until regulations or other guidance are issued to reflect those changes. A complete and accurate disclosure of tax status in Schedule UTP (Form 1120) “Statement of Unspecified Tax Status” for the relevant year will be considered as a company’s filing of Form 8275 or Form 8275-R. However, filing Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be considered as a company’s filing of Schedule UTP (Form 1120). Use Form 8275-R to disclose items or tax items that conflict with regulatory requirements.

You will not have to pay a fine if you justify the way in which you have recorded a particular item (provide a valid reason). You must also prove that you have acted in good faith. This provision does not apply to transactions that do not make economic sense.

You may be fined if you make a wrong refund or credit request. The penalty is 20% of the amount of the request for which you were denied. However, the penalty will not be imposed if you prove that you had a good reason for making the request. However, any rejected requests for transactions that do not make economic sense will be considered as having no good reason. The penalty will not be imposed on any part of the amount of the rejected request if it is subject to a fine for tax fraud or for providing false information to the tax authorities.

If you file a false tax return or other false tax documents, you may be fined up to $5,000. A false tax return is a return that contains insufficient information to determine the correct tax amount or contains information that clearly shows that the tax amount stated is incorrect. For more information on false tax returns, false tax documents and a list of items designated as false, see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or later). You will be fined for filing such tax returns or tax documents due to your false position or to your desire to delay or impede the enforcement of federal tax laws. This includes altering or deleting pre-printed text above the field for your signature. This penalty is in addition to other penalties provided by law.
If there is a tax deduction on your tax return due to tax fraud, a penalty of 75% of the amount of the deduction will be added to your tax.

If you fail to provide your Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or SSN or another person's ITIN in the appropriate fields of a tax return, report or other document, you will be fined $50 per pass. You may also be fined $50 if you fail to provide your SNN or ITIN to another person if required to do so in a tax return, report or other document. For example, if you have a bank account on which interest is accrued, you must provide your SSN or ITIN to the bank.
If the reason for the non-submission of the tax return was tax fraud, the penalty is 15% for each full or incomplete month of delay in the filing of the tax return, but not more than 75%lite.

If you file your tax return more than 60 days after the tax return deadline or the tax return deadline with extension, you will be fined $510 or 100% of the amount of unpaid tax, whichever is the lesser.
you will not have to pay a fine if you prove that you failed to file your tax return on time for a valid reason and not because of intentional negligence l l

You will have to pay a penalty of ½ of 1% (0.005) of the amount of unpaid tax for each full or incomplete month after the tax deadline. This penalty does not apply during the automatic 6-month extension period if you have paid at least 90% of the actual amount of your tax liability until the tax deadline and pay the balance on filing. The monthly penalty rate for non-payment of tax is half the standard rate of 1/4% (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)) if there is an installment agreement in effect for that month. You must file your tax return on time (including extension periods) to qualify for the reduced penalty rate.

If both the default penalty and the non-payment penalty (see above) are applied in the same month, the default penalty of 5% (or 15%) is reduced by the amount of the non-payment penalty. However, if you file your tax return more than 60 days after the tax return deadline or the tax return deadline after extension, you will be fined $510 or 100% of the amount of the unpaid tax, whichever is the lesser.

The penalty is 20% of the amount of the tax debt. The penalty is 40% of any amount of the debt related to an undisclosed transaction that does not make economic sense or an undisclosed transaction with a foreign financial asset.

The term “negligenza” (neglect) includes situations where a person does not comply with tax laws or does not exercise reasonable care in preparing a tax return. “Negligenza” also includes improper accounting records. You will not have to pay a fine for negligence if you have a justification for your position. “Negligenza” (neglect) includes any careless, frivolous or deliberate negligence.

You can avoid a penalty for neglecting rules or regulations if you properly disclose a reason on your tax return that has at least a good cause. See the section "Disclosure Statement" below. This exception does not apply to tax return items related to tax havens. It also does not apply if you do not keep proper accounting records or if you do not properly justify the tax return item.
