You may be held criminally responsible (prosecuted) for the following acts... 1. tax evasion; 2. deliberate failure to file the required information, refusal to pay taxes due; 3. tax fraud and false statements; or 4. preparing and filing a false tax return.

This chapter discusses how to pay income tax as you earn or earn income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is paid from current income. There are two ways to pay taxes from current income. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer will probably withhold income tax from your salary. Tax may also be withheld from some other income, such as pensions, bonuses, commissions and gambling winnings. The withheld amount is paid to the U.S. Treasury on your behalf. 2.

If you are a non-resident alien, you must provide your employer with a Form 8233 or a Form W-8BEN to prove your foreign status. In addition, you must provide a Form W-4 to prove that your source of payment is subject to progressive withholding at the same rates as resident aliens or U.S. citizens. If you are a resident alien and receive income other than your salary (for example, dividends and royalties), the taxpayer will generally have to file a Form W-9 or a similar statement with the tax agent so that he or she does not withhold income tax at the 30% rate (or a lower treaty rate).

The following withholdings apply to non-resident aliens. Resident aliens are taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Wages and other monetary rewards for services performed as an employee are generally subject to progressive withholding at the same rates as resident aliens and U.S. residents. Thus, your refund, unless it is excluded by law from the notion of "wages" or exempt from tax by a treaty, is subject to progressive withholding.

If you are an employee and receive a salary subject to progressive withholding, you must complete a Form W-4. Also complete a Form W-4 for a scholarship if it is a payment for past, present or future services for which you do not claim an exemption from withholding under Form 8233 (see below, "Income Eligible for Treaty Benefits").
If you are eligible for the benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement, you may be entitled to an additional withholding tax in addition to the standard deduction.

If you are a household employee, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, you may voluntarily withhold income tax by filing a Form W-4 with your employer. The agreement takes effect when your employer accepts it and begins to withhold income tax. To terminate the agreement, you or your employer must notify the third party of this decision in writing.

As a rule, wages exempt from U.S. income tax under a double taxation treaty are not subject to withholding tax. For information on how to obtain this exemption, see the section "Eligible Income under Tax Treaties" below. Wages paid to foreigners who are residents of American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin Islands may be exempt from withholding tax. The following paragraphs explain these exemptions.

If you are a non-resident foreign worker who is a resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico, salary for services rendered in American Samoa or Puerto Rico is generally not subject to withholding unless you are an employee of the United States or any of its agencies in American Samoa or Puerto Rico.

Income earned by non-resident aliens who are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands while working in the United States is not subject to withholding tax, because such persons pay income tax in the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid withholding tax on income earned in the United States, genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands must write a letter in two copies to their employers stating that they are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands and expect to pay tax on all income in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive pension payments in the United States, they are usually taxed at a rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate). However, you may withhold progressive rates of tax on the portion of your pension that you began to receive after 1986 for services rendered in the United States. To do so, you must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and submit it to the tax agent or payer before the income is paid or accrued to you.

Tips you receive during a year for services rendered in the United States are subject to income tax and must be included in your taxable income. In addition, tips received while working for a single employer and amounting to $20 or more per monthluu are subject to progressive withholding tax.

If you and the person you provide services to do not qualify as an employee and an employer, respectively, your refund is subject to a 30% (or lower contractual rate) withholding tax. However, if you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the tax year, your refund for personal services as an independent contractor (independent contractor services) may be exempt from all or part of the withholding tax if you agree with the IRS on the amount of the required withholding tax. The agreement between you and the IRS regarding the amount of the withholding tax from your refund for personal services as an independent contractor is effective once all parties have agreed upon it. You must agree to file your income tax return for the current tax year on time.

If you are a non-resident foreign artist or non-resident athlete performing or participating in sports events in the United States, you may enter into a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA) with the IRS, provided that certain requirements are met. This agreement will under no circumstances reduce your withholding tax to less than the estimated amount of tax payable. Use Form 13930 to file a CWA for a non-resident artist or non-resident athlete whose gross income in the U.S. for the calendar year was at least $10,000. Form 13930 can be faxed to 866-715-1507 or mailed to the address below. Central Withholding Agreement Program Internal Revenue Service 25520 Commercentre Dr. Lake Forest, CA 92630-8884 We have temporarily waived the income requirement for which form to use to file for a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA). Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. While the waiver is in effect, individuals with income below $10,000 may file for a CWA using Form 13930, “Instructions for Filing a Central Withholding Agreement.” For more information on how to file for a CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, see IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements. A request for a CWA must be received by the IRS at least 45 days before the effective date of the agreement, so that the tour or first performance in the United States is scheduled to begin.

If the information provided is eligible, the IRS will determine the amount of your preliminary income tax for the tax year on gross income actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. Ordinary and necessary expenses related to the conduct of a business activity may be considered if they meet the requirements of the IRS Commissioner or his/her agent. The Commissioner or his/her agent will send you a letter addressed to the tax agent. This letter will indicate the exempted amount of the final compensation payment and the amount you are eligible to receive as a result of the exemption. You must give two copies of the letter to the tax agent and attach one copy to your income tax return for the tax year for which the exemption applies. For more information, see Publication No. 515.

If you are a network company distributor and have been affected by an erroneous withholding tax, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F) or, if you have already filed one, a refund claim (Form 1040-X or a supplemented Form 1120-F) to refund the amount of tax withheld in error. In addition, you must attach additional information to your U.S. income tax return or refund claim, including but not limited to the following documents: A copy of your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 to confirm the amount of tax withheld. A statement explaining why the income stated on your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 is not taxable in the U.S. A statement listing all of your dates of entry and exit from the U.S. during the tax year. If compensation is paid over several years, the claim must include all of your dates of entry and exit from the U.S. for each tax year covered by the compensation. Copies of any documents or records indicating the number of days you were in the U.S. in each tax year. A statement containing (a) the number of days (or a smaller unit of time if necessary) you provided individual services in the U.S. related to the recruitment, training and support of your lower-level distributors; and (b) the total number of days (or a smaller unit of time if necessary) you provided individual services regardless of location related to the recruitment, training and support of your lower-level distributors.

For U.S. income tax purposes, green card holders remain resident aliens until their status as legal permanent resident is revoked under immigration laws or by administrative or judicial action. See the Green Card Test section in Chapter 1. If you are a green card holder and your social security payments have been erroneously withheld tax because you have a foreign address, the IRS will refund the withheld tax. To claim a tax refund, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. To determine whether you are eligible for a tax refund, send your return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301 In addition, you must attach the following documents to your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. A copy of Form SSA-1042S "Social Security Payments Claim". A copy of your green card. A signed declaration stating: "The U.S. Social Security Administration (SSA) has erroneously withheld income tax on social security payments because I am a legal permanent resident of the United States and my green card has not been cancelled. It has not been terminated by administrative or judicial action. I am filing my U.S. income tax return for the tax year as a resident alien and I report all my income regardless of where I am. I have not claimed benefits for the tax year as a resident of the country, and I have not received any benefits from the U.S. government.

Other income subject to a 30 per cent (or a lower treaty rate) withholding tax is usually fixed or determined income, such as interest (other than on an investment portfolio), dividends, pensions and annuities, as well as income from certain sales and exchange transactions described in chapter 4.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign corporation, the corporation will withhold tax on your share of the directly related taxable income (ECTI). The corporation in which you are a member may reduce the withholding tax rate on your share of the directly related taxable income by offering certain deductions at the partner level.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign partnership that carries on (or has the status of) a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and sells your share directly or indirectly in exchange for profits, the recipient of the share transferred after 2017 will generally withhold and pay tax to the IRS on your behalf at a rate of 10% of the amount realized. The rules for withholding and paying this amount are similar to those for selling a real estate share in the U.S. You will be sent Form 8288-A, which will indicate the amount withheld. You can then request a refund of this amount on line 25f of Form 1040-NR as a tax credit on your gains. You can provide the recipient with certain information to reduce the amount withheld or to completely cancel the withholding. For example, if the Tax Code non-recognition provision applies to all the gains received on the share transfer, the recipient does not have to withhold tax if you provide a notice describing the application of the non-recognition provision. If you are a recipient who did not withhold tax, then under Section 1446(f)(4), the partnership is required to withhold tax on your income distribution equal to the amount you did not withhold (plus interest, if applicable). On November 30, 2020, the Department of the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service approved final regulations by issuing a decision of the Treasury (T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910)) for the transfer of both shares in a non-PTP partnership (see above) and a PTP partnership under Section 14.

If you are a student or fellow with a non-resident foreigner status and hold an F, J, M or Q visa, and you receive a U.S. grant or scholarship that is not fully exempt from tax, the tax agent (usually the payer of the grant) will withhold tax at a rate of 14% (or the lower treaty rate) on the taxable part of the grant or scholarship that is not a fee for services. However, if you are not a fellow and the grant does not meet certain requirements, tax will be withheld at a rate of 30% (or the lower treaty rate).

Your tax agent may choose an alternative withholding tax procedure by asking you to complete a Form W-4. The following items can reduce the amount of tax withheld: a) the amount of the tax withheld; b) the amount of the tax withheld; c) the amount of the tax withheld; d) the amount of the tax withheld.
Include the expenses that will be deducted on your return. These include the deduction for the individual pension account described in the section "Deductions" in Chapter 5.

If you are filing a Form W-4 to reduce the amount of tax withheld from your scholarship or grant or to completely cancel the tax withholding, you must file an annual income tax return to qualify for any deductions requested on that form. If you have been in the United States for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to your annual Form W-4 that you have filed an income tax return for the previous year. If you have not been in the United States for a sufficient amount of time to be required to file a return, you must attach a statement to your Form W-4 that you are willing to file a tax return when required.

If you provide individual services as an employee or independent contractor and are eligible for exemption from withholding tax on income from the provision of individual services under a double taxation agreement, provide Form 8233 to each tax agent from whom you receive the amounts. Even if you file Form 8233, the tax agent may be required to withhold tax on your income. This is because the factors on which the exemption from taxation under the double taxation agreement is based can only be determined after the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to return the excess tax withheld and provide the IRS with proof that you are eligible for exemption from taxation under the double taxation agreement.

If the required agreement is not listed in the annexes, you must attach a statement in a format similar to that for other agreements. If you have received a student or graduate scholarship and income from the provision of individual services from the same tax agent, use Form 8233 to claim a double taxation agreement exemption for both types of income.

A full 30% withholding tax is required on payments to a non-resident alien or foreign company for income from ticket sales (including television and other) for music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment or sports events, unless the tax agent has been specifically informed otherwise in a letter from the IRS. Depending on the calendar year in which the gross income was received, Form 13930 may be used to request a reduction in the amount of the withholding tax. Withholding tax may be required even if income is not taxable under the provisions of a double taxation agreement. One reason is that partial or full exemption is usually based on factors that can only be determined after the end of the tax year. We have temporarily waived the income requirement for which form to use when filing a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA). Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. While the waiver is in effect, individuals with income below $10,000 may file for a Central Withholding Agreement using Form 13930, “Instructions for Filing a Central Withholding Agreement.” For more information on how to file for a Central Withholding Agreement, see Form 13930. For more information, see IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements. You must pay tax on your departure from the United States on any income for which you have incorrectly claimed a double taxation agreement exemption.

The buyer shall not consider the certificates in paragraphs (3) and (4) if the buyer or a qualified substitute of the buyer has the factual knowledge or has been notified by an agent of the seller or the buyer (or his substitute) that they are false; this also applies to a declaration by a qualified substitute under paragraph (4).

The buyer must file and pay the withholding tax within 20 days of the transfer using Forms 8288. This form must be filed with the IRS together with copies A and B of Form 8288-A. Copy B of this return will be stamped, sent to the IRS and returned to you (the seller) if the return is complete and contains your taxpayer identification number (TIN).
Refunds of withholding tax on Form 1042-S, Form 8288-A or Form 8805 may require additional time to process.

If you are employed in the United States, in most cases you are required to pay taxes to the Social Security Funds and Medicare. By paying these taxes, you contribute to your coverage under the U.S. Social Security System. Coverage includes pension, survivor and disability benefits, and Medicare payments to persons who qualify. In most cases, the first $168,600 of taxable wages received in 2024 for services provided in the United States are subject to Social Security tax. All taxable wages are subject to Medicare tax. Your employer deducts these taxes from each payroll payment. Your employer is required to deduct these taxes on your income tax return if you have multiple employers and the amount withheld from your total 2024 wages exceeds $10,453.20. If one of your employers has made a deduction of more than $10,453.20, you are not eligible for a tax credit for that amount. Contact your employer to request a refund of the excess tax. If your employer does not refund the excess tax, you can file a refund using Form 843. Generally, U.S. Social Security and Medicare taxes apply to wages paid for services provided as an employed person in the United States, regardless of your nationality.

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) of the additional Medicare tax on the wages or RRTA compensation that it pays you in excess of $200,000 per calendar year. If you plan to file jointly and assume that your and your spouse's individual wages do not exceed $200,000, but your combined wages and self-employment income exceed $250,000, you may request an additional W-4 withholding and/or make estimated tax payments. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay additional Medicare tax if the total of your wages and self-employment income exceeded $125,000 if you are married (you checked the "Married filing separately" box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR), or $200,000 if you are a Single or Qualifying surviving spouse (you checked the "Single" or "Qualifying surviving spouse" box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR).

Generally, services performed by you as a non-resident alien temporarily in the United States as a non-immigrant under section 101(a)(15) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are not covered by social security if the services are performed for the purpose for which you were admitted to the United States. This means that no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be deducted from the wages you receive for those services. These types of services are very limited and usually include only campus work, practical training and hardship work.

If you are a non-resident foreigner temporarily admitted to the United States as a student, you are generally not allowed to work for a salary or to do business while you are in the United States. In some cases, a student admitted to the United States on an F-1, M-1, or J-1 visa is granted a work permit. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from the student's wages for work if the student is not considered a resident foreigner. Any student who regularly attends classes may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes for services performed for the institution. The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service (USCIS) allows campus work for F-1 students if the work is not claimed by a U.S. resident.

If you have received a Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly from your salary, you can claim a credit for it against the total tax liability on your tax return by filing Form 8959 with Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR. If you have received a Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly in a previous year for which you have already filed Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR, you must file Form 1040-X for the previous year in which you originally received your salary or compensation to claim the Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly withheld. See Form 1040-X instructions.

Self-employment tax is the tax to the Social Security Fund and the Medicare Fund for individuals who are self-employed. Non-resident foreigners are not subject to self-employment tax unless an applicable international social security agreement states that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) or American Samoa are considered U.S. residents for this purpose and are subject to self-employment tax.
To report and calculate self-employment tax, use Schedule SE (Form 1040). Then enter the tax amount in Schedule 2 (Form 1040), line 4. Attach Schedule SE (Form 1040) to Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-NR.

If you have both wages and self-employment income, the threshold for the self-employment additional Medicare tax is reduced (but not reduced to zero) by the amount of wages subject to the Medicare additional tax. Losses from self-employment are not considered for this tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay Medicare additional tax if the total of your wages and self-employment income exceeded $125,000 if you are married (you checked the “Married filing separately” box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR), or $200,000 if you are a Single or Qualifying surviving spouse (you checked the “Single” or “Qualifying surviving spouse” box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR).
If you are required to pay self-employment tax, you can deduct part of the self-employment tax paid when calculating your adjusted gross income.

The United States has entered into social security agreements, commonly referred to as “totalization agreements,” with foreign countries to coordinate the social security coverage and taxation of workers who are employed in part or in full time in one country. Under these agreements, double coverage and double contributions (taxes) for the same work are excluded.

Generally, under these agreements, you pay social security taxes only in the country where you work. However, if you are posted to the same employer in the United States and your salary is normally subject to social security taxes in both countries, most agreements provide that you are only covered by the social security system of the country from which you are posted. To confirm that your salary is subject only to foreign social security taxes and is exempt from U.S. social security taxes (including Medicare tax) under the agreement, you or your employer must request a coverage certificate from the appropriate tax office in the foreign country. This is usually the same office to which you or your employer pay foreign social security taxes. The foreign office will be able to tell you what information is required to issue the certificate. Your employer should keep a copy of the certificate as it may be needed to confirm that you are exempt from U.S. social security taxes. Only wages paid on or after the effective date of the agreement can be exempt from U.S. social security taxes.

Under most treaties, self-employed citizens are covered by the social security system of the country in which they reside. However, under some treaties, you may be exempt from U.S. self-employment tax if you temporarily transfer your business to or from the U.S. If you believe your self-employment income is subject only to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from foreign social security tax, request a coverage certificate from the U.S. Social Security Administration. Please follow the link in the Note above. This certificate will confirm your exemption from foreign social security tax. To confirm that your self-employment income is subject only to foreign social security tax and is not subject to U.S. self-employment tax, request a coverage certificate from the relevant foreign agency.

If your adjusted gross income for 2024 was more than $150,000 ($75,000 if your 2025 tax status is married and filing separately), replace 110% (1.10) with 100% (1.00) in paragraph (2) above if you are not a farmer or fisherman. Paragraph (2) does not apply if you have not filed a 2024 return. A non-resident alien must use Form 1040-ES (NR) to calculate and pay the assessed tax. If you pay by cheque, write it out to the United States Treasury.

If you filed your 2024 return on Form 1040-NR and you believe your income and total deductions in 2025 will be about the same, you should use the 2024 return as a guide to completing the Estimated Tax Worksheet in the Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions. If you have not filed your 2024 return, or if your income, deductions, or credits in 2025 will be different, you should calculate those amounts. Calculate your estimated tax liability using the tax rate table for your tax status in the Form 1040-ES (NR) 2025 instructions.

Even if you are not required to make a deduction in April or June, your circumstances may change so that you will have to make a deduction later. This may happen if you have additional income or if any of your deductions are reduced or cancelled. In this case, see the Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions and Publication No. 505 for information on how to calculate a deduction.
You will be fined for not paying the deductible tax, except in certain situations.

Extended Natural Disaster Benefit. The Federal Natural Disaster Benefit Act of 2023 extends the special rules and procedures for compensation for losses incurred as a result of certain major natural disasters declared at the federal level between February 26, 2021 and February 10, 2025.

The Disaster Tax Protection Act 2019 and the Disaster Tax Protection Act 2020 have expanded the special filing rules and procedures for claiming eligible personal accident losses related to certain federally declared disasters in 2018, 2019 and 2020. Eligible accident losses incurred in these tax years can be filed on Form 4684. For more information, see the "Qualifying Disaster Loss" subsection below. Previous versions of Form 4684 can be obtained by clicking on IRS.gov/Form1040X. You may need to file an amended Form 1040-X to claim these benefits on your 2018, 2019 and/or 2020 returns. See the "How to Report a Loss on Form 1040-X" subsection below. Accident and Theft Limitations. If you are an individual, accident losses or theft of personal property not related to a professional or commercial activity or transaction for profit are deductible in 2018-2025, but only if the loss is a result of a natural disaster.

This publication explains the taxation of accidents, thefts and losses of deposits. In an accident, a person’s property is damaged as a result of natural disasters such as hurricanes, fires, car accidents and the like. In a theft, a third party unlawfully appropriates the property of a person. In a loss of deposits, the financial institution in which the person’s deposits are held becomes insolvent or declares bankruptcy. This publication raises the following issues: Definition of accident, theft and loss of deposits. Methods of determining a person’s profit or loss. How to use insurance and other forms of compensation for losses. Limitations on deductions. When and how to report an accident or theft. Special rules for losses in a disaster zone.

Publication No. 584 “Worksheet on Accident, Natural Disaster and Theft (Personal Property)” will help you to list stolen or damaged personal property and determine the amount of the loss. It includes annex documents to determine the amount of damage to the home, its interiors and motor vehicles. Publication No. 584-B “Worksheet on Accident, Natural Disaster and Theft in Business” will help you to list stolen or damaged business or income-generating property and determine the amount of the loss.

All three types of loss are related to federally declared disasters, but the requirements for each are different. A federally declared disaster is a reason given by the President of the United States for the provision of federal government assistance under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a declaration of a major natural disaster or (b) a declaration of an emergency under the Stafford Act.

If you suffered an accident or theft of personal property not related to a federally declared disaster, the loss is not a federal accident loss and you are not eligible for a deduction for it, except in special cases.

A natural disaster loss is a loss related to a federally declared natural disaster and incurred in an area eligible for assistance under a presidential declaration. The natural disaster loss must be incurred in a district eligible for state or individual assistance (or both).

Eligible disaster loss includes personal accident and theft of personal property that is related to: a major disaster declared by the President in 2016 under section 401 of the Robert T. Stafford Act; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Cyclone Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; the 2017 and January 2018 California wildfires; a major disaster declared by the President in 2018 under section 401 of the Robert T. Stafford Act that occurred before December 21, 2019 and continued until January 19, 2020 (including); and a major disaster declared by the President between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025 (including).

Accidental damage is not deductible, even if it does not exceed the individual's personal profit from the accident, if the loss or destruction is caused by: Accidental breaking of objects such as glassware or porcelain. Pets (see explanation below). Fire if the individual deliberately caused it or paid a third party to cause it.

If you choose not to do so, you are subject to all the provisions applicable to accidental losses. So you must complete lines 1-9 as per the instructions on Form 4684. For example, this may mean that you must prove that the damage, destruction or loss of property occurred as a result of an identifiable event defined in the section "Accident".

If the amount on line 8 is less than or equal to the amount on line 3, you cannot claim an accidental loss deduction using this provision. If you have filed a claim (or you intend to file a claim) and it is pending, you may receive an income or additional deduction in the following tax year depending on the actual amount of the claim received.
The way in which profits and losses are reported depends on whether the property was commercial, generating income or used for personal purposes.
Use Form 4684 to file your profit and loss statement. You will also need to file your profit and loss statement on other forms, as explained below.

Individuals report losses on income-producing property in Schedule A (Form 1040). Gains on business and income-producing property are added to losses on business property, and the net gain or loss is reported on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, enter the net gain or loss on your tax return only on the line specified on Form 4797 (for those filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this will be Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 4).

If your losses on business and income-producing property exceed the profits on those types of property, combine your losses on business and income-producing property with the total profits on business and income-producing property. Report the net profit or loss as ordinary profit or loss on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, enter the net profit or loss on your tax return only on the line for Form 4797 (for those filing Form 1040, this will be Schedule 1 (Form 1040), Line 4).

If the damaged or stolen property was depreciable property that you owned for more than 1 year, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income within the limits of permitted or allowed depreciation. You calculate this ordinary income in Part III of Form 4797. See the “Depreciation Recapture” section in Chapter 3 of Publication No. 544 for more information on the repayment rule.
If you have suffered an accident or theft, you must deduct the amount of the damage you have suffered. The result is the adjusted cost of ownership.

If the deduction for accident or theft results in a year's deductions that exceed your year's income, you may have a net operating loss (NOL). Generally, you can use the NOL to reduce your tax in subsequent years. You do not have to be a business person to be eligible for an accident or theft NOL. See the instructions for Form 172 for more information.

Once you have all your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or digitally) or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G); interest, dividend and pension statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have several options for preparing and filing your tax return.
To complete the mobile-friendly forms, you must have an IRS account. You can file the form(s) online or download and print them to be sent by mail.

Go to IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account information. View amounts due and breakdowns by tax year. View payment agreement details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment, view 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments. Get online access to your tax records, including key details from your latest return, economic consequences payments and statements. View electronic copies of some IRS notifications. Approve or reject an authorization request from a tax professional. Update your address or choose how you want to receive notifications.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process. You can get a statement, view your last filed tax return and update your adjusted gross income.
This tool allows your tax professional to apply for authorization to access your individual online account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The quickest and easiest way to get your tax refund is to file online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account. A direct deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS.

The following are options for preparing and filing your return online or at your home if you are eligible. Direct File. Direct File is a finally approved software that allows you to file federal individual tax returns online for free and securely. Direct File is suitable for taxpayers from partner states who file relatively simple tax returns that include certain types of income and certain credits and deductions. While you cannot file a state return using Direct File if you live in a partner state, the system will redirect you to state-approved tax software for free state return filing. For more information, updates and answers to frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile Free File Free File System. This program allows you to prepare and file a federal individual income tax return for free using the software or the Free File fillable forms. However, state tax return filing may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to find out if you are eligible for free federal tax preparation online, electronic filing, direct contribution or payment options. VITA. The Income Tax Assistance Grant (VITA) program offers free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income individuals, disabled individuals and taxpayers with limited English language skills who need assistance preparing their tax return. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app, or call 800-906-9887 for information on free tax return filing. TCE. Tax Advice for Seniors
For returns in which an earned income credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC) is claimed, the IRS may not issue a refund before mid-February.

IRS Direct Payment: Pay your individual tax bill or deferred tax payment directly from your deferred or savings account at no cost to you. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment system for online or telephone payments. Electronic Federal Tax Payment: Best for business. Registration required. Check or money transfer: Send your payment by mail to the address provided in the notification or instructions. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at any participating store. Same-day delivery: You can also make a same-day transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to find out about the availability, cost and timing of the service.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on the options available. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations through monthly payments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today.
Go to IRS.gov/Notices for more information on how to respond to an IRS notice or letter.

You can use the LEP (Form 1040) Request for Change of Preferred Language to state your preference to receive IRS notices, letters and other correspondence in a language other than English. You may not immediately receive correspondence in the language you request.

TAS will help you solve problems that you haven't been able to solve yourself. If you have problems after contacting the IRS, always try to solve them. If you haven't, contact us. Our services are free.

If you are a sole trader or your company is registered as a partnership or S-Corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount
Go to IRS.gov/SocialMedia to learn about the various social media tools that the IRS uses to share the latest information about tax changes, fraud warnings, initiatives, products and services.

Losses due to depreciation of shares acquired in the investment stock market cannot be deducted from taxes as losses from theft if the depreciation occurred as a result of financial fraud or other unlawful actions by employees or directors of the corporation that issued the shares; however, if the shares were sold, exchanged or lost their value completely, such losses may be deducted as losses from depreciation of assets in Annex D (Form 1040).

The simple loss of money or property is not theft. However, if the property was accidentally lost or missing as a result of a certain unexpected, unforeseen or unusual event, then such loss may be considered an accidental loss. u u Unexpected, unforeseen and unusual events are defined above under the heading “Accident”.

If you are eligible for Tax Procedure 2009-20 as amended by Tax Procedure 2011-58, and you choose to follow the procedures described in the guide, you will first need to complete Section C of Form 4684 to determine the amount to be entered in Line 28 of Section B. Skip lines 19-27 and complete lines 29-39 in Section B if necessary.

You may not declare any other deductions, including the deduction for losses from ordinary deposit operations in an insolvent financial institution or in a financial institution that has declared bankruptcy.

You can deduct a loss of deposits as an accidental loss for any year for which you can objectively calculate the amount of deposits lost due to the insolvency or bankruptcy of the financial institution.

If you are an individual, accidental losses to personal property are deductible only if such losses can be attributed to a federally declared natural disaster. The exception to the rule limiting the deduction of accidental losses and thefts to federally declared natural disasters applies when you have accidental gains.

If you received a refund of a loss tax deduction in the previous year, you may need to include the amount in your income for the year in which you received the refund. If your tax was not reduced in the previous year due to the initial deduction, you do not need to include the amount in your income.

For accidental losses, you must provide the following documentary evidence: proof that you owned the property or rented it from another person and fulfilled the terms of the rental agreement in case of damage to the rented property; type of accident (road accident, fire, extreme weather conditions, etc.) and date of the accident; proof that the loss was incurred directly as a result of the accident; existence of a claim for damages under which you can expect payment of the compensation amount.
To prove your tax deduction entitlement, you must provide the required reports. If you do not have these documents, you can provide other evidence.

If your property is insured, you should file a claim with your insurance company in time. If you have not filed a claim, you will not be able to deduct all of the unpaid amount as accident or theft loss. Only the part of the loss that is not covered by your insurance policy can be deducted. Part of the damage that is not normally covered by insurance (for example, the amount for which you are responsible and not the insurance (deductible)) is not covered by this rule.
The most common form of compensation is an insurance payment for stolen or damaged property. Other forms of compensation are discussed below. See also the instructions for Form 4684.

If you receive money from your employer's disaster fund and you need to use that money to restore or replace property for which you are claiming an accidental loss deduction, you must take into account the amount of the payment when calculating the accidental loss deduction.

If you receive eligible cash gifts as a victim of a natural disaster, and there are no limits on how you can use the money, you will not reduce your accidental losses from these non-income cash gifts. This applies even if you use the money to pay for repairs to property damaged as a result of a natural disaster.

You do not reduce your accident losses by the insurance payments you receive to cover your living expenses in any of the following situations: you lose the use of your home due to an accident, the authorities have closed your main residence due to an accident or a threat of an accident, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster, u you have been forced to leave your home due to a disaster,

You include the taxable part of the insurance payment in the income for the year in which you resume the use of your main residence, or if the insurance payment is received later, for the year in which you receive the taxable part of the insurance payment.

Do not reduce your accidental losses against the credit used to repair or replace the property for which you are claiming an accidental loss deduction. If you have a federal credit that has been cancelled (forgiven), see the "Federal Credit Cancelled" subsection below in the "Disaster Area Losses" section.

If you calculated your accident or theft loss using the expected compensation amount, you may need to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you received the actual compensation. This section explains what changes you may need to make. If you paid an amount to repair damage to a residential home with a deteriorating concrete foundation and declared a deduction on your original or amended tax return, and you (or contractors on your behalf) received payments from the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you must include some of the payments in your gross income. See Notice 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B. 796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5)._.

If you later receive a higher amount of refund than you expected after you filed the loss deduction, you may have to include the additional refund in your income for the year in which you received it. However, if any part of the initial deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, do not include that part of the refund in your income.
If you later receive exactly the refund you expected to receive, you do not have to include any refund in your income and you will not be able to deduct any additional losses.

There are two ways to claim a tax deduction for an increase in the value of goods sold in the inventory report at the beginning and end of the reporting period. The loss does not need to be re-reported as an accidental or theft loss. If you calculate the loss for an increase in the value of goods sold, you must include any insurance or other compensation you have received in your gross income.

If you are responsible for an accidental damage to the property you rent, the amount of damages is calculated as follows: the amount you have to pay for the repair of the property minus the amount received under insurance or other damages received or expected to be received.

If you have received a theft loss refund, you will need to recalculate the amount of the loss using the lesser of the two values: the original value of the property (see definition below) or the decrease in fair market value between the time immediately before the theft and the time of the return.

To calculate the fair market value reduction for accident or theft losses, you need to determine the correct amount. However, other methods can be used to determine some types of reduction. See the subsections "Assessing the amount", "Cleaning or repairing costs" and "Special procedure: safe harbor methods for calculating accident and theft losses" below.

The cost of repairing damaged property is not included in the accidental damages. The cost of cleaning the property after an accident is also not included in the accidental damages. However, the cost of cleaning or repairing after an accident can be used to determine the reduction in fair market value if you meet all of the following conditions: Repairs have been made. Repairs are necessary to restore the property to the condition in which it was before the accident. The amount spent on repairs is not exaggerated. Repairs have been made only in respect of damage caused. The value of the property after repairs does not exceed the value of the property before the accident because of the repairs made.

The cost of re-developing the property after an accident to restore it to its original condition may affect the fair market value. You can calculate the amount of damage by calculating the cost of the following procedures: Removal of destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs minus the value of any property saved. Pruning and other methods of rescuing damaged trees and shrubs. Replanting of vegetation required to restore the property to its approximate value before the accident.

You can use the retail price of the car as stated in the manual to calculate the value of the car. It should be adjusted for factors such as mileage and condition. This price is not officially set, but it can help you determine the value of the car and compare it to current car prices in your area. If your car is not in the manuals, determine its value using other sources. When a car dealer offers to trade in your car for a new car, it is usually not the true value of the car.

Losses determined using safe harbor methods must be reduced to the cost of any repair provided by a third party free of charge (e.g., work done by volunteers or through donations) to you. You must also reduce your loss by the amount of any insurance, reimbursement or other compensation you have received.

Include the specific safe harbor method used. When completing Form 4684, do not enter the amount on line 5 or line 6 for each property. Instead, enter the reduction in FMV determined by the appropriate safe harbor method on line 7. For damages from Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma and Hurricane Maria, see Tax Procedure 2018-09, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB#RP-2018-09, for information on the safe harbor method for cost indices.

Residential property for personal use is generally real estate, including improvements, owned by an individual who has suffered an accidental loss and comprising at least one residential property. This does not include personal housing if any part of it is used for rental or contains a home office used for trade, business or profit-making transactions. For more information, see Tax Procedure 2018-08. The following safe harbor methods are available in Tax Procedure 2018-08 for residential property for personal use. Estimated value of repairs. Minimum amount. Insurance. Contractor’s safe harbor. Estimated damage for credit in the event of a natural disaster.

If the loss was in a disaster area and caused by a federally declared natural disaster, you may use the EOD method or the Disaster Credit Assessment Method. Under the Contractor Safe Harbor Method, you may use the amount specified in a contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the reduction in the FMV of your personal residential property for repair.

Personal effects generally include tangible personal property belonging to a person who has been injured in an accident or theft, provided that it is not used in a trade or business. Personal effects do not include items that retain or increase in value over time, as well as certain other types of property.

The cost of protecting your property from accident or theft is not part of the accident or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or storm cover for your home is not part of your loss. If the property is a commercial property, these costs are deducted as a commercial expense. u If you are constantly improving your property to protect it from accident or theft, add the cost of these improvements to your main property. u An example is the cost of a dam to prevent floods.

You cannot increase your share of the property or deduct as business expenses any expenses you have incurred in respect of disaster mitigation payments (discussed further in the "Disaster Area Losses" section).

Contingencies related to an accident or theft, such as injury treatment, temporary accommodation or car rental, are not part of your accident or theft loss. However, they may be deducted as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is commercial property.

Photos taken after an accident will help determine the condition and value of the property after it has been repaired, restored or replaced. For information on appraisals, see the “Appraisal of the amount” subsection above, in the “Calculating the Fair Market Value of Property Items to be Recognized” section.

The amount of your investment in the property you own is its original value. For property you buy, your original value is usually the price at which it was acquired. For property you acquired in another way, such as by inheritance, by gift or in exchange for a tax-free amount, you must determine its original value differently, as explained in Publication No. 551.

If you inherited property from someone who died in 2010 and the beneficiary chose to use the original cost method under section 1022 of the IRS Revenue Code using Form 8939, "Assignment of the Increase in the Original Value of Property Acquired from the Deceased", then special rules apply to the original cost.

Once you have determined the amount of your accident or theft losses, you must determine how much of the loss you can deduct. The deduction for accident and theft losses of personal property is limited. During the tax years 2018 through 2025, individuals’ personal accident and theft losses are deductible only to the extent that they are related to a federally declared natural disaster. Personal accident and theft losses related to a federally declared natural disaster are governed by the $100 rule and the $10% rule, which will be discussed later. The $100 and $10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. There is an exception to the rule that allows accident and theft losses to be deducted only when they are related to a federally declared natural disaster. If you have accident profits, you can deduct accident losses not related to a federally declared natural disaster to the extent that they do not exceed the personal accident profits. Any excess profits are used to reduce losses from a federally declared natural disaster. The 10% rule applies to any remaining federal disaster losses. Losses to commercial property and income-generating property are not covered by these rules. However, if the accident or theft losses are related to a home that you used for business or rented, your deductible loss may be limited. See the Form 4684 instructions, section 10.

If you and your spouse have an accident or theft loss and filed separate returns, each of you must reduce your loss by $100. This is true even if you have a joint property. If one of you owns the property, only he or she can deduct half of the loss on the separate returns. Neither of you can deduct the entire loss on the separate return.
If your reported profits exceed your losses, deduct your losses from your profits. The difference is treated as a gain on the sale of capital assets and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040).

When calculating the loss of real estate that you own for personal use, all the landscaping objects (such as buildings and ornamental trees, as well as the land on which these objects are located) are considered together.

Personal property is any property that is not real property. If your personal property is stolen, damaged or destroyed in an accident, you must calculate the loss separately for each item of property. Then combine these individual losses to determine the total loss. Subtract the total loss by $100 and 10% of your adjusted gross income to calculate the loss deduction.

If the property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for commercial or income-generating purposes, the deduction for accidental or theft damages must be calculated separately for the part used for personal purposes and for the part used for commercial or income-generating purposes.
The amount you will receive includes any money plus the value of any property you have received less any costs incurred in obtaining the refund.

As a rule, you must report your profits as income for the year in which you receive the rebate. However, you are not required to report your profits if you have chosen to defer reporting on it in accordance with the rules explained below in the section “Deferring Profits”.

Do not report profits if you receive a refund in the form of property that is similar to or equal to the property that was destroyed or stolen. As a rule, you must report profits on the stolen or destroyed property if you have received money or other property as a refund. However, you may defer a report of profits if you acquire a controlling stake (at least 80%) in a corporation that owns property that is similar to or equal to the property.

In the case of accidents and thefts described in paragraph (3) above, profits may not be offset against losses in determining whether the total profits exceed $100,000. If the property is owned by a partnership, the limit of $100,000 applies to the partnership and each partner. If the property is owned by an S corporation, the limit of $100,000 applies to the S corporation and each shareholder.
This rule does not apply if the related person acquired the property from the unrelated person within the time allowed for the replacement of the destroyed or stolen property.

If a taxpayer dies after receiving the profit but before purchasing the replacement property, the profit must be reported in the accounts for the year in which the deceased realized the profit. The executor of the estate or the person who inherits the funds obtained as a result of an accident or theft cannot postpone the reporting of the profit by purchasing the replacement property.

You must purchase replacement property for the specific purpose of replacing the property that was destroyed or stolen. Property received as a gift or inheritance is not eligible. You are not required to use the same funds that you received as compensation for the old property to purchase the replacement property.

If you have paid in advance to a contractor to replace damaged or stolen property, you are deemed not to have acquired the replacement property unless it is completed by the end of the replacement period.

If your gains from the destruction of your main home exceed the amount you can exclude from your income (see the subsection "Main home destroyed" in the section "Calculate your gains") you can defer reporting of all the additional gains, the replacement property must be worth no less than the amount you received from the destruction, less the excluded gains.
You must deduct the original cost of the replacement property (the purchase price) by the amount of the deferred profit.
Replacement equipment must be identical or similar to the equipment it replaces.

Timber on the ground (not land) purchased by you from the proceeds of selling timber that was felled as a result of an accident (e.g., a strong wind, an earthquake or a volcano eruption) is considered a replacement property.
If you are a user-owner, "analogous or similar" means that the replacement property must function in the same way as the property it replaces.

If your destroyed business or income-generating property was located in a federally declared disaster area, any tangible property you acquire for use in your business is considered to be similar to the destroyed property. Replacement property does not have to be located in a federally declared disaster area. For more information, see the "Disaster Area Losses" section below.
You can replace the property by acquiring a controlling stake in a corporation that owns property similar to or similar to your damaged, destroyed or stolen property.

In order to defer income reporting, you must purchase replacement property for a certain period of time. This is the replacement period. The replacement period begins on the date your property was damaged, destroyed or stolen. The replacement period usually ends 2 years after the end of the first tax year in which any of your income was realized, u sti.
The extension is usually limited to a period of no more than 1 year. A high market value or a shortage of replacement property is not a sufficient reason for an extension.

Your request should include a detailed description of the reasons for the extension. 2. A detailed description of the converted property. 3. The date of the conversion of the property. 4. The adjusted historical cost of the converted property. 5. The date(s) and amount(s) of the payments received.

You defer reporting of profits from accident or theft by reporting your choice on the tax return for the year in which you made the profits. You receive the profits in the year of receipt of insurance or other compensation that results in profits. If the stolen or destroyed property belongs to a partnership or corporation, only the partnership or corporation can decide to defer reporting of profits.

If you acquire replacement property before filing for the year in which you received the profit, your return must also contain details of all of the following: Replacement property. Deferred profit. Adjustment to historical cost reflecting deferred profit. Any profit that you report as income.

If you intend to acquire replacement property after filing the return for the year in which you made a profit, your return must also state that you have decided to replace the property within the required replacement period. Then you must attach another statement to your return for the year in which you acquired the replacement property. This statement must contain details of the replacement property. If you acquired part of the replacement property in one year and part in another, you must file a return for each year.

Once you have acquired a qualifying replacement property that you have designated as a replacement property in the statement attached to your tax return, you cannot subsequently replace it with another qualifying replacement property. This statement is true even if you acquire another property during the replacement period. However, if you find that the original replacement property was not a qualifying replacement property, you can (due a replacement period) replace it with a new qualifying replacement property.

You must file an amendment return (individuals use Form 1040-X) for the tax year in which the profit was made in one of the following situations. You do not acquire the replacement property during the required replacement period, subject to the extension. On this amended return, you must report the profits earned and pay any additional tax. You acquire the replacement property during the required replacement period, plus the extension, but at a price lower than the amount you received for the accident or theft. On this amended return, you must report the portion of the profits that cannot be deferred and pay the additional tax.

The income tax period ends 3 years after the date you notify the head of the IRS office in your place of residence of any of the following facts. You have replaced property. You do not intend to replace property. You have not replaced property within the replacement period.

If you receive an insurance or other compensation that exceeds the adjusted original value of the property that was destroyed or stolen, you are receiving a profit from the accident or theft. You must include this profit in your income in the year you receive the compensation, unless you choose to defer reporting profits as explained earlier.

As a rule, you can deduct accidental losses that are not recoverable only in the tax year in which the accident occurred. This statement is true even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until the following year. (However, see the section "Disaster Area Losses" below for exceptions.) You can deduct theft losses that are not recoverable only in the year in which you discovered that your property was stolen.

If you rent property from another person, you may deduct the loss on that property in the year in which your loss is determined. This is true even if the loss occurred or the debt was paid in another year. You are not entitled to the deduction until your lease debt is determined with sufficient accuracy. Your debt may be determined after a settlement, a court ruling or a waiver of the recovery action.

This section discusses the special rules that apply to losses related to federally declared disasters. It also provides information on when you can deduct losses, how to file for them, how to deal with a home in a disaster, and what time periods for paying taxes can be extended.

If the damaged or destroyed property was non-commercial property and you did not include your deductions in the original return, you must first determine whether the accidental loss deduction is beneficial to you.

You must keep documentation to support your loss deduction. You are not required to attach it to your amendment return. If your documentation has been destroyed or lost, you may need to recover it. Information on how to recover your records is available at IRS.gov.

If your tax preparation professional is unable to do so, you can obtain a copy by filing a Form 4506 with the IRS. A fee is charged for each requested return. However, if your main home, main place of business or tax records are in a federally declared disaster area, no fee will be charged.
If part of your federal disaster loan has been cancelled under the Stafford Act, this is considered a damages.

Do not include Staffordshire Aid grants in your income if the grant payments were made to help you cover essential expenses or serious needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation or funeral expenses.

A grant received by an enterprise under a governmental program to compensate enterprises for damage or destruction of property as a result of a natural disaster is not excluded from income under the general welfare exclusion, as a gift, as a related disaster payment (explained below) or as a contribution to capital.
You cannot claim a credit, deduction or increase in the original value of your property for any expenses already paid for by eligible forest fire payments.

Relevant disaster mitigation payments made under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (April 15, 2005) are not included in income. These are payments that you, as a property owner, receive to reduce the risk of damage to your property in the future. You cannot increase your original value in the property, nor can you get a deduction or credit for expenses incurred in connection with these payments.

In general, if you sell or otherwise transfer property, you must report the gain or loss for tax purposes. (You cannot deduct losses on personal property unless the loss is the result of an accident, as discussed above.)

The IRS can defer certain tax dates for taxpayers affected by a federally declared natural disaster. The IRS can defer the filing of income tax, excise tax and employer taxes, and contributions to a traditional IRA (individual retirement account) or a Roth IRA (individual retirement plan).

If you have already filed a previous year's return, you can file a disaster loss and reduce your income for that year by filing an amended return. Individuals file an amended return using Form 1040-X (see the "How to file a loss on Form 1040-X" subsection below). To choose this option, complete Part I of Section D of Form 4684 for 2023 and attach it to the 2023 original return or to the amended return that includes the disaster loss deduction. You must make the choice to deduct the loss in the previous year on the day 6 months after the deadline for filing the original return (excluding extensions) for the year of the disaster or earlier. For individuals paying taxes for a calendar year, the deadline for making a decision on the 2024 disaster loss on the 2023 original or amended return is October 15, 2025. For more information on how to report those losses on the 2023 original or amended return, see the instructions for Form 4684 for 2023. If you have filed a disaster loss deduction on your tax return for the year in which the disaster occurred and now choose to deduct that loss on your previous year's return, you must file an amended return to exclude the previously deducted loss on the date of filing (or earlier) of the original or amended return for the previous year that includes the disaster loss deduction.

Eligible disaster losses include accidental or theft of personal property related to: A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; The 2017 and January 2018 California Fires; A major disaster declared by the President between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025.
The Earned Income Credit (EIC) is a tax credit for working people whose earned income is less than $63,398.

No. You can qualify for an EIC without a qualifying child if you are at least 25 years old but not older than 65 years old and your earned income is less than $17,640 (or $24,210 for a married couple filing jointly).
If you qualify for an EIC, you can calculate the amount yourself or let the IRS do the calculation.
In addition, your adjusted gross income must be less than one of the above amounts that applies to your situation. For more information, see Rules 1 and 15.

Additional Medicaid Health Care Payments. For information on how Medicaid payments are considered in the context of the EIC, see the Earned Income section. Don't miss out on a state tax credit. Your adjusted gross income must be less than: $56,838 ($63,398 for married couples filing jointly) if you have three or more qualifying children with a valid SSN, $52,918 ($59,478 for married couples filing jointly) if you have two qualifying children with a valid SSN, $46,560 ($53,120 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with a valid SSN, or $17,640 ($24,210 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with a valid SSN.

Adjusted gross income is the amount shown on line 11 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. If the amount of your adjusted gross income is equal to or greater than the applicable limits listed above, you are not eligible for an EIC.

If you are married but entitled to file a separate tax return under the special rules for married but separated taxpayers (see Rule 3) and you live in a state with a community of property law, your adjusted gross income includes the portion of your wages and salaries that is required to be included in the gross income.

To qualify for an EIC, you (and your spouse if you are filing jointly) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) on the date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions). Your eligible child must have a valid SSN issued at or before the 2023 tax return (including extensions) deadline so that you can claim a higher amount of credit for that child. If you have at least one child who qualifies for an EIC but that child does not have a valid SSN issued at the 2023 tax return (including extensions) deadline, you may be eligible to apply for an EIC without children if you are in principle eligible for the credit. For information on how to complete the EIC Appendix if your eligible child or children do not have a valid SSN issued on or before your return deadline, see the EIC Appendix. For the EIC, the SSN is valid unless it was issued after the 2023 tax return deadline (including extensions) or when it was issued exclusively for the purpose of applying for a federal benefit or for issuing a federal benefit but without granting the right to work. An example of a federal benefit is Medicaid. If you, your spouse or child have a Social Security card that says “Not valid for employment” and your, your spouse’s or your child’s immigration status has changed, and those children are not eligible for an EIC, you may be eligible to apply for an EIC without children.

If you (or your spouse if you are filing a joint tax return) use an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) instead of a Social Security Number, you will not be able to get an EIC. An ITIN is issued by the IRS to non-U.S. citizens who are unable to get a Social Security Number.
If you do not have a valid Social Security number at or before the 2023 tax return deadline (including extensions), mark the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).
If you still haven't received your Social Security number by the time of your tax return, you can apply for an automatic extension of your tax return by filling in the form below.
If you meet these conditions, check the box at the top of the EIC Appendix (Form 1040).
If you were a foreign resident at any time during the year, you cannot receive an EIC unless you file a joint tax return.

If you file Form 2555, “Income from Employment Abroad”, you are not eligible for an EIC because you are filing the forms to exclude income from employment abroad from your gross income or to deduct or exclude payments for housing abroad.

If your investment income is less than $11,000, you are eligible for an EIC. If your investment income is more than $11,000, you are not eligible for an EIC. Use worksheet 1 in this chapter to calculate your investment income.
If you are an employee, your earned income includes all taxable income that you receive from your employer. Rule 15 provides the information you need to calculate your earned income.
Earned income includes the following types of income. 1. Unit wages, salaries, tips and other remuneration of an employee that is subject to taxation. 2.
A report of the wages, salaries and tips you receive for work done is submitted in column 1 of Form W-2.

Other income not reported on Form W-2 includes wages of domestic workers, tips not reported to the employer, tax-exempt Medicaid care benefits if eligible for EIC, tax-exempt dependent care benefits, employer-provided adoption benefits, wages reported on Form 8919, and other income.
To get an EIC, you can include the tax-free warfare cash bonus in your earned income.

The rent or housing allowance provided to a preacher as part of his or her salary is not subject to income tax, but is included in the net profits from the self-employed person’s activity, and therefore is included in the earned income for the purposes of the EIC (except as described in Approved Form 4361 or Form 4029 below).
You are a statutory employee if you receive a Form W-2 with the “Statutory employee” box (box 13) checked.
Benefits paid to you in connection with a strike or lockout, including both cash and the fair market value of other property (except gifts that are actually such), are usually taxable.

Each of the forms provides for a certain amount of income to be exempt from social security tax, and each form contains a list of terms that describe the amounts of income that are earned for the purposes of the EIC.
Regardless of whether you have an approved Form 4361, the payment you receive for performing the duties of a paid employee is considered earned income.
Regardless of whether you have an approved Form 4029, any piece wages, salaries, tips and other remuneration for employment that is subject to taxation is considered earned income.
If you are a disability retiree, the taxable benefit you receive under your employer's disability pension plan is considered earned income until you reach the minimum retirement age.
If you are a member of a disability insurance program, you may not be eligible for earned income.
