If you are married but entitled to file separately or as a primary breadwinner under the special rules for married but separately living taxpayers (see Rule 3), and you live in a state with a matrimonial property law, your earned income does not include any remuneration received by your spouse that is considered to be your property under such laws.

If you are a legal partner under the laws of Nevada, Washington or California, the same rules apply. For the purposes of calculating your EIC, your earned income does not include any payment received by your partner.
U.S. Armed Forces's non-taxable payroll, such as the Combat Payroll, the Basic Housing Allowance (BAH) and the Basic Salary Allowance (BAS), are not considered earned income.
Your child is permanently and totally disabled if the following two conditions apply: 1. He or she cannot engage in any substantial gainful activity because of a physical or mental condition. 2.

A substantial paid activity is one that is performed for a reasonable period of time, working for a salary or wage, or performing a job that is normally performed for a reward or profit. A full-time work (or a part-time work performed at the discretion of the employer) in a competitive workplace, at least for a minimum wage, shows that a child is capable of a substantial paid activity.

An exception to the requirement of a joint tax return applies if your child and his or her spouse file a joint tax return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or an estimated amount of tax paid.
If you have more than one eligible child and only one has a valid SSN, you can use only that child to receive the higher amount of EIC.

If you and someone else have the same qualifying child, but the other person cannot claim the EIC because he or she is not eligible for it, or his or her earned income or AGI is too high, you may consider the child to be qualifying.

For more information on eligibility, see Rule 8. If you are a qualifying child for another taxpayer, you cannot claim an EIC. This is true even if the person for whom you are a qualifying child does not claim an EIC or does not meet all the rules for an EIC.
If you are married and filing jointly, you are eligible if you or your spouse were born after December 31, 1958 and before January 2, 1999.
If you do not file a joint tax return, you do not meet this rule if you do not check the box "Someone can claim you as a dependent" or the box "Someone can claim your spouse as a dependent".

As a rule, the other person cannot declare you as a dependent if you are married and file a joint tax return. However, if you and your spouse file a joint tax return only for the purpose of receiving a refund of income tax withheld from wages or of deductible tax paid, the other person may declare you as a dependent. However, if you apply for an EIC on a joint tax return, the other person may not declare you or your spouse as a dependent.

For details on eligibility, see Rule 8. If you are a qualifying child of another taxpayer, you cannot claim an EIC. This limitation applies even if the person for whom you are a qualifying child does not apply for an EIC or does not meet all the requirements for an EIC.

As a rule, you cannot qualify as a child of another taxpayer if you are married and filing a joint tax return. However, if you claim an EIC on a joint tax return, neither you nor your spouse can qualify as a child of another taxpayer.
If this statement does not apply to you, enter “No” on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

Your earned income must be less than: $56,838 ($63,398 for married couples filing jointly) if you have three or more qualifying children with valid SSNs, $52,918 ($59,478 for married couples filing jointly) if you have two qualifying children with valid SSNs, $46,560 ($53,120 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with valid SSNs, or $17,640 ($24,210 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with valid SSNs.
As a rule, earned income is wages, salaries, tips, other remuneration for work subject to taxation, and net profits from self-employment.

If you are a sole proprietor, a statutory employee or a clergyman or a church employee and you are filing a Schedule SE (Form 1040), you should calculate your earned income using the worksheet in Step 5 of the Form 1040 instructions for line 27, and then complete Part 4 of the EIC worksheet in the Form 1040 instructions.

If you are a clergyman filing Schedule SE and the amount on line 2 of that Schedule includes an amount reported on Form 1040 or 1040-SR on line 1z, subtract that amount from the amount on line 1z of Form 1040 or 1040-SR and enter the result on line 1 of the table in Step 5 of the Form 1040 Line 27a instructions. Enter "Clergy" on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).
When filling out the worksheet in Step 5 of the Instructions for Form 1040, line 27, enter the above mentioned Medicaid payments that you excluded from your income in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8s.

If you have a qualifying child, complete the EIC Appendix (described later in this chapter) and attach it to your tax return. If you would like an EIC calculated by the IRS, see the section "The IRS will calculate the EIC for you" above.
To calculate the amount of EIC you need to select worksheet A EIC or worksheet B EIC. This section contains tips on how to use the worksheets and how to state the EIC in your tax return.
If you were not self-employed at any time in 2023 and you are not a clergyman, a church employee filing Schedule SE, or a full-time employee filing Schedule C, you must use Worksheet A of the EIC.
If you were a self-employed person or a clergyman, a church employee filing Schedule SE, or a full-time employee filing Schedule C at any time in 2023, you must use Worksheet B EIC.
If your net income from self-employment is $400 or more, you must complete the appropriate Self-Employment Tax Form 1040. Otherwise, you may not receive the full amount of EIC you are entitled to.

You must complete Part 1 and Part 2 of Worksheet B EIC if all of the following statements are true for you. 1. You are married and file a joint tax return with your spouse. 2. Both you and your spouse have self-employed income. 3. You or your spouse have filed a Schedule SE and the other of you does not.
If you are required to submit a Form 8862 with your 2023 tax return, but you are applying for an EIC without a completed Form 8862, you will automatically be denied the benefit.

Sharon Jamie is 63 years old and retired. She received $7,000 in social security benefits and $17,000 in part-time income. She also received a taxable pension of $7,400. Sharon cannot be declared as a dependent on any other person's tax return. She has no investment income and no child who would qualify.
Cynthia and Jerry Gray have two children, Kirk, 10, and Susan, 8. The children lived with Cynthia and Jerry throughout 2023.

The amount reported by Cynthia and Jerry on line 11 of Form 1040 is $23,555. Both have a valid SSN for many years. They are married and are about to file a joint return. Neither Cynthia nor Jerry are non-resident foreigners.
The Grays’ only investment income is $525. That’s less than $11,000, so they answer “No” to the second question in Step 2 and move on to Step 3.
Cynthia and Jerry have calculated their total income to be $33,030. That is less than $59,478, so they go to Step 6 to calculate their credit.
Cynthia and Jerry want to calculate their EIC themselves, so they fill out the EIC worksheet in the instructions for the 1040 (see below).

Cynthia and Jerry fill out their worksheet as follows. 1. Cynthia and Jerry enter their total earned income ($33,030) on line 1. 2. To determine their deduction, they go to the EIC table. They find their income of $33,030 in the range of $33,050.

Added a checkbox button to Form 2848 (Power of Attorney and Representative Declaration) to allow taxpayers to authorize their authorized representative to access the taxpayer's IRS records through an intermediate service provider. For more information, see Power of Attorney for Accessing IRS Electronic Records Through Intermediate Service Providers in the Form 2848 instructions.

Priority Service Implementation® (PPS). Priority Service Implementation® is a national toll-free hotline that provides professional support to tax filing practitioners on accounting-related issues. The toll-free number for this service is 1-866-860-4259. Annual Tax Filing Season Program (AFSP) and Federal Tax Filler Guide. The Annual Tax Filing Season Program is a voluntary program that grants limited practice rights to tax filing practitioners who are not lawyers, licensed accountants, or registered agents. The IRS issues an annual report on the Annual Tax Filing Season Program for tax filing practitioners who receive a certain number of hours of continuous education in preparation for a particular tax year. Tax filing practitioners do not have unlimited practice rights (unless they are also lawyers, licensed accountants, or registered agents). Their rights are limited to representing clients whose returns they have prepared and signed, but only before tax agents, customer service representatives, and similar IRS staff, including the Taxpayer Advice Service. They may not represent clients whose returns they have not prepared and signed, nor may they represent clients before collection or appeals functions. See IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Annual-Filing-Season-Program 1:1 for more information on the AFSP, which has searchable databases of tax filing practitioners with PTINs who have professional credentials recognized by the IRS or proof of completion of the Annual Tax Filing Season Program.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as “registered agent” and “practitioner”, are defined in the Glossary near the end of this publication.
Visit IRS.gov/FormsPubs to download forms and publications. Or you can go to IRS.gov/OrderForms to order current and previous year's forms and instructions.

In connection with their special relationship with the taxpayer, the following persons may represent the taxpayer with the IRS provided that they provide satisfactory identification and, except for the individual described in paragraph (1) below, proof of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. Individual. An individual may represent himself or herself with the IRS and does not need to file a written declaration of qualifications and authority. 2. Family member. A person may represent his or her immediate relatives. The immediate family includes a spouse, child, parent, brother or sister of a person. 3. Official. A genuine official of a corporation (including a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), association or organized group may represent a corporation, association or organized group. An official of a government body, agency or other body with authority may, in the performance of his or her official duties, represent a government body, agency or other body with authority with the IRS. 4. Partner. A general partner may represent a partnership with the IRS. 5. Employee. A full-time employee may represent his or her employer. The definition of employer includes, but is not limited to, an individual, partnership, corporation (including a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), association, trust, out-of-state administration, trusteeship, estate, organized group, public body, agency or body with authority. 6. Trustee. A trustee (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, receiver or guardian) acts as the taxpayer and does not act as a representative. See Section 10.1.
Any registered agent with active status who is not currently suspended or disqualified from representing before the IRS may represent before the IRS.

Generally, persons who do not meet the participation criteria or who have lost their privilege as a result of certain actions are not eligible to represent before the IRS.1 If an individual loses his or her right to represent, the IRS will not recognize a power of attorney that designates the person as a representative.2

Registered individuals and those with a confirmed end of Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) that are not eligible for an extension will receive a notification from the IRS that explains the reason for the ineligibility and gives them an opportunity to provide information for re-examination.

The registered person must apply for renewal within 3 years, and meet all the requirements for renewal after being turned into inactive status. Otherwise, at the end of the next renewal cycle, he will be removed from the list and the registration status will be cancelled.

All persons representing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary action and may be reprimanded, suspended, disqualified from the practice or fined for violating any provision of Circular 230. This includes engaging in acts that demonstrate incompetence or improper conduct. For more information, see the “Incumplicence and Improper Conduct” subsection in the “What are the Rules of Representation” section below. Professionals who are suspended or disqualified from the practice in disciplinary proceedings may not represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension/disqualification. The practitioner may apply for reinstatement to the Professional Responsibility Division before the specified period of suspension or after five years of imprisonment. See the “What is Representation before the IRS” section above. If a practitioner seeks reinstatement, he or she may not represent before the IRS until the Professional Responsibility Division gives permission for reinstatement. The Professional Responsibility Division may reinstate the practitioner: u1 if the future conduct of the practitioner is unlikely to violate the rules and if the granting of reinstatement would not be contrary to the public interest, subject to other conditions and for a reasonable period of time.

The rules governing representation with the IRS are published in the Federal Rules, namely: 31 C.F.R. Subpart A, Part 10 and are available in digital form as Treasury Circular No. 230 (Circular 230). A lawyer, licensed accountant, registered agent, registered pension plan agent or registered actuary authorized to practice with the IRS (hereinafter referred to as a practitioner) and an appraiser are required to perform certain actions and are prohibited from performing other actions.

The presumption of due diligence will apply in situations where the results of another person have been relied upon if reasonable care has been taken in the recruitment, supervision, training and evaluation of that person, with due regard to the nature of the relationship between the individual subject to Circular 230 and that person.
Persons covered by Circular 230 are not to unduly delay the expeditious processing of any matter by the IRS.

Individuals covered by Circular 230 may not sign any cheque (including sending or receiving payment by any means, electronic or otherwise, to an account owned or controlled by the professional, or any firm or other organization with which the professional is associated) issued by the state as a federal tax liability.

Persons covered by Circular 230 may be disqualified from the practice of law or suspended from practice before the IRS, and may be subject to reprimands for incompetence or improper conduct. A monetary fine may also be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on both individuals and their firms. The following list provides examples of conduct deemed improper. Examples are provided in Circular 230, Section 10.51(a). Being convicted of any criminal offence under tax law or any offence involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Knowingly providing or engaging in false or misleading information in connection with federal tax matters. Extorting work by prohibited means as discussed in Section 10.30 of Circular 230. Willfully failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade payment of any federal tax or payment, or engaging in such conduct. Misappropriating or improperly and timely transferring money received from clients for the payment of taxes or other obligations due to the United States. Attempting to influence, directly or indirectly, the official actions of IRS officials by threats, false accusations, pressure or coercion, and by offering gifts, services or any special incentives. Being disqualified from the practice of law or suspended from practice as a lawyer, licensed accountant, public accountant or actuary by the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, possession, territory, Commonwealth, any federal court, any federal agency, agency or body.
A power of attorney is your written authorization for an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to perform certain actions on your behalf.

Lawyers, licensed accountants and registered agents may perform the following actions: 1. Sign an offer or waiver of a limitation on the assessment or collection of a debt, as well as a waiver of a claim for a tax credit or refund.
When signed by a representative, it must be accompanied by a power of attorney (or a copy) authorizing the representative to sign the declaration.

A trust can be extended in the event of your incapacity or incompetence if you allow it in line 5a “Other Actions Allowed” of Form 2848 and if your long-term non-IRS trust meets all the requirements for IRS acceptance.

If you want to authorize another person to receive your confidential tax information and represent you to the IRS, regardless of whether the agent performs any of the other actions mentioned earlier in the section What is a Power of Attorney.
The IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all the above information.
The proxy agent named in your non-IRS proxy can sign the Form 2848 on your behalf. 1.

Typically, when you file a proxy with the IRS, it is processed for inclusion in the CAF system. It also allows the IRS to automatically send copies of IRS notifications and other communications to your proxy if you specify that your proxy should receive these communications.
To determine where to send the Form 2848, see the section on Where to File the Form 2848. For more information on the specific use, see Line 4.
If you choose to send the power of attorney by fax, make sure that the appropriate IRS office is equipped to receive such a type of mail.

Submit any update or change to an existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the person(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do so by sending the updated Form 2848 or the non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously sent the original power of attorney, including the service center where the relevant return was or will be filed.

The new power of attorney on the same subject shall cancel the previous power of attorney, provided it specifically states that it does not cancel the previous power of attorney and is accompanied by one of the following provisions: a copy of the previously unrevoked power of attorney, or a statement signed by the taxpayer, stating the name and address of each representative authorized under the previously revoked power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously issued power of attorney and do not want to appoint a new one, you must write “REVOKE” at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date immediately below that annotation.

If your representative wants to withdraw the representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW” at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date immediately below the annotation. In this case, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with an annotation of the withdrawal to the IRS in the manner described in the subsection “Withdraw by the Taxpayer” above.

For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which abolished the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and rules applicable to the election of large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, eliminated the role of the “tax partner” and replaced it with a “partnership representative.” Under section 301.9100-22T of the Treasury Department’s regulations, some partnerships may choose to apply the new regime to partner returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015 and before January 1, 2016.

The power of attorney is recognized once it is received by the IRS, verified for all necessary information, and approved. However, until the power of attorney is registered in the Central Authorization File, the IRS may not be aware of the authority of the person who is selected to represent the taxpayer.

If the taxpayer does not have a signature or a date, the IRS will try to contact the taxpayer's representative. Otherwise, the power of attorney will be invalidated until the missing information is completed and approved by the IRS.

If the power of attorney is complete and valid, the IRS will initiate the approval process for the agent. For example, a power of attorney signed for a single purpose or giving a representative specific powers of attorney is not processed in the Centralized Authorization File.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to enable taxpayers to make secure electronic payments. Electronic payments can be made online, by phone and in the IRS2Go app from a mobile device. Electronic payments are faster and easier than paying by check or money order. Go to IRS.gov/Payments to pay taxes using any of the following features. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or deductible tax directly from your current or savings account for free. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment system to pay online, by phone or from a mobile device. Electronic Withholding Tax: Available only when filing federal taxes using tax calculator software or for tax consultant services. Electronic Federal Tax Payment: Best for companies. Registration required. Check or postal money transfer: The payment must be sent to the address listed in the notice or instructions.

Low-Income Taxpayer Assistance Centers are independent organizations. They represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and who need to solve problems in dealing with the IRS, such as audits, filing appeals and collecting taxes.
Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely view your personal federal tax account.

The fastest way to get your tax refund is by direct bank transfer and electronic filing. With direct bank transfer, the tax refund is securely transferred electronically directly to the taxpayer's bank account. 8 out of 10 taxpayers receive their tax refund by direct bank transfer. The IRS sends more than 90% of payments in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in law, the IRS may not make payments on returns filed for Earned Income Credit (EIC) or Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC) before mid-February 2018, and this applies to the entire payment, not only to the portion related to the earned income credits.

The IRS.gov/EIC Helper will help you determine if you are eligible for an earned income credit (EIC). The IRS.gov/EIN Helper will help you calculate the amount that should be deducted from your salary as federal income tax.
